ADOPTING ORDINANCES



ORDINANCE NO. 16-05-06



AN ORDINANCE ENACTING A CODE OF ORDINANCES FOR THE CITY OF HENDERSON,
REVISING, AMENDING, RESTATING, CODIFYING AND COMPILING CERTAIN EXISTING
GENERAL ORDINANCES OF THE POLITICAL SUBDIVISION DEALING WITH SUBJECTS
EMBRACED IN SUCH CODE OF ORDINANCES, AND THE EFFECTIVE DATE THEREOF.



   WHEREAS, the present general and permanent ordinances of the political
subdivision are inadequately arranged and classified and are insufficient in
form and substance for the complete preservation of the public peace, health,
safety and general welfare of the municipality and for the proper conduct of
its affairs; and



   WHEREAS, the Acts of Legislature of the State of Texas empower and
authorize the political subdivision to revise, amend, restate, codify and
compile any existing ordinances and all new ordinances not heretofore adopted
or published and to incorporate such ordinances into one ordinance in book
form;



   WHEREAS, the Legislative Authority of the Political Subdivision has
authorized a general compilation, revision and codification of the ordinances
of the Political Subdivision of a general and permanent nature and
publication of such ordinance in book form; and



   WHEREAS, it is necessary to provide for the usual daily operation of
the municipality and for the immediate preservation of the public peace,
health, safety and general welfare of the municipality that this ordinance
take effect at an early date.



   NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF
HENDERSON, TEXAS:



   SECTION 1:   The general ordinances of the Political Subdivision as
revised, amended, restated, codified, and compiled in book form are hereby
adopted as and shall constitute the "Code of Ordinances of the City of
Henderson, Texas".



   SECTION 2:   Such Code of Ordinances as adopted in Section 1 shall
consist of the following Titles:



   SECTION 3:   All prior ordinances pertaining to the subjects treated
in such Code of Ordinances shall be deemed repealed from and after the
effective date of this ordinance except as they are included and reordained
in whole or in part in such Code; provided, such repeal shall not affect any
offense committed or penalty incurred or any right established prior to the
effective date of this ordinance, nor shall such repeal affect the provisions
of ordinances levying taxes, appropriating money, annexing or detaching
territory, establishing franchises, or granting special rights to certain
persons, authorizing public improvements, authorizing the issuance of bonds
or borrowing of money, authorizing the purchase or sale of real or personal
property, granting or accepting easements, plat or dedication of land to
public use, vacating or setting the boundaries of streets or other public
places; nor shall such repeal affect any other ordinance of a temporary or
special nature or pertaining to subjects not contained in or covered by the
Code.



   SECTION 4:   Such Code shall be deemed published as of the day of
its adoption and approval by the Legislature Authority and the Clerk of the
Political Subdivision is hereby authorized and ordered to file a copy of such
Code of the Ordinance in the Office of the City Secretary.



   SECTION 5:   Such Code shall be in full force and effect as provided
in Section 6, and such Code shall be presumptive evidence in all courts and
places of the ordinance and all provisions, sections, penalties and
regulations therein contained and of the date of passage, and that the same
is properly signed, attested, recorded, and approved and that any public
hearings and notices thereof as required by the law have been given.



   SECTION 6:   That this ordinance shall take full effect and force
upon the final passage by the City Council of the City of Henderson, Texas.



   PASSED AND APPROVED this first reading on the 12th of May, 2016.



   PASSED, APPROVED AND ADOPTED this second reading on the ___th of June,
2016.



                        _____________________________



                        Patricia L. Brack, Mayor



ATTEST:



______________________________



Stephanie Kimbrell, City Secretary



HOME RULE CHARTER



   Editor’s note:



      Printed herein is the Charter of the City of Henderson, Texas,
which was adopted at an election held on April 1, 1947



ARTICLE I. NAME AND BOUNDARIES



Section 1.  Corporate name.



   All the inhabitants of the Town of Henderson, in Rusk County, Texas, as
the boundaries and limits of said town are herein established, shall be a
body politic, incorporated under, and to be known by the name and style of
the “City of Henderson,” with such powers, rights and duties as are
herein provided.



Section 2.  Boundaries.



   The boundaries and limits of said corporation shall include the
following boundaries as adopted by the Home Rule Charter of the City of
Henderson on April 1, 1947, plus any and all modifications whether by
annexation or disannexation subsequent to April 1, 1947.



Part of the Smith, Warren, Bennett, Starr, Johnson, Sory, Brooks, Brumley
Surveys, in Rusk County, Texas:



BEGINNING one mile due South from the center of the Courthouse in said town
of Henderson;



THENCE E 145 vrs to the middle of the Mt. Enterprise Road continuing E at 925
vrs the West bank of Dutch Creek and at 1900 vrs to a cor in W.E. Shadden’s
field from which a cabin in Shadden’s field brs N 39’45” E 133 2-10 vrs
the oil mill tower brs N 31’15” W;



THENCE N 1260 vrs the Pine Hill Road and 1360 vrs the Carthage Road and at
1520 vrs E edge of Willow Lake and continuing N across said lake at 3800 vrs
to a cor; from which a red oak brs N 53’30” E 15-1/2 vrs a sweet gum brs
S 44’20” W the N E cor of W.D. Arnold’s land brs S 85’45”E 11 vrs;



THENCE W 1900 vrs to a point due North of said Courthouse and at 3800 vrs in
all to a cor in R.E. Huston’s orchard from which Huston’s west chimney
brs S 2’30”;



THENCE S 140 vrs the Overton Road and at 1900 vrs one mile due West of the
Courthouse and continuing due S at 3800 vrs a cor in Gould’s pasture from
which a sweet gum 20 in dia brs N 11’40” E 34-1/2 vrs a post oak 15 in
dia N 4710” W;



THENCE E 534 vrs Shawnee Creek and at 1900 vrs in all the beginning, one mile
due South of the Courthouse.



Also the following:



BEGINNING at a point established as the Northwest Corner of the City of
Henderson prior to the 12th day of March, 1936, according to the filed notes
recorded in Vol. 70, page 190 of the Deed Records of Rusk County, Texas.



THENCE due West 950 vrs to a stake for corner;



THENCE due South 3800 vrs to a stake for corner;



THENCE due East to a point established for the Southwest Corner of the City
of Henderson as it existed prior to the 12th day of March, 1936, and
according to said field notes recorded in Volume 70, page 190, of the Deed
Records of Rusk County, Texas;



THENCE due North 3800 vrs along and with the West Boundary Line of the City
of Henderson as it existed prior to the 12th day of March, 1936, as
established according to said field notes recorded in Vol. 70, page 190, of
the Deed Records of Rusk County, Texas, to the place of beginning.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 1)



Statutory reference:



   Municipal boundaries and annexation, see Tex. Local Gov’t Code, Ch.
41 et seq.



Section 3.  Platting of property.



   (a)   Should any property within the City Limits be hereafter
platted into blocks, lots, additions or subdivisions, the owner thereof shall
plat and lay the same off to conform to streets and alleys abutting the same,
and in conformity with the Zoning Ordinances of the City; all such plats,
together with proposed restrictions, before recording in the Deed Records,
shall be submitted to the Council for approval and until and unless approved
no such lots, blocks, subdivisions or additions shall be officially
recognized or accepted by the City.



   (b)   In addition to the platting above provided, it is expressly
provided, by the adoption of this Charter by vote of the qualified voters of
the City, that the provisions of Article 974-a, as amended from time to time,
relating to platting of subdivisions and the approval and recording thereof,
are hereby adopted and made a part hereof as though fully copied at length
herein, and as cumulative and in addition to subsection (a) of this section.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 2)



Statutory references:



   Plat required for division of tract, see Tex. Local Gov’ Code, §
212.004



   Recording of plats, see Tex. Property Code, § 12.002



Section 4.  Extension of boundaries.



   The City Council shall have the power by ordinance to annex additional
property lying adjacent to the city in accordance with Article 970-a V.A.T.S.
known as the Municipal Annexation Act [V.T.C.A., Local Government Code sec.
43.001 et seq.].



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 3)



Statutory references:



   Authority of home-rule municipality to annex area, see Tex. Local
Gov’t Code, § 43.021



   Municipal annexation, see Tex. Local Gov’t Code, Ch. 43



   Municipal boundaries and annexation, see Tex. Local Gov’t Code, Ch.
41 et seq.



ARTICLE II. CORPORATE POWERS



Section 1.  General.



   The City of Henderson shall from henceforth have and enjoy the benefits
of local self-government, shall have perpetual succession, may use a common
seal, may sue and be sued, may contract and be contracted with, implead and
be impleaded in all courts and places and in all matters whatever; may take,
hold and purchase lands, within or without the city limits, as may be needed
for the corporate purposes of said city, and may sell any real estate or
personal property owned by it; perform and render all public services, and
when deemed expedient, may condemn property for corporate use, and may hold,
manage and control the same, and shall be subject to all the duties and
obligations now pertaining to or incumbent upon said Town of Henderson as a
corporation, not in conflict with the provision of this charter, and shall
enjoy all the rights, immunities, powers, privileges and franchises now
possessed by said town and herein conferred and granted.



Statutory references:



   Authority of local self-government, see Tex. Local Gov’t Code, §
51.072



   General powers of home-rule municipality, see Tex. Local Gov’t Code,
§§ 51.071 et seq.



   Powers of home-rule municipality, see Tex. Local Gov’t Code, §§
9.0001 et seq.



Section 2.  Power of ordinances.



   The City of Henderson shall have the power to enact and enforce all
ordinances necessary to protect health, life and property, and to prevent and
summarily abate and remove all nuisances and to preserve and enforce the good
government, order and security of the city and its inhabitants, and to enact
and enforce ordinances on any and all subjects, provided, that no ordinance
shall be enacted inconsistent with the provisions of this charter, or the
general laws or constitution of the State of Texas.



Statutory reference:



   Ordinance, rule or regulation necessary to carry out other powers, see
Tex. Local Gov’t Code, § 51.001



Section 3.  Style of ordinances.



   The style of all ordinances of the City of Henderson shall be: “Be It
Ordained by the [city council of the] City of Henderson,” but the same may
be omitted when published in book or pamphlet form purporting to be published
by the City of Henderson.



Section 4.  Real estate.



   All real estate owned in fee simple title or held by lease, sufferance,
easement or otherwise; all public buildings, fire stations, parks, streets
and alleys, and all property, whether real or personal, of whatever kind,
character or description, now owned or controlled by the Town of Henderson,
shall vest in, inure to, remain and be the property of the said City of
Henderson.



Section 5.  Acquisition of property.



   The City of Henderson shall have the power and authority to acquire by
purchase, gift, devise, deed, condemnation or otherwise any character of
property, including any charitable or trust fund.



Statutory reference:



   Authority relating to property, see Tex. Local Gov’t Code, § 51.076



Section 6.  Eminent domain.



   Said City shall have the right of eminent domain and the power to
appropriate private property for public purposes whenever the governing
authority shall deem it necessary; and to take any private property, within
or without the city limits for any of the following purposes, to wit:
Cemeteries, airports, city halls, police stations, jails, calabooses, fire
stations and fire alarm systems, libraries, hospitals, sanitariums,
auditoriums, market houses, reformatories, abattoirs, streets, alleys, parks,
highways, playgrounds, sewer systems, storm sewers, sewerage disposal plants,
filtering beds and emptying grounds for sewer systems, drainage, water and
electric light and power systems, streetcar systems, telephone and telegraph
systems, gas plants or gas systems, crematories, prison farms, pest houses,
and to acquire lands within or without the city, for any other municipal
purpose that may be deemed advisable. That the power herein granted for the
purpose of acquiring private property shall include the power of improvement
and enlargement of waterworks, including water supply, riparian rights, stand
pipes, watersheds, and the construction of supply reservoirs. In all cases
where the city exercises the power of eminent domain, it shall be controlled,
as nearly as practicable, by the laws governing the condemnation of property
by railroad corporations in this state; the city taking the position of the
railroad corporations in such cases.



Statutory references:



   Eminent domain, see Tex. Property Code, Ch. 21



   Municipal right of eminent domain, see Tex. Local Gov’t Code, Ch. 251



Section 7.  Improvements.



   To appropriate so much of the revenues of the city emanating from
whatever source, for the purpose of retiring and discharging the accrued
indebtedness of the city and for the purpose of erecting and maintaining city
hall, and other public buildings and projects, and for maintaining public
parks and playgrounds, as may from time to time be expedient.



Section 8.  Public utility systems.



   (a)   Said City shall have the power to buy or own, or construct,
and to maintain and operate, within or without the city limits, complete
water system or systems, gas or electric lighting or power plant or plants,
telephone systems, street railways, sewer systems, sewerage plants,
fertilizing plants, abattoirs, municipal railway systems, or any other public
service utility, and to demand and receive compensation for services
furnished by the city for private purposes or otherwise, and to have the
power to regulate, by ordinance, the collection of compensation for such
services. That said City shall have the power to acquire by lease, purchase
or condemnation, the property of any person, firm or corporation now or
hereafter conducting any such business, for the purpose of operating such
public utility or utilities, and for the purpose of distributing such service
throughout the City or any portion thereof.



   (b)   Should the City determine to acquire any public utility by
purchase, condemnation or otherwise, as herein provided, said City shall have
the power to obtain funds for the purpose of acquiring said public utility
and paying the compensation therefor, by issuing bonds or notes, may secure
such notes by fixing a lien upon the property constituting the public utility
so acquired, and said security shall apply alone to said property so pledged.



Statutory references:



   Municipal home-rule powers to regulate public utilities and franchises
using streets, etc., see Tex. Local Gov’t Code, §§ 9.0001 et seq.



   Municipal utilities, see Tex. Local Gov’t Code, §§ 552.001 et seq.



Section 9.  Operation of public utility by city.



   Said City shall have the authority to manufacture its own electricity,
gas or anything else that may be needed for public use, to make contracts
with any person, firm or corporation for the purchase of gas, water,
electricity or any other commodity or articles used by it or the public, and
to sell same to the public as may be determined by the governing authority.



   In the event said City shall acquire by purchase, gift, devise, or
deed, condemnation or otherwise, any waterworks system, electric light or
power system, gas system, street railway system, telephone system, or any
other public service utility, to operate and maintain for the purpose of
serving the inhabitants of said City, the right to operate and maintain such
public service utility, so acquired, shall be exclusive.



Statutory references:



   Authority for municipal public services and utility systems in
home-rule municipalities, see Tex. Local Gov’t Code, § 552.002



   Municipal jurisdiction over electric utility, see Tex. Utilities Code,
Ch. 33



   Municipal jurisdiction over rates, operations and services of gas
utility, see Tex. Utilities Code, Ch. 103



   Municipal jurisdiction over water and sewer utility rates, operations
and services, see Tex. Water Code, § 13.042



   Public Utility Regulatory Act, see Tex. Utilities Code, Ch. 11 et seq.



   Water systems in home-rule municipalities, see Tex. Local Gov’t Code,
§ 552.017



Section 10.  Reserved.



Editor’s note:



   Section 4 of an amendment of April 6, 1985, repealed section 10 in its
entirety. Former section 10 pertained to the regulation of charges and
licenses on franchises and trades



Section 11.  Streets, etc., paving, improvement and assessments.



   The City of Henderson shall have exclusive dominion, control and
jurisdiction in, upon, over, and under the public streets, avenues, alleys
and highways of the City and to provide for the improvement thereof by
paving, repaving, raising, grading, draining, or otherwise; the provision of
Title 28, Chapter 9, of the 1925 Revised Civil Statutes of Texas, together
with existing amendments and such amendments as hereinafter may be made, are
expressly adopted by reference herein in regard to the powers of the City
over such properties, the order for improvements, the levying of costs
thereof, the assessment of railroads and street railroads, the assessments
against owners of abutting property, and certificates as evidencing the
owner’s obligations, the exemption of certain properties, the enforcement
of liens thus created, the notice of hearing thereunder, the hearing, the
reassessments, the right of an owner to sue thereunder, provision for special
reassessment, and notice thereunder, special liens to be created, the time
and amount of such assessment, or reassessment, and the dates on which such
assessment or reassessment shall be enforceable.



Statutory references:



   Assessment for street improvements, see Tex. Transportation Code, §
311.091



   Assessment of costs of improvements on abutting properties, see Tex.
Transportation Code, §§ 313.041 et seq.



   Authority of municipality over and under public highways, streets and
alleys, see Tex. Transportation Code, § 311.001



   Street improvements and assessments in cities having more than 1,000
inhabitants, see Tex. Transportation Code, Ch. 313



Section 12.  Sidewalks, curbs and gutters.



   Said City shall have the power to provide for the construction and
building of sidewalks and to charge the entire cost of the construction of
such sidewalks, including the curb and gutter, against the owner of the
abutting property and to make a special charge against the owner for such
cost, and to provide by special assessment a lien against such property for
such cost.



Statutory references:



   Assessment for construction of sidewalks and curbs, see Tex.
Transportation Code, § 311.093



   Authority over sidewalks, see Tex. Transportation Code, § 311.004



Section 13.  Repair of sidewalks, etc.



   Said City shall have the power to provide for the construction,
improvement or repair of any such sidewalk, or the construction of any such
curb and gutter, by penal ordinance, and to declare defective sidewalks to be
a public nuisance.



Statutory reference:



   Authority over sidewalks, see Tex. Transportation Code, § 311.004



Section 14.  Franchises.



   Said City shall have the power and authority to grant franchises for
the use and occupancy of the streets, avenues, alleys, and any and all public
grounds belonging to or under the control of the City. No telegraphs,
telephone, electric light or power, street railway, interurban railway, steam
railway, gas company, waterworks, water systems or any other character of
public utilities shall be granted any franchise or permitted the use of any
street, avenue, alley, highway or grounds of the City without first making
application to and obtaining the consent of the governing authorities
thereto, expressed by ordinance, and upon paying such compensation as may be
prescribed, and upon such conditions as may be provided for by such
ordinance, and before such ordinance proposing to make any grant or franchise
or privilege to any applicant to use or occupy any street, avenue, alleys or
other public ground belonging to the City, or under its control, shall become
effective, publication of such ordinance as finally proposed to be passed,
shall be made in some newspaper published in the City of Henderson, once a
week for three consecutive weeks, which such publication shall be made at the
expense of the applicant desiring said grant, and said proposed ordinance
shall not be thereafter changed unless republished as in the first instance,
nor shall any such ordinance take effect or become a law or contract or vest
any rights in the applicant therefor until after the expiration of thirty
days from the last publication of said ordinance, as aforesaid.



Statutory references:



   Authority to grant franchise to use or occupy public grounds, see Tex.
Local Gov’t Code, § 282.003



   Franchise to use streets in municipality, see Tex. Transportation Code,
§§ 311.071 et seq.



   Municipal home-rule powers to regulate public utilities and franchises
using streets, etc., see Tex. Local Gov’t Code, §§ 9.0001 et seq.



Section 15.  Street improvements, widening, etc.



   Said City shall have the power to open, extend, straighten and widen
any public street, avenue, or alley, and for such purpose to acquire the
necessary land by purchase or condemnation, and to provide that the cost of
improving any such streets, avenues or alleys by opening, extending,
straightening or widening, the same shall be paid by the owner of property
lying in the territory of such improvement, and which is especially
benefitted thereby; and to provide that the cost shall be charged by special
assessment against such owner and his property for the amount due by him, and
three special commissioners shall be appointed by the county judge of Rusk
County, Texas, for the purpose of condemning said land and apportioning said
cost, and such apportionment shall be specially assessed by the governing
authority of said City against the owner or owners and their property lying
in the territory so found by said special commissioners to be specially
benefitted in enhanced values, and said City may issue assignable
certificates for the payment of any such cost against such property owner and
his property, and may provide for the payment thereof in deferred payments,
which deferred payments shall bear interest at the rate of not exceeding
eight per centum per annum. Said City shall pay such portion of such cost as
may be determined by said special commissioners to be due by it; provided the
cost paid by the City shall never exceed one-half of the cost of such
improvement.



Statutory references:



   Assessment for street improvements, see Tex. Transportation Code, §
311.091



   Assessment of costs of improvements on abutting properties, see Tex.
Transportation Code, §§ 313.041 et seq.



   Authority of municipality over and under public highways, streets and
alleys, see Tex. Transportation Code, § 311.001



   Street improvements and assessments in cities having more than 1,000
inhabitants, see Tex. Transportation Code, Ch. 313



Section 16.  Opening streets.



   Said City shall have the power to control, regulate and remove all
obstructions, encroachments, and encumbrances on any public street, avenue or
alley, and to narrow, alter, widen, straighten, vacate, abandon the same, and
create and open up new streets where deemed needed; to provide for sprinkling
and cleaning same, and to regulate and control the moving and building and
structures of every kind and character upon and along the same.



Section 17.  Parks.



   Said City shall have exclusive control over all city parks and
playgrounds, within or without the city limits, and to control, regulate and
remove all obstructions and prevent all encroachments thereupon; and to
provide for raising, grading, filling, terracing, landscape gardening,
erecting buildings, providing amusements therein, for establishing walks and
paving driveways around, in and through said parks, maintaining zoological
gardens, playgrounds and other public grounds, and appropriating funds
therefor.



Statutory reference:



   Authority to acquire and maintain parks, museums and historic sites,
see Tex. Local Gov’t Code, Ch. 331



Section 18.  General miscellaneous powers.



   Said City shall have the power to define all nuisances, prohibit the
same within the city limits, outside of the city limits for a distance of
5,000 feet; to police all parks, grounds, speedways, streets, avenues and
alleys owned by said City, within or without the city limits; to prohibit the
pollution of all sources of water supply of said City, and to provide for the
protection of watersheds; to provide for the inspection of dairies, cows and
dairy herds, slaughter pens and slaughter houses and abattoirs, within or
without the city limits from which meat, milk, butter or eggs from same are
furnished to the inhabitants of said City, and to provide for the inspection
of meat markets, grocery stores, drugstores, confectioneries, fruit stands,
ice cream factories, laundries, bottling plants, hotels, restaurants, and
bakeries, and the source, storage and distribution of water, and all other
places where food or drinks for human consumption are manufactured, handled,
sold or exposed for sale, and to regulate and inspect the character and
standards of such articles of food and drinks so sold or offered for sale; to
provide for the inspection and regulation of the sanitary condition of all
premises and vacant lots within the city limits, for the removal of garbage,
night soil, refuse and unsanitary vegetation; to provide for establishing a
lien against the property for any expense incurred by the City in enforcing
this provision, and further to provide for the making and enforcing of all
proper and reasonable regulations for the health and sanitation of said City
and its inhabitants; and to provide for a health department and the
establishing of rules and regulations protecting the health of the City; the
establishing of quarantine station, pest houses, and hospitals, and to
provide for the adoption of necessary quarantine laws to protect the
inhabitants against contagious and infectious diseases; to provide for a
sanitary sewer system and for the maintenance thereof; to require property
owners to make connections with such sewer with their premises, and to
provide for fixing a lien against any property owner’s premises who fails
or refuses to make sanitary sewer connections and to charge the cost against
the said owner and make it a personal liability, and to fix penalties for
failure to make sanitary sewer connections; to restrict the use of any toilet
facility where sanitary sewerage is available; to require property owners,
their agents and lessees to remove within a reasonable time, ice, slush, snow
and other debris from sidewalks fronting on property owned, occupied or
controlled by such owner, agent, lessee, and to require such owner, agent or
lessee to remove all low hanging limbs from trees adjacent to sidewalks in
said City; to provide for social security, pensions, hospitalization and
medical attention for employees; to provide for the regulation and
prohibition of driving herds of horses, mules, cattle, hogs, sheep, goats and
all herds of domestic animals along or upon the streets, avenues or alleys of
said City; to establish and regulate public pounds and regulate, restrain and
prohibit the running at large of horses, mules, cattle, sheep, swine, goats,
chickens, pigeons, ducks and all other domesticated animals and fowls, and to
authorize the restraining, impounding and sale of the same for the cost of
the proceedings and the penalty incurred, and to order their destruction when
they cannot be sold and to impose penalties upon the owner thereof for the
violation of any ordinances regulating or prohibiting the same, and to tax,
regulate, restrain and prohibit the running at large of dogs, and to
authorize their destruction and impose penalties on the owners or keepers
thereof; to prohibit the inhumane treatment of animals and provide punishment
therefor; to prohibit and restrain the flying of kites, firing of firearms,
fireworks, rolling of hoops, and the use of velocipedes, bicycles and skates,
or the use and practice of and amusement on the streets or sidewalks to the
annoyance of pedestrians or persons using such streets or sidewalks and to
restrain, regulate and prohibit the ringing of bells, or blowing of horns,
bugles and whistles, crying of goods and other and all noises, practices and
performances tending to the collection of persons in the streets or tending,
unnecessarily, to interfere with the peace and quietude of the inhabitants of
said city, and to suppress and regulate all unnecessary noises; to license
any lawful business, occupation or calling that is susceptible to the control
of the police power, and to license, regulate, control or prohibit the
erection of signs or billboards; to license, tax and regulate or suppress and
prevent hawkers, peddlers and pawnbrokers; to license, tax and regulate all
charges of fares made by any person, firm or corporation owning, operating or
controlling any vehicle operated for the carriage of passengers or freight
for hire on the public streets of the City; to regulate the operation of
railway trains and streetcars operated on, along or across the streets,
avenues or alleys of said City, and airplanes over the City; to license and
control the operation of automobiles, motorcycles, taxicabs, buses, cabs and
carriages and all character of vehicles using the public streets and to
regulate the use and occupancy of the streets by any such vehicle; to provide
for the regulation and control of plumbers and plumbing work, and to secure
efficiency in the same; to provide for the inspection of weights, measures
and meters and to fix a standard of such weights, measures and meters and
require conformity to such standards and provide penalties for failure to use
or conform to the same, and to provide for inspection fees; to regulate and
provide for location of heavy, dangerous and noisy business in districts set
apart for such purpose; to provide for the issuance of permits for erecting
all buildings; for the inspection of the construction of all buildings in
respect to proper wiring, for electric lights and other electrical
appliances; piping for gas, flues, chimneys, plumbing and sewer connections,
and to enforce proper regulations in regard thereto; to provide for the
establishment and designation of fire limits; to provide for the kind and
character of fireproof buildings within said limits and for the condemnation
of dangerous or dilapidated structures which are calculated to increase the
fire hazard; to enact and enforce all ordinances and resolutions, necessary
to regulate the safety of all office buildings, hotels, apartment houses,
rooming houses, hospitals, theaters, store buildings and all public
buildings; to require the construction of fire escapes in connection with
public buildings, and to determine the efficiency and regulate the safety of
all exits and fire escapes provided on public buildings of every kind and
character; to restrain and punish vagrants, mendicants, beggars and
prostitutes, to regulate, control or prohibit the sale, gift, barter,
exchange of cocaine, opium, morphine and the salts thereof, and other
narcotics; to define nuisances and prohibit and punish same by fine; to pass
ordinances defining offenses against the person and property and public
health and safety and provide penalties to enforce same; to prohibit and
punish keepers and inmates of bawdy, assignation and disorderly houses, and
to prevent and suppress such bawdy, assignation and disorderly houses, and to
punish such keepers, inmates and owners, or agents of such owners of such
houses, knowingly permitting such houses to be occupied as such bawdy,
assignation or disorderly houses, to determine such inmates and keepers to be
vagrants; to provide for establishing and maintaining the fire department of
the City; to require waterworks corporations, gas companies, streetcar
companies, telephone companies, electric light and power companies, or other
companies or individuals, exercising franchises, now or hereafter from the
city, to make and furnish extension of their services to such territory as
may be required by ordinance; to establish and maintain the city police
department, prescribe the qualifications and duties of policemen and regulate
their conduct; to provide for the enforcement of all ordinances enacted by
the city by a fine not to exceed $200.00, provided that no ordinance shall
provide a greater or less penalty than is prescribed for a like offense by
the laws of this state; to provide for the commutation of fines imposed by
labor in a workhouse, on the public streets and public highways of the City,
and for a collection of any fine imposed, execution may be enforced, as
executions issued in civil cases and capias pro fines; to establish, maintain
and regulate the city prison, workhouses and other means of punishing
vagrants, city convicts and disorderly persons, and such hospitals,
orphanages and charitable institutions as may be deemed expedient by the
governing authorities.



Section 19.  Zoning.



   The City of Henderson shall have the power to divide the City in zones
or districts, and to regulate the location, size, height, bulk, and use of
buildings within such zones or districts, and to establish building lines
within such zones or districts or otherwise, and make different regulations
for different districts and thereafter to alter the same. The City is
authorized to create a commission or board for the purpose of carrying out
the powers of this section, or may provide for the creation of a board of
appeals or review for the purpose of hearing and deciding on appeals from and
reviewing any order, requirement, decision, or determination of the City in
carrying out the powers and authority herein conferred, provided the
authority and power herein conferred shall never be construed to be a
limitation of any other power and authority conferred in this Charter.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 5)



Statutory reference:



   Municipal zoning authority, see Tex. Local Gov’t Code, Ch. 211



Section 20.  Reserved.



Editor’s note:



   Section 5 of an amendment of April 6, 1985, repealed section 20 in its
entirety. Former section 20 pertained to the establishing of building lines



Section 21.  Additional general powers.



   The enumeration of particular powers in this Charter shall not be held
or deemed to be exclusive, but in addition to the powers enumerated herein,
implied thereby or appropriate to the exercise thereof, the City of Henderson
may have and shall exercise all other powers which, under the Constitution of
the State of Texas, it would be competent for the Charter specifically to
enumerate.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 6)



Section 22.  Additional home rule powers.



   (a)   The City of Henderson shall have and exercise all the powers
conferred upon cities by what is known as the Home Rule Amendment to the
Constitution of the State of Texas and the enabling act and all other laws
passed or which may hereafter be passed by the legislature in relation to
such matters.



   (b)   The City of Henderson may exercise any of its powers or
perform any of its functions, and may participate in the financing thereof,
jointly or in cooperation, by contract or otherwise with the Government of
Texas or any agency thereof, or with the Federal Government of Texas [sic] or
any agency thereof, or with the Federal Government or any agency thereof, or
with the government of any county, city, or political subdivision to
accomplish any lawful municipal purpose.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 7)



Statutory references:



   Authority of local self-government, see Tex. Local Gov’t Code, §
51.072



   General powers of home-rule municipality, see Tex. Local Gov’t Code,
§§ 51.071 et seq.



   Powers of home-rule municipality, see Tex. Local Gov’t Code, §§
9.0001 et seq.



ARTICLE III. CITY COUNCIL



Section 1.  Composition of city council.



   The municipal government of the City of Henderson, Texas, shall consist
of a Mayor, elected at large, and five (5) Council members elected from five
(5) geographically defined districts. The Mayor and two (2) district Council
members shall be elected in even numbered years. Three (3) district Council
members shall be elected in odd numbered years. The Mayor and Council members
shall serve two (2) year terms.



   This form of government shall be instituted at the time of the city
election beginning in 1986.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 8)



Section 2.  Election of officers.



   (a)   An election shall be held annually in the City on the first
Saturday of April, at such places as the City Council may direct. Such
election shall be conducted in accordance with the Texas Election Code,
including any and all amendments to such code. The provisions of the Texas
Election Code, and any and all amendments thereto, relating to qualifications
of officers, limitations of council members, vacancies and special elections
to fill such vacancies, are hereby adopted.



   (b)   The Mayor and all Council members elected by the City shall be
elected with a majority of the votes cast for that particular office, and in
the event that there are more than two (2) candidates for any office and no
candidate is elected by a majority, then there must be a runoff election
held. The runoff election shall be held in compliance with the Texas Election
Code and any and all amendments thereto.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 8)



Statutory references:



   Applicability of Election Code, see Tex. Election Code, § 1.002



   Date for election of officers, see Tex. Local Gov’t Code, § 26.042



   Election dates, see Tex. Election Code, Ch. 41



   Election by plurality, see Tex. Election Code, §§ 2.001 et seq.



   Runoff election, see Tex. Election Code, §§ 2.021 et seq.



Section 3.  Election from district.



   In addition to the qualifications contained in Section 4, Article III
of this Charter, a City Council member elected from a district must have been
a bona fide resident of that district on the day of filing for such office.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 8)



Statutory reference:



   Age and residence requirements for home-rule city office, see Tex.
Election Code, § 141.003



Section 4.  Qualifications.



   Each member of the City Council and the Mayor shall at the time of his
or her election to office be at least twenty-one (21) years of age and shall
be a qualified voter of the State of Texas and a citizen of the City for a
period of time not less than six (6) months next preceding his or her
election. No member of the City Council or the Mayor shall hold any other
office or salaried employment under the City Government while he or she is
serving as a member of the City Council or as Mayor, nor shall he or she hold
any salaried employment under the City Government within one (1) year
thereafter. A member of the City Council or the Mayor ceasing to reside in
the City or in the district from which he or she was elected shall
immediately forfeit his or her office. No member of the City Council nor the
Mayor shall hold any other public office except as Notary Public while he or
she is a member of the City Council or Mayor. No candidate for public office
or public official of the City of Henderson shall be delinquent in any
account owed to the City.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 8)



Statutory references:



   Age and residence requirements for home-rule city office, see Tex.
Election Code, § 141.003



   Candidates for city office, see Tex. Election Code, Ch. 143



   Eligibility for public office, see Tex. Election Code, §§ 141.001 et
seq.



Section 5.  Duties and powers of officers.



   Each and all provisions of Chapter Three, Title 28, R.C.S. 1925, and
amendments, being Articles 993 through 1006 of said Statutes [V.T.C.A., Local
Government Code sections 22.005, 22.008, 22.010, 22.012, 22.042,
22.073-22.077, 52.003, 141.001, 141.006, 141.007, 142.004-142.008, 341.001,
341.011, 341.012, 362.001, 362.002], are hereby adopted and made a part of
this Charter to the same effect as though fully copied herein.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 8)



Section 6.  Vacancies.



   All vacancies from any cause in the office of Mayor or City Council
member shall be filled in accordance with Article 989, Revised Civil
Statutes, State of Texas, and amendments [V.T.C.A., Local Government Code
section 22.010].



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 8)



Section 7.  Council meetings, procedures, ordinances and powers.



   The City Council shall meet at least once each month and more often as
may be fixed by ordinance; a majority of the duly elected Council members
shall constitute a quorum for the purpose of holding a legal meeting.



   Chapter Four, Title 28, R.C.S. 1925, and amendments [V.T.C.A., Local
Government Code sections 22.033, 22.037, 52.004], are hereby adopted
expressly, to the same effect as though such chapter were fully copied
herein, which chapter relates to attendance and salary of officers, powers of
the Council, ordinances, public governmental affairs, finances and other
related subjects.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 8)



Section 8.  Ordinances.



   (a)   The Council shall have the power to carry into effect all the
powers granted under this Charter, including ordinances regulating and
concerning all matters of property, health, safety and public peace and all
other matters pertaining to local self-government not inhibited by the
Constitution and laws of the State.



   (b)   The Council shall have the power by ordinance to define
misdemeanor offenses against person, property, health, safety, morals and all
other form of culpable misconduct within the City Limits, and to prohibit the
same and fix penalties for violation of such ordinances.



   (c)   All ordinances of the City providing for a penalty or any
other ordinances heretofore required by law to be published twice in an
official newspaper of the City, once each week during a ten (10) day period
and such publication need not set out the entire text of such ordinance, but
it shall be sufficient for such publication to contain a descriptive caption
or title stating in summary, the purpose of the ordinance and the penalty for
violation thereof



   (d)   Before an ordinance is finally passed, it shall be read in two
(2) consecutive meetings of the Council; provided, however, that emergencies
may be dealt with as authorized by paragraph (e) of this section.



   (e)   An emergency ordinance is an ordinance or resolution for the
immediate preservation of public peace, property, health or safety, or
providing for the usual daily operation of a municipal department, and shall
become immediately in force and effective after passage, irrespective of any
rule providing for separate readings more than once.



   (f)   In any investigation by the Council of matters pertaining to
any City Department, and franchise, and any matter of a public nature in
which the interest of the City is concerned, the Council shall have the power
to issue subpoena for witnesses, require the production of books and records
and papers pertinent to such investigation, and to pass ordinances providing
for such attendance and production of papers and records before the Council
and providing penalty for failure to do so.



   (g)   The Council shall have the power to require by ordinance the
extension of any public utility where the health and welfare of the City and
public requires it.



   (h)   The Council shall have the power to enact all ordinances
necessary to maintain order and public peace, prohibit unlawful interference
with the right of the people to work and to restrain unlawful assemblies,
boycotts, strikes and other unlawful acts against the City, free enterprise
and business where the public interest and welfare is concerned.



   (i)   The enumeration of specific powers hereinabove set forth are
not exclusive, and shall not be so deemed, and it is expressly provided that
the Council shall have the power to pass all ordinances and do all things
necessary for the welfare of the City in the administration of municipal
departments, in the administration of police powers, and for the preservation
of public peace, property, health, safety and general welfare of the City and
its citizens, and for the progress and development of the City as local
self-government may require.



   (j)   The style of all ordinances of the City of Henderson shall be:
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF HENDERSON, TEXAS.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 8)



Statutory references:



   Ordinance, rule or regulation necessary to carry out other powers, see
Tex. Local Gov’t Code, § 51.001



   Publication of ordinances, see Tex. Local Gov’t Code, § 52.013



Section 9.  Transition.



   Once these changes in the Charter of the City of Henderson are approved
and the drawing of district lines become effective, each one of the existing
Council members shall be designated as the particular representative of one
of the five (5) respective districts in the following way:



   (a)   If only one Council member presently resides in a newly drawn
geographic district, that Council member shall be designated the
representative of that particular district and shall continue to represent
said district until standing for reelection according to the existing
reelection schedule.



   (b)   If two (2) or more Council members presently reside in a newly
drawn geographic district, each shall draw by lot in order to determine which
one shall become the designated representative of that district.



   (c)   Newly drawn geographic districts within which no current
Council member resides shall each have one Council member designated as that
district’s representative with previously unassigned Council members
drawing by lot for each one’s specific district representation assignment.
Each Council member shall then represent said district until each
respectively would normally stand for reelection according to the existing
reelection schedule.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 8)



ARTICLE IV. ADMINISTRATIVE ORGANIZATIONS



   Editor’s note:



      Section 9 of an amendment of April 6, 1985, renamed article IV as
“Administrative Organization.” Former article IV was entitled
“Departments.”



Section 1.  The city manager generally.



   The Council shall appoint a City Manager who shall be the
administrative and executive officer of the City. The Manager shall be chosen
by the Council solely on the basis of training, experience and ability. The
Manager need not, when appointed, be a resident of the City of Henderson;
however, upon acceptance, the Manager shall immediately establish residence
within the City. The Council shall appoint the Manager only for an indefinite
term and fix the annual compensation. In the absence or inability of the City
Manager to perform designated duties, the Council, by majority vote, may
designate a qualified administrative officer to perform the duties of the
Manager during such absence or disability.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 9)



Section 2.  Responsibilities and general powers of the city manager.



   The City Manager shall be responsible to the Council for the proper
administration of all the affairs of the City. The powers and duties herein
conferred upon the City Manager shall include, but shall not be limited by,
the following:



   (a)   To appoint and remove any officer or employee of the City
except those officers and employees whose appointment or election is
otherwise provided for by law or this Charter; and to supervise all municipal
programs.



   (b)   To prepare the budget annually, submit it to the Council and
be responsible for its administration after its adoption.



   (c)   To manage the City’s funds; to keep the Council informed of
the financial condition of the City; and to make recommendations on current
and future needs of the City as may seem desirable.



   (d)   To provide information to the Council facilitating its ability
to make informed decisions in the best interests of the community.



   (e)   To prepare the Council meeting agendas; to attend all such
meetings serving as a resource to the Council and the public; and to
recommend alternatives by which the Council can respond to the community
needs.



   (f)   To perform such other duties as may be prescribed by this
Charter or required of him by the Council which are not inconsistent with the
provisions of this Charter.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 9)



Section 3.  Removal of the city manager.



   The Council may remove the Manager from office in accordance with the
following procedures:



   (a)   The Council shall adopt, by affirmative vote of a majority of
all its members, a preliminary resolution which must state the reasons for
removal and may suspend the Manager from duty for a period not to exceed
thirty (30) days. A copy of the resolution shall be delivered promptly to the
Manager.



   (b)   Within seven (7) days after a copy of the resolution is
delivered to the Manager, the Manager may file with the Council a written
request for a public hearing. This hearing shall be held at a Council meeting
not earlier than ten (10) days, nor later than twenty (20) days, after the
request is filed. The Manager may file with the Council a written reply not
later than five (5) days before the hearing.



   (c)   The Council may adopt a final resolution of removal, which may
be made effective immediately, by affirmative vote of a majority of all its
members at any time after five (5) days from the date when a copy of the
preliminary resolution was delivered to the Manager, if the Manager has not
requested a public hearing, or at any time after the public hearing, if one
has been requested.



   The Manager shall continue to receive full salary until the effective
date of a final resolution of removal. The action of the Council in
suspending or removing the Manager shall be final.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 9)



Section 4.  Administrative departments.



   There shall be such administrative departments as are established by
this Charter and as may be established by ordinance, all of which shall be
under the control and direction of the City Manager. The Council may abolish
or combine one or more departments created by it and may assign or transfer
duties of any departments of the City from one department to another by
ordinance.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 9)



Section 5.  Directors of departments.



   At the head of each department there shall be a director, whose
qualifications may be prescribed by the Council, who shall be appointed by
the City Manager for an indefinite term, subject to the consent of the City
Council, and who may be removed by the City Manager. Such directors shall
have supervision and control over their respective departments. The City
Manager may authorize directors of departments to appoint and remove
subordinates in each one’s respective department. Two (2) or more
departments may be headed by the same individual and the City Manager may
head one or more departments.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 9)



Section 6.  City attorney.



   The City Council shall appoint a City Attorney from recommendations of
the City Manager, or by any member of the City Council, who shall be duly
licensed to practice law in the State of Texas. The City Attorney shall
receive, for particular services, such compensation as may be fixed by the
Council, and may be removed at any time by majority vote of the City Council.



   The City Attorney shall represent the City of Henderson in all its
litigation, serving as the legal advisor of and attorney and counsel for the
City of Henderson, the Council and all boards, commissions and agencies, and
all officers and departments thereof.



   Notwithstanding the above provisions, the Council may engage special
legal counsel to represent the City of Henderson in any specific matter or
for the performance of any specifically delineated duties otherwise to be
performed by the City Attorney.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 9)



Section 7.  Municipal court and judge.



   There shall be a Municipal Court of the City of Henderson which shall
have such jurisdiction, powers, and duties as are prescribed by the Laws of
the State of Texas, over which shall preside the Municipal Judge, whose
qualifications shall be prescribed by the Laws of the State of Texas, and who
shall be appointed by a majority vote of the City Council from
recommendations of the City Manager or by any member of the City Council.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 9)



Section 8.  City secretary.



   The City Council by majority vote, upon the recommendation of the City
Manager, shall appoint the City Secretary who shall serve at the discretion
of the Council and who may be removed from office by the City Council upon
the recommendation of the City Manager. The duties of the City Secretary
shall include, but not be limited to, the following:



   (a)   To attend all meetings of the City Council and keep accurate
records of all actions taken by the Council;



   (b)   To maintain the official records and files of the City;



   (c)   To administer oaths of office;



   (d)   To attest contracts, assessment certificates and other legal
instruments when executed by the authorized officers of the City;



   (e)   To serve as the election official for all City elections; and



   (f)   To perform such other duties as may be assigned by the City
Council or the City Manager or as may be required by this Charter or State
Law.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 9)



ARTICLE V. TAXATION



Section 1.  Tax limit.



   The City shall have the power and is hereby authorized to annually
levy, assess and collect taxes not to exceed $2.50 on each $100.00 assessed
valuation of all real and personal property within the city limits of the
City of Henderson, not exempt from taxation by the constitution and laws of
the State of Texas.



Statutory references:



   Property taxes authorized, see Tex. Tax Code, § 302.001



Section 2. Reserved.



Editor’s note:



   Section 10 of an amendment of April 6, 1985, repealed section 2 in its
entirety. Former section 2 pertained to the levy of a poll tax.



Section 3.  Issuance of licenses.



   Said City shall authorize the granting and issuance of licenses and
shall direct the manner of issuing and registering the same, and fix the fees
therefor, but no license shall be issued for a longer period than one year,
and shall not be assignable, except by permission of the governing body of
the City.



Section 4.  Street rental charge and/or gross receipt tax.



   The City shall have the right and power to levy and collect annually a
street rental charge and/or gross receipt tax against any utility corporation
using and occupying the public streets and grounds of the City, separately
from the tangible property of such corporations, and to levy annually upon
the property and shares of corporations, companies and corporate institutions
as the same are now, or may be, assessed hereafter by the state laws, and
shall have full power to enforce the collection of such taxes. (Amend. of
4/6/85, sec. 11)



Statutory references:



   Municipal authority to impose charges on electric utility using
streets, etc., see Tex. Utilities Code, Ch. 33



   Municipal authority to impose charges on gas utility using streets,
etc., see Tex. Utilities Code, Ch. 103



Sections 5-9. Reserved.



Editor’s note:



   Section 12 of an amendment of April 6, 1985, repealed sections 5
through 9 in their entirety. Former sections 5 through 9 pertained to taxes



Section 10.  Collection.



   The City shall have full power to provide for the prompt collection, by
suit or otherwise, of taxes assessed, levied and imposed, and it is hereby
authorized, and to that end, shall have full power and authority to sell, or
cause to be sold, all kinds of property, real and personal, and shall make
such rules and regulations, and enact all such ordinances as are deemed
necessary for the collection of any taxes provided for in this Charter.



Statutory reference:



   Tax collection powers, see Tex. Tax Code, § 302.102



Section 11. Reserved.



Editor’s note:



   Section 13 of an amendment of April 6, 1985, repealed section 11 in its
entirety. Former section 11 pertained to not requiring a bond to be executed
on behalf of the city in any action, suit or proceeding



Section 12.  Fiscal year.



   The City shall have the power to control and manage the finances of the
City; to provide its fiscal year and fiscal arrangements.



Statutory references:



   City fiscal year, see Tex. Tax Code, § 1.05



   General fiscal power to establish fiscal year, see Tex. Local Gov’t
Code, § 101.022



Section 13.  City funds.



   All moneys arising from the collection of taxes by the City shall be
divided into appropriate funds and designated as the general funds and
interest and sinking fund.



Sections 14-16.  Reserved.



Editor’s note:



   Section 12 of an amendment of April 6, 1985, repealed sections 14
through 16 in their entirety. Former sections 14 through 16 pertained to
assessment irregularity, a board of equalization, and general law applicable
to taxation, respectively



Section 17.  Occupation tax.



   The City shall have the right to assess and collect such occupational
taxes, license and franchise taxes upon trades, professions, occupations, and
any business transaction carried on in the said City as may be authorized by
the laws of the State of Texas, but the amount so levied in collection shall
not exceed one-half of the amount levied by the State of Texas for the same
trades, professions, occupations, vocations or businesses.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 14)



Statutory reference:



   Occupation taxes, see Tex. Tax Code, § 302.101



ARTICLE VI. CITY FINANCES



Statutory reference:



   General financial provisions applicable to home-rule municipality, see
Tex. Local Government Code, §§ 101.021 et seq.



Section 1.  Revenue appropriation for bond improvements, etc.



   The governing authority of the City shall have the power to appropriate
so much of the general revenue of the City as may be necessary for the
purpose of retiring and discharging the accrued indebtedness of the City and
for the purpose of improving the streets, constructing sewers, erecting and
maintaining public buildings and parks of every kind, and for the purpose of
erecting, maintaining and operating an electric light plant, or plants, and
such other public utilities as the governing body may from time to time deem
expedient, and in the furtherance of any and all of these subjects the City
shall have the right and power to borrow money upon the credit of the City
and to issue bonds of the City therefor in the sum or sums as may be deemed
advisable within the limits governed by federal law and the laws of the State
of Texas, provided that the aggregate amount of said bonds shall not exceed
ten (10) percent of the whole taxable value of the City of Henderson, as
ascertained from the tax records, at the time of the issuance of such bonds.
Said bonds to be issued in conformity with the ordinances hereafter to be
enacted by the City Council and conformity with the general laws of the State
of Texas, and all federal laws applicable thereto and governing the issuance
of bonds by municipalities.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 15)



Statutory references:



   Authority of municipality to issue bonds for public improvements, see
Tex. Gov’t Code, § 1331.052



   Municipal bonds, see Tex. Gov’t Code, Ch. 1331



Section 2.  Bond provisions for payment.



   All bonds shall specify for what purpose they are issued and when any
bonds are issued by the City a fund shall be provided to pay the interest and
create a sinking fund to redeem said bonds, which fund shall not be diverted
or drawn upon for any other purpose, and the person acting as City Treasurer
shall honor no drafts upon said fund, except to pay interest upon or redeem
the bonds for which it was provided.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 16)



Statutory references:



   Municipal bonds, see Tex. Gov’t Code, Ch. 1331



   Public Security Procedures Act, see Tex. Gov’t Code, Ch. 1201



Section 3.  Bond term.



   Said bonds shall be issued for a period of time not to exceed a period
of forty (40) years, shall be signed by the Mayor and countersigned by the
person acting in the capacity of City Secretary, and shall be payable at such
places and times that may be fixed by ordinance of the City Council. All such
bonds shall be submitted to the Attorney General of the State of Texas for
his approval, and the State Comptroller for registration, as provided by the
laws of Texas, provided that any such bonds after approval may be issued by
the City either optional or serial or otherwise, as may be deemed advisable
by the City Council.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 17)



Section 4.  Bond elections.



   Before the issuance of any bonds the same shall be submitted to a vote
of the qualified property taxpaying voters of the City of Henderson, and
should a majority of the votes cast in said election be in favor of the
issuance of the bonds the same shall be issued as provided herein, but should
said election fail to carry, the bonds shall not be issued. The election
provided for above shall be conducted as other elections under the state law,
after due notice of such election in accordance with Article 704, V.A.T.S.
[V.T.C.A., Government Code section 1251.003], and amendments.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 18)



Statutory reference:



   Bond elections generally, see Tex. Gov’t Code, Ch. 1251



Section 5.  Emergency deficiency warrant.



   The City Council shall issue no deficiency warrant, except in cases of
emergency and the [same shall] not draw interest at more than six per cent
per annum, and in no event without the unanimous vote of all members of the
City Council, and in no event shall deficiency warrants be outstanding for
more than $5,000.00 at any one time.



Section 6.  Budget expenditures.



   Expenditures shall be legal only on the basis of appropriations in the
budget and on the authority of warrants issued by authority of the City
Council.



Statutory reference:



   Levy of taxes and expenditure of funds under budget, emergency
expenditure, see Tex. Local Gov’t Code, § 102.009



Section 7.  Transfer of funds.



   For good cause shown the City Council may pass resolutions,
transferring appropriations made from one department to another department,
but in no event shall the total appropriation made for all the departments of
the City exceed the reasonable and anticipated revenues of the City in excess
of fixed charges for that year.



Section 8.  Audit of records.



   The City Council shall cause a continuous audit of the books and
accounts of all records and transactions of the administration of the affairs
of the City, such audit to be made annually, embracing each fiscal year, and
shall be made by a Certified Public Accountant. The duty of such accountant
shall include the certification of all statements required, such statements
shall include a general balance sheet showing summaries of income and
expenditures and also comparisons in proper classification with the last
previous audit; such summary shall be published in a newspaper published in
the City of Henderson, one time within ten (10) days after completion of such
audit.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 19)



Statutory reference:



   Audit of municipal finances, see Tex. Local Gov’t Code, Ch. 103



Section 9.  City depository or depositories.



   The City Council shall receive applications for the custody of City
funds from any banking corporation, association or individual banker that may
desire to be selected as a depository of the City and designate such a
depository or depositories in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 3,
Title 47, Revised Civil Statutes of Texas [V.T.C.A., Local Government Code,
chapter 105], in effect at the time of such selection. The term of
designation of such depository or depositories shall be for no more than
three (3) years unless otherwise provided by Statute.



(Amend. of 4/2/82, sec. 3)



Statutory reference:



   Depositories for municipal funds, see Tex. Local Gov’t Code, Ch. 105



Section 10.  City cemetery.



   The City Council shall have the power to make ample provisions for the
upkeep and maintenance of the City Cemeteries, and in the furtherance
therefor shall enact all ordinances and pass all resolutions necessary in the
premises, and shall provide by appropriations from the general fund of said
City, annually, such amount as may be necessary for that purpose.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 20)



Statutory references:



   Cemeteries, see Tex. Health and Safety Code, §§ 711.001 et seq. and
§§ 714.001 et seq.



   Municipal regulation of cemeteries, see Tex. Health and Safety Code,
§§ 713.001 et seq.



Section 11.  General law adopted for bond issuance.



   In addition to the specific powers herein enumerated, with reference to
issuance of bonds, revenue bonds, and warrants, it is expressly provided that
the City shall have all of the powers to issue bonds as provided in Title 28,
R. C. S. 1925 [V.T.C.A., Government Code title 9], and amendments now or
hereafter made by the State Legislature, in the mode and manner and for the
purposes therein set forth, and in addition for such other purposes which may
be for the public good and welfare, so long as such purposes are not
inhibited by the Constitution or law of the State; and the City may
appropriate available funds, which are not by law limited to specific
purposes, for improvements and purposes necessary in the administration and
progress of a local self-governing home rule city, provided only that such
purposes for expenditures of funds be not inhibited by the Constitution and
Laws of Texas.



Section 12.  Reserved.



Editor’s note:



   Section 21 of an amendment of April 6, 1985, repealed section 12 in its
entirety. Former section 12 pertained to the assumption of city obligations
incurred prior to charter adoption



ARTICLE VII. GENERAL PROVISIONS



Section 1.  Ordinances, orders, etc., to remain in force.



   All ordinances, resolutions and orders of the City Council of the Town
of Henderson in force at the time of taking effect of this Charter, not
inconsistent with its provisions, shall continue in force and effect until
amended or repealed.



Section 2.  Vested rights continued.



   All vested rights of the Town of Henderson shall continue to be vested
and shall not in any manner be affected by the adoption of this Charter,
unless otherwise herein expressly provided to the contrary. All contracts
entered into by the Town of Henderson or for its benefit prior to the taking
effect of this Charter shall be continued and performed hereunder, according
to their terms, tenor and effect. Public improvements for which legislative
steps shall have been taken under the laws in force at the time of the
adoption of this Charter and the time it becomes effective may be carried out
and completed in accordance with the provisions of such laws.



Section 3.  Savings or constitutional clause.



   Should any portion of this Charter be held unconstitutional, or in
conflict with a State law, rendering it void, such holding shall not have the
effect of invalidating any other portion of the Charter.



Section 4.  Oath of office.



   (a)   Elected officers. Every elected officer of the City shall,
before entering upon the duties of his office, take and subscribe to the
following oath or affirmation, to be filed and kept in the office of the City
Secretary:



      I, ____________ , do solemnly swear (or affirm), that I will
faithfully execute the duties of the office of the City of Henderson, State
of Texas, and will to the best of my ability preserve, protect and defend the
constitution and laws of the United States and of this state and the Charter
and ordinances of this City; and I furthermore solemnly swear (or affirm)
that I have not directly or indirectly paid, offered, or promised to
contribute any money, or valuable thing, or promised any public office or
employment, as a reward for the giving or withholding a vote at the election
at which I was elected. So help me God.



   (b)   Appointed officers. Every appointed officer of the City shall,
before entering upon the duties of his office, take and subscribe to the
following oath or affirmation, to be filed and kept in the office of the City
Secretary:



      I, ____________ , do solemnly swear (or affirm), that I will
faithfully execute the duties of the office of the City of Henderson, State
of Texas, and will to the best of my ability preserve, protect and defend the
constitution and laws of the United States and of this state and the Charter
and ordinances of this City; and I furthermore solemnly swear (or affirm)
that I have not directly or indirectly paid, offered, or promised to
contribute any money, or valuable thing, or promised any public office of
[or] employment, as a reward to secure my appointment or the confirmation
thereof So help me God.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 22)



State constitution reference:



   Oath of office, see Texas Constitution, Art. 16, § 1



Section 5.  Effect of this Charter on existing law.



   All ordinances, resolutions, rules and regulations now in force under
the city government of the City and not in conflict with the provisions of
this Charter shall remain in force under this Charter until altered, amended
or repealed by City Council after this Charter takes effect; and all rights
of the City under existing franchises and contracts are preserved in full
force and effect to the City, and any unissued bonds and revenue bonds, or
installments thereof, heretofore authorized at an election held in said City
shall not be affected by the adoption of this Charter, but the right to sell,
issue and deliver same, in whole or in part, in keeping with the provisions
of the laws under which they were voted is hereby expressly reserved.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 23)



Section 6.  General law adopted where not otherwise provided herein.



   All subjects, matters, powers and procedures pertaining to municipal
law and government not expressly covered herein may be dealt with and
conducted as provided by the general laws of the State pertaining to cities
of over 5,000 inhabitants and the laws pertaining to home rule cities; this
provision is not to be construed as a limitation on the powers of the City
but as a cumulative provision, subject to change by ordinance to such extent
as not prohibited by the Constitution and law of the State.



Section 7.  Liberal construction of home rule powers.



   The provisions of this Charter shall be liberally construed for the
purpose of obtaining the objects and ends hereof. It is intended by this
Charter to vest in the City Government all of the powers which a political
entity can lawfully exercise in the administration of local self-government
for the present and future good and welfare of the citizens and progress,
growth and development of the City, limited only by the inhibitions and
prohibitions of the Constitution and laws of the State.



Section 7.1.  Severability clause.



   If any section or part of a section of this Charter shall be held
invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, such holding shall not affect
the remainder of this Charter nor the context in which such section or part
of such section so held invalid may appear, except to the extent that an
entire section or part of a section may be inseparably connected in meaning
and effect with the section or part of a section to which such holding shall
directly apply.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 24)



Section 7.2.  References to laws.



   All references within this Charter to laws of the State of Texas or of
the United States are to be construed as meaning such laws as now or
hereafter amended or superseded.



(Amend. of 4/6/85, sec. 25)



Section 8.  Provision for submission of this charter.



   This Charter is submitted in accordance with the provision of Chapter
13, Title 28, R. C. S. 1925, and amendments [V.T.C.A., Local Government Code
secs. 9.001 et seq., 26.021, 26.041, 51.072, 51.074 et seq., 43.021, 43.142,
101.022, 141.004 et seq., etc.], for vote of the qualified citizens at the
City General Election held on Tuesday, April 1, 1947, and when adopted by the
citizens shall be the Charter of the City of Henderson, Rusk County, Texas.



The State of Texas         )



County of Rusk         )



City of Henderson         )



I, the undersigned City Secretary of the City of Henderson, Texas, do hereby
certify that the above and foregoing is a true and correct copy of the
Charter of the City of Henderson, Texas, as adopted by the voters of the City
of Henderson, Texas, at an election held on April 1, 1947.



I further certify that no amendments of any nature have been made to this
charter since April 1, 1947.



Witness my hand and seal of office, this the 11th day of April, 1958.



         /s/      W. M. Armstrong



               City Secretary,



               City of Henderson, Texas.



(SEAL)



TITLE I:  GENERAL PROVISIONS



   Chapter



      10.   GENERAL CODE CONSTRUCTION; GENERAL PENALTY



CHAPTER 10:  GENERAL CODE CONSTRUCTION; GENERAL PENALTY

   10.02   Interpretation



   10.03   Application to future ordinances
