WATER CONSERVATION PLAN




§ 54.01  UTILITY EVALUATION.



   (A)   The city, in an effort to conserve the treated water supply
available to the city, has initiated a plan to reduce the loss of treated
water delivered within its system, which includes meter testing and line
losses in the production and distribution system. The city’s goal is a 5%
reduction allowing for new additions and users over a period of time.



   (B)   The city serves approximately 5,099 customers (active
accounts) in the incorporated city limits. The major water users, outside of
domestic use, would be the gas and oil industries. The city’s water source
is supplied from eight wells in the Wilcox Aquifer and a 4.5 million gallons
a day surface water treatment plant.



   (C)   The city, from and after the effective date of this
subchapter, will implement the following water conservation plan:



      (1)   Population of service area: 11,273;



      (2)   Area of service area: 11 square miles;

(Prior Code, § 13.06.031)



§ 54.02  WATER CONSERVATION PLAN.



   (A)   (1)   The city promotes water conservation by informing the
public of ways to conserve water.



      (2)   The following methods will be used to inform water users:



         (a)   Newspaper articles, one feature article per year
minimum, in the Henderson Daily News;



         (b)   Direct mailings, in the first year of production,
there will be three direct mailings covering areas of conservation on indoor
water use, outdoor and lawn watering and plumbing retrofit information. In
each subsequent year, there will be two more direct mailings covering water
conservation or specific aspects as required; and



         (c)   Printed handouts and direct communication with
customers, new and existing, using various pamphlets and printed material of
the state water development board, American Water Works Association, Texas
Water Utilities Association and information created in-house will be given to
all new customers when they request service; and existing customers when they
visit City Hall. Distribution will also be made at city-sponsored seminars.



   (B)   Suggestions on ways to save water which may be included in
public information are listed below:



      (1)   Bathroom:



         (a)   Take a shower instead of a tub bath; showers use
less water;



         (b)   Install a low-flow shower head which restricts
water flow at 60 pounds per square inch to not more than three gallons per
minute;



         (c)   Take short showers and install a cut-off valve or
turn the water back on again to rinse;



         (d)   Do not use hot water when cold will do; water and
energy can be saved by washing hands with soap and cold water; hot water
should only be added if hands are especially dirty;



         (e)   Reduce the level of the water in the bathtub by
one or two inches if shower is not available;



         (f)   Turn off water when brushing teeth until time to
rinse;



         (g)   Do not let water run when washing hands; instead,
hand should be wet, water should be turned off while scrubbing, and water
should be on again to rinse; consider installing a cut-off valve on the
faucet;



         (h)   Shampoo hair in shower; it takes only a little
more water than is used to shampoo during a bath and much less than
shampooing and bathing separately;



         (i)   Test toilets for leaks; to test, add a few drops
of food coloring to water in the tank do not flush; if coloring appears in
the bowl within a few minutes, fixture needs adjustment or repair;



         (j)   Hold hot water in the basin when shaving instead
of letting faucet continue to run;



         (k)   Use a toilet tank displacement device to reduce
the amount of water in tank but still provide enough for flushing; a
one-gallon plastic milk bottle can be filled with stones or water, recapped
and placed in the tank (bricks are not recommended for this purpose as the
eventually crumble and could damage the working mechanism); these devices
should not be used with new low-volume toilets;



         (l)   Install faucet aerators to reduce consumption;



         (m)   Never use toilet to dispose of tissues, cigarette
butts or other trash; this is a waste of water and places unnecessary load on
treatment plants; and



         (n)   Install new low-volume flush toilet when building
a new home or remodeling a bathroom.



      (2)   Kitchen:



         (a)   Use a pan of water (or place a stopper in the
sink) for rinsing pots and pans when cooking rather than turning on the
faucet each time for rinsing items;



         (b)   Never run a dishwasher without a full load; this
saves water, expensive detergent and energy;



         (c)   Use garbage disposal sparingly; never for just a
few scraps;



         (d)   Keep a container of drinking water in the
refrigerator; running from tap until cool is a waste;



         (e)   Use a small pan of cold water to clean vegetables
rather than letting the faucet run;



         (f)   Use only a small amount of water in your pots and
use a lid for cooking most food; this method will save water and food is more
nutritious; and



         (g)   Use a pan of water for rinsing dishes when
hand-washing rather than running the faucet.



      (3)   Laundry:



         (a)   Wash only a full load in washing machine;



         (b)   Use lowest possible water level setting for light
loads; and



         (c)   Use cold water as often as possible; save hot
water for uses cold water cannot serve.



      (4)   Appliances and plumbing:



         (a)   Check water requirements of any new appliance as
models and brands may vary; some will use less water;



         (b)   Check all water line connections and faucets for
leaks; your money may be going down the drain;



         (c)   Learn to replace faucet washers to correct drips
promptly; it is easy, costs very little and saves in plumbing and utility
bills;



         (d)   Check for water leakage between water meter and
the house; if indoor and outdoor faucets are all turned off, the meter should
not run; if it does, a leak probably exists and needs to be found;



         (e)   Insulate all hot water pipes to avoid delays (and
wasted water) while waiting for water to get hot;



         (f)   Be sure hot water heater thermostat isn’t set
too high; hot settings result in waste of energy and water as it may be mixed
with cold water before use; and



         (g)   Use a moisture meter to determine when house
plants need water; more plants die from overwatering than from being on the
dry side.



      (5)   Out-of-door use:



         (a)   Water lawn early in the morning during hot summer
months to minimize evaporation;



         (b)   Use a sprinkler which produces large drops rather
than a mist to avoid evaporation;



         (c)   Turn soaker hoses so holes are on bottom to avoid
evaporation;



         (d)   Water slowly for better absorption; never in high
winds;



         (e)   Do not water streets, walks or driveways;



         (f)   Condition soil with compost before planting grass
or flower beds so water will soak in, not run off;



         (g)   Fertilize lawn at least twice a year for root
stimulation; the better the root system, the less water it will require;



         (h)   Learn to know when grass needs watering; if it has
turned a dull gray-green, or if footprints remain visible, it is time to
water;



         (i)   Do not water too frequently; too much water can
overload the soil so air cannot get to the roots and can encourage plant
diseases;



         (j)   Do not over-water; soil can absorb only so much
moisture, the rest simply runs off; one and one-half inch of water applied
once a week will keep most grasses alive;



         (k)   Operate automatic sprinkler system only when the
demand on water supply is lowest; set system to operate between 12:30 a.m.
and 4:00 a.m.;



         (l)   Do not “scalp” lawn when mowing during hot
months as taller grass holds moisture better;



         (m)   Use watering can or hand-water with hose in small
areas of lawn that need more frequent watering;



         (n)   Learn what types of grasses, shrubbery and plants
do best in the area and in which part of the lawn and plant accordingly;



         (o)   Consider decorating areas of the lawn with rocks,
gravel, wood chips or other materials that require no water at all;



         (p)   Do not “sweep” walks and driveways with a
water hose; use a broom or rake instead; and



         (q)   Use a bucket of soapy water and use the hose only
for rinsing when washing vehicles.



(Prior Code, § 13.06.032)



§ 54.03  PLUMBING CODES.



   The city has adopted the 2012 International Building Code. This Code
prescribes 1.6 gallons per flushing cycle on toilets, and insulated hot water
pipes. These Code provisions are enforced by the City Code Enforcement
Department, which is authorized to issue citations for violations. A
violation of the code carries a fine of up to $2,000 for each violation and
every day is a separate violation; provided that no penalty shall be greater
or less than the penalty provided under state law.



(Prior Code, § 13.06.033)



§ 54.04  RETROFIT PROGRAM.



   Customers in existing buildings which do not have water saving devices
will be encouraged to replace their old plumbing fixtures as the need arises.
The advertising program will help inform them of the advantages of installing
water saving devices. The current inverted rate structure should encourage
them to be conservative in their water use. This type of rate has been in
force since October 1, 1992.



(Prior Code, § 13.06.034)



§ 54.05  WATER RATE STRUCTURE.



   A water rate structure which encourages water conservation has been
implemented.



(Prior Code, § 13.06.035)



§ 54.06  METERING.



   (A)   The city currently meters 100% of the customers’ usage. The
city has a policy of rereading and then testing all meters which appear to
have abnormally high or low water usage. Incorporated in the water
conservation plan, the city will set up the following meter testing schedule:



      (1)   Well production meters: test every three years;



      (2)   Surface water treatment plant production meter: test
every year; and



      (3)   Meters six inch and smaller: test or replace when
constantly high or constantly low readings are observed.



   (B)   The city currently uses a computer system which handles all
billing requirements and generates water use reports. The computer easily
identifies dead meters, any high or low rate users and keeps track of all
water usage.



(Prior Code, § 13.06.036)



§ 54.07  WATER CONSERVATION LANDSCAPING.



   The advertising program will include suggestions on landscaping and
irrigation procedures which will save water usage and money. The current rate
structure should continue to encourage customers to save water outdoors.



(Prior Code, § 13.06.037)



§ 54.08  LEAK DETECTION AND REPAIR.



   (A)   The city currently has a leak detection program which will be
maintained.



   (B)   The program includes:



      (1)   Accounting for water by comparing water production with
water billed, allowing for internal system use such as back flushing filter,
over-flowing elevated towers and general in-flushing;



      (2)   Constant monitoring of elevated storage tanks which
identify major water main breaks;



      (3)   Visual inspection by meter readers and by city employees
who keep a constant watch out for abnormal conditions suggesting leaks;



      (4)   An adequate maintenance staff which is available to
repair any leak; and



      (5)   The city’s customer service personnel are available to
assist customers with leak detection on their premises as well as observing
all city distribution facilities.



(Prior Code, § 13.06.038)



§ 54.09  IMPLEMENTATION AND ENFORCEMENT.



   The water conservation plan will be enforced by the following methods.



   (A)   New service taps will not be given to customers who do not
meet the requirements of the water conservation plumbing fixtures codes.



   (B)   The city’s Code Enforcement Department will handle the
enforcement as described in the Plumbing Code of the water conservation plan,
to ensure new buildings are installing the plumbing fixtures that are
proposed in the service tap application, along with suggestions to citizens
and businesses to use the water conservation fixtures when replacing old
fixtures.



   (C)   The current rate structure should encourage retrofitting of
old plumbing fixtures which are using large amounts of water: people will
realize that replacing their fixtures will save them money on their bill
(both water and sewer).



(Prior Code, § 13.06.039)



§ 54.10  RECYCLING AND REUSE.



   The city has two wastewater plants. Effluent from these plants is not
currently being reused as no economically feasible application exists. The
city, however, will continue to study the possibilities of utilizing this
potential water source.



(Prior Code, § 13.06.040)



§ 54.11  CONSERVATION PLAN ANNUAL REPORT.



   (A)   The city will maintain a file which addresses the progress and
effectiveness of the water conservation plan.



   (B)   The report will include:



      (1)   Public information which has been issued;



      (2)   Public response; and



      (3)   Effectiveness of plan in reducing water use by providing
consumption data.



(Prior Code, § 13.06.041)



§ 54.12  FIVE- AND TEN-YEAR TARGETS AND GOALS.



   (A)   Five-year target and goals. The city’s current municipal
usage is 218 gallons per capita per day and water loss is 18 gallons per
capita per day. The city’s goal is to achieve a municipal usage of 210
gallons per capita per day and water loss of 15 gallons per capita per day



   (B)   Ten-year target and goals. The city’s goals are to achieve a
municipal usage of 200 gallons per capita per day and water loss of 12
gallons per capita per day.



(Prior Code, § 13.06.042)  (Ord. 10-05-08, passed 5-11-2010)




DROUGHT CONTINGENCY PLAN




§ 54.25  DECLARATION OF POLICY, PURPOSE AND INTENT.



   (A)   In order to conserve the available water supply and protect
the integrity of the city water supply facilities, with particular regard for
domestic water use, sanitation and fire protection, and to protect and
preserve public health, welfare and safety and minimize the adverse impacts
of water supply shortage or other water supply emergency conditions, the city
hereby adopts the following regulations and restrictions on the delivery and
consumption of water.



   (B)   Water uses regulated or prohibited under this drought
contingency plan (the plan) are considered to be nonessential and
continuation of such uses during times of water shortage or other emergency
water supply condition are deemed to constitute a waste of water which
subjects the offender(s) to penalties as defined in § 54.34 of this plan.



(Prior Code, § 13.06.071)



§ 54.26  PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT.



   Opportunity for the public to provide input into the preparation of the
plan was provided by the city by means of a public meeting held at the City
Hall May 14, 2002, at 9:00 a.m. to accept input on the plan. Notices were
published in the local newspaper notifying the public of the meeting to
discuss the plan on Sunday, May 12, 2002.



(Prior Code, § 13.06.072)



§ 54.27  PUBLIC EDUCATION.



   The city will periodically provide the public with information about
the plan, including information about the conditions under which each stage
of the plan is to be initiated or terminated and the drought response
measures to be implemented in each stage. This information will be provided
by means of public events and newspaper.



(Prior Code, § 13.06.073)



§ 54.28  COORDINATION WITH REGIONAL WATER PLANNING GROUPS.



   The service area of the city is located within the East Texas Regional
Water Planning Area and the city has provided a copy of this plan to the East
Texas Regional Water Planning Group.



(Prior Code, § 13.06.074)



§ 54.29  AUTHORIZATION.



   The Mayor or his or her designee is hereby authorized and directed to
implement the applicable provisions of this plan upon determination that such
implementation is necessary to protect public health, safety and welfare. The
Mayor, or his or her designee, shall have the authority to initiate or
terminate drought or other water supply emergency response measures as
described in the plan.



(Prior Code, § 13.06.075)



§ 54.30  APPLICABILITY.



   The provisions of this plan shall apply to all persons, customers and
property utilizing water provided by the city. The terms PERSON and CUSTOMER
as used in the plan include individuals, corporations, partnerships,
associations and all other legal entities.



(Prior Code, § 13.06.076)



§ 54.31  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   AESTHETIC WATER USE.  Water use for ornamental or decorative purposes
such as fountains, reflecting pools and water gardens.



   COMMERCIAL AND INSTITUTIONAL WATER USE.  Water use which is integral
to the operation of commercial and nonprofit establishments and governmental
entities such as retail establishments, hotels and motels, restaurants and
office buildings.



   CONSERVATION.  Those practices, techniques and technologies that
reduce the consumption of water, reduce the loss or waste of water, improve
the efficiency in the use of water or increase the recycling and reuse of
water so that a supply is conserved and made available for future or
alternative uses.



   CUSTOMER.  Any person, company or organization using water supplied by
the city.



   DOMESTIC WATER USE.  Water use for personal needs or for household or
sanitary purposes such as drinking, bathing, cooking, sanitation or for
cleaning a residence, business, industry or institution.



   EVEN NUMBER ADDRESS.  Street addresses, box number or rural postal
route numbers ending in 0, 2, 4, 6 or 8 and locations without addresses.



   INDUSTRIAL WATER USE.  The use of water in processes designed to
convert materials of lower value into forms having greater usability and
value.



   LANDSCAPE IRRIGATION USE.  Water used for the irrigation and
maintenance of landscaped areas, whether publicly or privately owned,
including residential and commercial lawns, gardens, golf courses, parks and
rights-of-way and medians.



   NONESSENTIAL WATER USE.  Water uses that are not essential nor
required for the protection of public, health, safety and welfare, including:



      (1)   Irrigation of landscaped areas, including parks,
athletic fields and golf courses, except otherwise provided under this plan;



      (2)   Use of water to wash any motor vehicle, motorbike, boat,
trailer, airplane or other vehicle;



      (3)   Use of water to wash down any sidewalks, walkways,
driveways, parking lots, tennis courts or other hard-surfaced areas;



      (4)   Use of water to wash down buildings or structures for
purposes other than immediate fire protection;



      (5)   Flushing gutters or permitting water to run or
accumulate in any gutter or street;



      (6)   Use of water to fill, refill or add to any indoor or
outdoor swimming pools or jacuzzi-type pools;



      (7)   Use of water in a fountain or pond for aesthetic or
scenic purposes except where necessary to support aquatic life;



      (8)   Failure to repair a controllable leak(s) within a
reasonable period after having been given notice directing the repair of such
leak(s); and



      (9)   Use of water from hydrants for construction purposes or
any other purposes other than fire fighting.



   ODD NUMBERED ADDRESSES.  Street addresses, box numbers or rural postal
route numbers ending in 1, 3, 5, 7 or 9.



(Prior Code, § 13.06.077)



§ 54.32  CRITERIA FOR INITIATION AND TERMINATION OF DROUGHT RESPONSE STAGES.



   The Mayor or his or her designee shall monitor water supply and/or
demand conditions on a weekly basis and shall determine when conditions
warrant initiation or termination of each stage of the plan, that is, when
the specified “triggers” are reached.



   (A)   Stage 1 triggers - mild water shortage conditions.



      (1)   Requirements for initiation. Customers shall be
requested to voluntarily conserve water and adhere to the prescribed
restrictions on certain water uses, defined in § 54.31, when the total daily
water demand equals or exceeds six million gallons or 70% of system capacity,
whichever is the lesser, for seven consecutive days.



      (2)   Requirements for termination. Stage 1 of the plan may be
rescinded when the conditions listed as triggering events have ceased to
exist for a period of seven consecutive days.



   (B)   Stage 2 triggers - moderate water shortage conditions.



      (1)   Requirements for initiation. Customers shall be required
to comply with the requirements and restrictions on certain nonessential
water uses provided in § 54.33 when the total daily water demand equals or
exceeds seven million gallons, or 80% of system capacity, whichever is the
lesser, for seven consecutive days.



      (2)   Requirements for termination. Stage 2 of the plan may be
rescinded when all of the conditions listed as triggering events have ceased
to exist for a period of seven consecutive days.



   (C)   Stage 3 triggers - severe water shortage conditions.



      (1)   Requirements for initiation. Customers shall be required
to comply with the requirements and restrictions on certain nonessential
water uses for stage 3 of this plan when total daily water demand equals or
exceeds the capabilities of the daily water production (estimated at eight
million gallons per day, or 90% or greater of system capacity, whichever is
the lesser), or the imminent or actual failure of a major water system
component which could cause an immediate health or safety hazard.



      (2)   Requirements for termination. Stage 3 of the plan may be
rescinded when all of the conditions listed as triggering events have ceased
to exist for a period of four consecutive days. Upon termination of stage 3,
stage 2 becomes operative.



(Prior Code, § 13.06.078)



§ 54.33  DROUGHT RESPONSE STAGES.



   (A)   Notification procedures. The Mayor, or his or her designee,
shall monitor water supply and/or demand conditions on a daily basis and, in
accordance with the triggering criteria set forth in § 54.32, shall
determine that a mild, moderate or severe water shortage condition exists and
shall implement the following notification procedures.



      (1)   Notification of the public. The Mayor or his or her
designee shall notify the public by means of:



         (a)   Publication in the local newspaper;



         (b)   Signs posted in public places;



         (c)   Local radio stations; and



         (d)   Local televisions stations.



      (2)   Additional notification. The Mayor or his or her
designee shall notify directly, or cause to be notified directly, the
following individuals and entities:



         (a)   City Council;



         (b)   Fire Chief;



         (c)   County Judge;



         (d)   Texas Natural Resources Conservation Commission;



         (e)   Major water users; and



         (f)   Public Works Director.



   (B)   Stage 1 response - mild water shortage conditions.



      (1)   Goal: achieve a voluntary 10% reduction in daily water
demand.



      (2)   Supply management measures: reduce flushing water mains
by 20%.



      (3)   Voluntary water use restrictions.



         (a)   Water customers are requested to voluntarily limit
the irrigation of landscaped areas to Sundays and Thursdays for customers
with a street address ending in an even number, Saturdays and Wednesdays for
water customers with a street address ending in an odd number, and to
irrigate landscapes only between the hours of 12:00 midnight until 10:00 a.m.
and between 8:00 p.m. and 12:00 midnight on designated watering days;
however, irrigation of landscaped areas is permitted at anytime if it is by
means of a handheld hose, and faucet filled bucket or watering can of five
gallons or less, or drip irrigation system.



         (b)   Use of water to wash any motor vehicle, motorbike,
boat, trailer, airplane or other vehicle is prohibited except between the
hours of 12:00 midnight and 10:00 a.m. and between 8:00 p.m. and 12:00
midnight. Such washing, when allowed, shall be done with a handheld hose
equipped with a positive shutoff nozzle for quick rises. Vehicle washing may
be done at any time on the immediate premises of a commercial car wash or
commercial service station. Further, such washing may be exempted from these
regulations if the health, safety and welfare of the public is contingent
upon frequent vehicle cleansing, such as garbage trucks and vehicles used to
transport food and perishables.



         (c)   Use of water to fill, refill or add to any indoor
of outdoor swimming pools, wading pools or Jacuzzi-type pools is prohibited
except on designated watering days between the hours of 12:00 midnight and
10:00 a.m. and between 8:00 p.m. and 12:00 midnight.



         (d)   Operation of any ornamental fountain or pond for
aesthetic or scenic purposes is prohibited except where necessary to support
aquatic life or where such fountains or ponds are equipped with a
recirculation system.



         (e)   Use of water from hydrants shall be limited to
firefighting, related activities or other activities necessary to maintain
public health, safety and welfare, except that use of water from designated
fire hydrants for construction purposes may be allowed under special permit
from the city.



         (f)   Use of water for the irrigation of golf course
greens, tees and fairways is prohibited except on designated water days
between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 10:00 a.m. and between 8:00 p.m. and
12:00 midnight; however, if the golf course utilizes a water source or other
than that provided by the city, the facility shall not be subject to these
regulations.



         (g)   All restaurants are prohibited from serving water
to patrons except upon request of the patron.



         (h)   The following uses of water are defined as
nonessential and are prohibited:



            1.   Wash down of any sidewalks, walkways,
driveways, parking lots, tennis courts or other hard-surfaced areas;



            2.   Use of water to wash down buildings or
structures for purposes other than immediate fire protection;



            3.   Use of water for dust control;



            4.   Flushing gutters or permitting water to run
or accumulate in any gutter or street; and



            5.   Failure to repair a controllable leak(s)
within a reasonable period after having been given notice directing the
repair of such leak(s).



   (C)   Stage 2 response - moderate water shortage conditions.



      (1)   Goal: achieve a 10% reduction in daily water demand.



      (2)   Supply management measures: reduce flushing water mains
by 50%.



      (3)   Water use restrictions: under threat of penalty for
violation, the following water use restrictions shall apply to all persons.



         (a)   Irrigation of landscaped areas with hose-end
sprinklers or automatic irrigation systems shall be limited to Sundays and
Thursdays for customers with a street address ending in an even number,
Saturdays and Wednesdays for water customers with a street address ending in
an odd number, and to irrigation of landscaped areas is further limited to
the hours of 12:00 midnight until 10:00 a.m. and between 8:00 p.m. and 12:00
midnight on designated watering days; however, irrigation of landscaped areas
is permitted at anytime if it is by means of a handheld hose, and faucet
filled bucket or watering can of five gallons or less, or drip irrigation
system.



         (b)   Use of water to wash any motor vehicle, motorbike,
boat, trailer, airplane or other vehicle is prohibited except on designated
watering days between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 10:00 a.m. and between
8:00 p.m. and 12:00 midnight. Such washing, when allowed, shall be done with
a handheld hose equipped with a positive shutoff nozzle for quick rises.
Vehicle washing may be done at any time on the immediate premises of a
commercial car wash or commercial service station. Further, such washing may
be exempted from these regulations if the health, safety and welfare of the
public is contingent upon frequent vehicle cleansing, such as garbage trucks
and vehicles used to transport food and perishables.



         (c)   Use of water to fill, refill or add to any indoor
or outdoor swimming pools, wading pools or Jacuzzi-type pools is prohibited
except on designated watering days between the hours of 12:00 midnight and
10:00 a.m. and between 8:00 p.m. and 12:00 midnight.



         (d)   Operation of any ornamental fountain or pond for
aesthetic or scenic purposes is prohibited except where necessary to support
aquatic life or where such fountains or ponds are equipped with a
recirculation system.



         (e)   Use of water from hydrants shall be limited to
firefighting, related activities or other activities necessary to maintain
public health, safety and welfare, except that use of water from designated
fire hydrants for construction purposes may be allowed under special permit
from the city.



         (f)   Use of water for the irrigation of golf course
greens, tees and fairways is prohibited except on designated water days
between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 10:00 a.m. and between 8:00 p.m. and
12:00 midnight; however, if the golf course utilizes a water source or other
than that provided by the city, the facility shall not be subject to these
regulations



         (g)   All restaurants are prohibited from serving water
to patrons except upon request of the patron.



         (h)   The following uses of water are defined as
nonessential and are prohibited:



            1.   Wash down of any sidewalks, walkways,
driveways, parking lots, tennis courts or other hard-surfaced areas;



            2.   Use of water to wash down buildings or
structures for purposes other than immediate fire protection;



            3.   Use of water for dust control;



            4.   Flushing gutters or permitting water to run
or accumulate in any gutter or street; and



            5.   Failure to repair a controllable leak(s)
within a reasonable period after having been given notice directing the
repair of such leak(s).



   (D)   Stage 3 response - severe water shortage conditions.



      (1)   Goal: maintain a 10% cushion between daily water demand
and system capacity.



      (2)   Supply management measures: reduce flushing water mains
to immediate water quality measures only and reduced irrigation of public
landscaped areas. In extreme circumstances water may be trucked or bottled
water delivered to a location inside the city accessible to the public.



      (3)   Water use restrictions: all requirements of stage 2
shall remain in effect during stage 3 except:



         (a)   Irrigation of landscaped areas shall be limited to
designated watering days between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 10:00 a.m.
and 8:00 p.m. and 12:00 midnight and shall be by means of handheld hoses,
handheld buckets, drip irrigation or permanently installed automatic
sprinkler system only. The use of hose-end sprinklers is prohibited at all
times;



         (b)   The watering of golf course tees is prohibited
unless the golf course utilizes a water source other than that provided by
the city; and



         (c)   The use of water for construction purposes from
designated fire hydrants under special permit is to be discontinued.



(Prior Code, § 13.06.079)



§ 54.34  ENFORCEMENT.



   (A)   No person shall knowingly or intentionally allow the use of
water from the city for residential, commercial, industrial, agricultural,
governmental or any other purpose in a manner contrary to any provision of
this plan.



   (B)   Any person, including a person classified as a water customer
of the city, in apparent control of the property where a violation occurs or
originates shall be presumed to be the violator, and proof that the violation
occurred on the person’s property shall constitute a rebuttable presumption
that the person in apparent control of the property committed the violation,
but any such person shall have the right to show that he or she did not
commit the violation. Parents shall be presumed to be responsible for
violations of their minor children.



   (C)   Any employee of the city, police officer, or other city
employee designated by the Mayor, may issue a citation to a person he or she
reasonably believes to be in violation of this subchapter.



      (1)   The citation shall be prepared in duplicate and shall
contain the name and address of the alleged violator, the offense charged,
and shall direct him or her to appear in the Municipal Court on the date
shown on the citation for which the date shall not be less than three days
nor more that five days from the date the citation was issued.



      (2)   If the alleged violator fails to appear in Municipal
Court, a warrant for his or her arrest may be issued.



      (3)   A summons to appear may be issued in lieu of an arrest
warrant.



(Prior Code, § 13.06.080)  Penalty, see § 54.99



§ 54.35  VARIANCES.



   (A)   The Mayor, or his or her designee, may, in writing, grant
temporary variance for existing water uses otherwise prohibited under this
plan if it is determined that failure to grant such variance would cause an
emergency condition adversely affecting the health, sanitation or fire
protection for the public or the person requesting such variance and if one
or more of the following conditions are met:



      (1)   Compliance with this plan cannot be technically
accomplished during the duration of the water supply shortage or other
condition for which the plan is in effect; and



      (2)   Alternative methods can be implemented which will
achieve the same level of reduction in water use.



   (B)   (1)   Persons requesting an exemption from the provisions
of this subchapter shall file a petition for variance with the city within
five days after the plan or a particular drought response stage has been
invoked.



      (2)   All petitions for variances shall be reviewed by the
Mayor, or his or her designee, and shall include the following:



         (a)   Name and address of the petitioner(s);



         (b)   Purpose of water use;



         (c)   Specific provision(s) of the plan from which the
petitioner is requesting relief;



         (d)   Detailed statement as to how the specific
provision of the plan adversely affects the petitioner or what damage or harm
will occur to the petitioner or others if the petitioner complies with this
subchapter;



         (e)   Description of the relief requested;



         (f)   Period of time for which the variance is sought;



         (g)   Alternative water use restrictions or other
measures the petitioner is taking or proposes to take to meet the intent of
this plan and the compliance date; and



         (h)   Other pertinent information.



   (C)   Variances granted by the city shall be subject to the
following conditions, unless waived or modified by the Mayor, or his or her
designee:



      (1)   Variances granted shall include a timetable for
compliance; and



      (2)   Variances granted shall expire when the plan is no
longer in effect, unless the petitioner has failed to meet specified
requirements.



   (D)   No variances shall be retroactive or otherwise justify any
violation of this plan occurring prior to the issuance of the variance.



(Prior Code, § 13.06.081)  (Ord. 09-02-01, passed 2-24-2009)



§ 54.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which
no specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to § 10.99.



   (B)   Any person who violates §§ 54.25 through 54.35 is guilty of
a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine of not less
that $200 for the first violation and not less than $1,000 for the second
violation. If a person is convicted of three or more distinct violations of
this plan, the Mayor, or his or her designee shall, upon due notice to the
customer, be authorized to discontinue water service to the premises where
such violations occur. Services discontinued under such circumstances shall
be restored only upon payment of all related fines and a reconnect charge,
hereby established at $45. In addition, suitable assurance must be given to
the Mayor, or his or her designee, that the same action shall not be repeated
while the plan is in effect. Compliance with this plan may also be sought
through injunctive relief in the District Court.



(Prior Code, § 13.06.080)



CHAPTER 55:  CROSS-CONNECTION CONTROL



Section



   55.01   Generally



   55.02   Condensing, cooling or industrial process or other system of
nonpotable usage



   55.03   Overhead bulk water dispensing stations



   55.04   Backflow prevention assembly installation, testing and
maintenance



   55.05   Customer service inspections



   55.06   Enforcement



Statutory references:



   Backflow prevention for water closet plumbing fixtures or other
equipment, see Tex. Occupations Code, § 1301.501



   Endorsement of water supply protection specialists, see Tex.
Occupations Code, § 1301.357



   Licensing and registration of persons who perform duties relating to
public water supplies, see Tex. Health and Safety Code, § 341.034 and Tex.
Water Code, Ch. 37



§ 55.01  GENERALLY.



   (A)   No water service connection shall be made, or continued where
there is existing service, to any establishment or residence where a
potential or actual contamination hazard exists unless the city water supply
is protected from contamination in accordance with the State Commission on
Environmental Quality rules and regulations for public water systems (TCEQ
rules) and this chapter. The city shall discontinue water service if a
required backflow prevention system is not installed, maintained and tested,
where such potential or actual contamination hazard exists, in accordance
with the TCEQ rules and this chapter.



   (B)   Any residence or establishment where an actual or potential
contamination hazard exists shall be required to have additional protection
at the meter in the form of an air gap or backflow prevention assembly as
required by TCEQ rules.



   (C)   Any residence or establishment where an actual or potential
contamination hazard exists and an adequate internal cross-connection control
program is in effect is not required to have backflow protection at the water
service entrance or meter, provided that:



      (1)   Such residence or establishment has an annual inspection
and testing by a certified backflow prevention assembly tester on all
backflow prevention assemblies used for health hazard protection; and



      (2)   Copies of all such inspection and test reports are filed
with the city. It is the responsibility of the city to ensure that these
requirements are met.



(Prior Code, § 13.07.001)  (Ord. 04-04-31, passed 4-27-2004)



§ 55.02  CONDENSING, COOLING OR INDUSTRIAL PROCESS OR OTHER SYSTEM OF
NONPOTABLE USAGE.



   There shall be no water connection from the city water supply to any
condensing, cooling or industrial process or any other system of nonpotable
usage over which the city does not have sanitary control, unless the
connection is made in accordance with the requirements of § 55.01. Water
from such systems may not be returned to the potable water supply.



(Prior Code, § 13.07.002)  (Ord. 04-04-31, passed 4-27-2004)



§ 55.03  OVERHEAD BULK WATER DISPENSING STATIONS.



   Overhead bulk water dispensing stations must be provided with an air
gap between the filling outlet hose and the receiving tank.



(Prior Code, § 13.07.003)  (Ord. 04-04-31, passed 4-27-2004)



§ 55.04  BACKFLOW PREVENTION ASSEMBLY INSTALLATION, TESTING AND MAINTENANCE.



   (A)   All backflow prevention assemblies shall be tested upon
installation by a recognized backflow prevention assembly tester and
certified to be operating within specifications. Backflow prevention
assemblies which are installed to provide protection against health hazards
must also be tested and certified to be operating within specifications at
least annually by a recognized backflow prevention assembly tester.



   (B)   All backflow prevention assemblies shall be installed and
tested for accuracy in accordance with the manufacture’s instructions and
the American Water Works Association Recommended Practice for Backflow
Prevention and Cross-Connection Control (Manual M14) or the University of
Southern California Manual of Cross-Connection Control.



   (C)   Assemblies shall be repaired, overhauled or replaced whenever
said assemblies are found to be defective at the expense of the owner of the
residence or establishment. Original forms documenting such tests, repairs
and overhaul shall be kept and submitted to the city within five working days
of the test, repair or overhaul of each backflow prevention assembly.



   (D)   No backflow prevention assembly or device shall be removed
from use, relocated or otherwise moved from the location where it was
originally installed. If such backflow prevention assembly or device becomes
defective to the extent that it cannot be repaired, the backflow assembly or
device shall be replaced with a backflow prevention assembly or device that
complies with this section, the American Water Works Association’s
Recommended Practice for Backflow Prevention and Cross-Connection Control
(Manual M14), current edition, University of Southern California Manual of
Cross-Connection Control, current edition, or the current plumbing code of
the city, whichever is more stringent.



   (E)   Test gauges used for backflow prevention assembly testing
shall be calibrated at least annually in accordance with the American Water
Works Association’s Recommended Practice for Backflow Prevention and
Cross-Connection Control (Manual M14), current edition, or the University of
Southern California’s Manual of Cross-Connection Control, current edition.
The signed and dated original of the calibration form must be submitted to
the city within five working days of calibration.



   (F)   To be a recognized backflow prevention assembly tester a
person must hold a current certification from the state commission on
environmental quality.



(Prior Code, § 13.07.004)  (Ord. 04-04-31, passed 4-27-2004)



§ 55.05  CUSTOMER SERVICE INSPECTIONS.



   (A)   A customer service inspection shall be completed prior to
providing continuous water service to all new construction, on any existing
service when the water surveyor has reason to believe that cross-connections
or other actual or potential contaminant hazards exist, or after any material
improvement, correction or addition to any residence or establishment.



   (B)   Only individuals with the following credentials shall be
recognized as capable of conducting a customer service inspection:



      (1)   Plumbing inspectors and water supply protection
specialists that have been licensed by the State Board of Plumbing Examiners;
and



      (2)   Certified waterworks operators, and members of other
water-related professional groups who have completed a training course and
passed an examination administered by the TCEQ, or its designated agent, and
hold a current certification issued by the TCEQ.



   (C)   The customer service inspection must certify that:



      (1)   There is no direct connection between the public
drinking water supply and an actual or potential source of contamination.
Actual or potential sources of contamination are isolated from the public
water system by an air gap or an appropriate backflow prevention assembly in
accordance with the TCEQ rules and regulations;



      (2)   There is no cross-connection between the public drinking
water supply, a private water system and a private water supply, unless an
approved reduced-pressure-zone backflow prevention assembly is properly
installed and a service agreement exists for annual inspection and testing by
a certified backflow prevention assembly tester on all backflow prevention
assemblies used for health hazard protection;



      (3)   No connection exists which would allow the return of
water used for condensing, cooling or industrial processes or any other
system of nonpotable usage over which the city does not have sanitary control
back to the public water supply;



      (4)   No pipe or pipe fitting which contains more than 8% lead
exists in private water distribution facilities installed on or after July 1,
1988; and



      (5)   No solder or flux which contains more than 0.2% lead
exists in private water distribution facilities installed on or after July 1,
1988.



(Prior Code, § 13.07.004)  (Ord. 04-04-31, passed 4-27-2004)



§ 55.06  ENFORCEMENT.



   Any person who violates this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and,
upon conviction shall be punished as provided for in § 10.99. If a person is
convicted of one or more distinct violations of this chapter, the city
designee shall, upon written notice to the customer, be authorized to
discontinue water service to the premises where such violations occur.
Services discontinued under such circumstances shall be restored only upon
payment of the current reconnection charge, and any other costs incurred by
the city in discontinuing service. Compliance with this chapter may also be
sought through injunctive relief in the District Court, as provided in §
10.99.



(Prior Code, § 13.07.005)  (Ord. 04-04-31, passed 4-27-2004)
