GENERAL PROVISIONS




§ 90.001  KEEPING OF SWINE.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain swine
in any place or property within the city at a distance of less than 300 feet
from any residence, dwelling, place of business, public sidewalk or public
street of the city; provided, however, that this section shall not be
construed to apply to nor to prohibit the public exhibition or keeping of
swine, in a sanitary and clean enclosure, and in such manner as not to be or
constitute a nuisance to the immediate neighborhood of such enclosure, for
experimental or educational purposes.



   (B)   Notwithstanding anything to the contrary herein, it shall not
be unlawful to keep a small exotic breed of pig (for example, a Vietnamese
potbellied pig) as a household pet; however, no household shall have more
than three pigs at one time. The owner of each such pig shall have a
veterinarian’s certificate of vaccination for erysipelas for each pig by
the age of three months.



(Prior Code, § 2.01.001)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 90.002  LIVESTOCK RUNNING AT LARGE.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to allow and permit any cows,
horses, mules, jacks, jennets, goats, sheep, swine or any other livestock of
any character to run at large within the city.



(Prior Code, § 2.01.002)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 90.003  FOWL RUNNING AT LARGE.



   It shall be unlawful for the owner or keeper of any geese, ducks,
turkeys, chickens or other domestic fowl to allow or permit the same to run
at large in the city.



(Prior Code, § 2.01.003)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 90.004  DISPOSAL OF DEAD ANIMALS.



   The carcass of any animal dead of disease or other cause not
slaughtered for food shall be removed and/or disposed of by the owner if
known and, if not known, the owner of the premises where such animal is
found, at his or her own expense within 24 hours after such death, according
to such method as may be approved by the animal control officer or designee.



(Prior Code, § 2.01.004)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 90.005  SANITATION.



   The owner or person in possession of animals shall keep yards, pens and
enclosures in which such animals, including livestock and fowl, are confined
in such a manner so as not to give off odors offensive to persons of ordinary
sensibilities residing in the vicinity, or to breed or attract flies,
mosquitoes or other noxious insects, or in any manner to endanger the public
health or safety, or create a public nuisance.



(Prior Code, § 2.01.005)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 90.006  PET CARE.



   It is hereby prohibited and shall be unlawful for any person to
willfully abandon any animal, to withhold food or water from any animal such
that its health is endangered, fail to provide shelter in accordance with
current conditions, or to treat the animal in such a way that it suffers
unduly.



(Prior Code, § 2.01.006)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 90.007  NUISANCES.



   The following shall be considered a public nuisance and shall be
unlawful:



   (A)   The keeping of any dog, cat, livestock or fowl, which by
causing frequent or long-continued barking or noise, shall disturb any person
of ordinary sensibilities in the vicinity;



   (B)   The keeping of any dog, cat, livestock or fowl in such a
manner as to endanger the public health; to annoy neighbors by the
accumulation of dog, cat, livestock or fowl wastes which cause foul and
offensive odors, or are considered to be a hazard to any other animal or
human being; or by continued presence on the premises of another; and



   (C)   All animal pens, stables or enclosures in which any animal may
be kept or confined which, from use have become offensive to a person of
ordinary sensibilities.



(Prior Code, § 2.01.007)  Penalty, see § 10.99




DOGS AND CATS




§ 90.020  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER OR DESIGNEE.  Any person designated by the City
Manager to enforce the provisions of this subchapter.



   CAT.  Any member of the Felis catus species, either male or female.



   DOG.  Any member of the canine species of animals, either male or
female.



   OWNER.  Any person having title to any animal; or a person who has,
harbors or keeps, or who causes or permits to be harbored or kept, an animal
in his or her care, or who permits an animal to remain on or about his or her
premises.



   RUNNING AT LARGE.  Not completely confined by a building, wall or
fence of sufficient strength or construction to restrain the animal, except
when such animal is either on a leash or held in the hands of the owner or
keeper, or under the direct supervision of the owner within the limits of the
owner’s private property. Leaving an unattended dog fastened to a leash,
chain or trolley shall not be deemed to comply with the requirements of this
subchapter.



   VICIOUS DOG.  Any dog that has made an unprovoked attack on any person
causing physical injury to that person, or that has caused physical injury to
at least two or more persons whether the attacks were provoked or not.



(Prior Code, § 2.02.001)



§ 90.021  ENFORCEMENT.



   (A)   Enforcement of this subchapter shall be the responsibility of
the animal control officer or designee.



   (B)   The animal control officer or designee shall have the
authority to issue citations for any violations of this subchapter. If the
person cited is not present, the animal control officer or designee may send
the citation to the alleged defendant by registered or certified mail.



   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with any
animal control officer or designee in the performance of his or her duties.



(Prior Code, § 2.02.002)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 90.022  RUNNING AT LARGE.



   It shall be unlawful for any dog possessed, kept or harbored to run at
large anywhere in the city. This regulation shall apply to all public places
and to all private property. Leaving an unattended dog fastened to a leash,
chain or trolley shall not be deemed to comply with the requirements of this
section. The animal control officer or designee is authorized to impound any
dog found to be running at large.



(Prior Code, § 2.02.003)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 90.023  LIMITATION ON NUMBER.



   (A)   It is unlawful for any household to own or keep more than four
dogs or four cats or a combination of four dogs and cats upon any private
premises within the city limits subject to the following exceptions: a
veterinary clinic, an animal hospital or similar facility; an animal shelter;
a kennel; a pet shop; a research institution; a qualified researcher; a
performing animal exhibition; or a litter up to 12 weeks old.



   (B)   It is an exception to this provision if the dogs are housed at
all times within a dwelling or on a premises which is a minimum of one acre
in size and the dwelling or premises is maintained in a sanitary manner that
is not a public health nuisance, no noise nuisance, or a danger to the
animals or the public.



   (C)   Provisions of divisions (A) and (B) above shall not become
effective until one year after the adoption of this code.



   (D)   Every yard, shed, pen or other structure used for the storage
or shelter of animals shall be cleaned and maintained so as to maintain safe
and healthy conditions for the animals, to prevent the escape of any noxious
odors or substances to adjacent properties, or to create any health hazard or
nuisance to adjacent property owners. Allowing or permitting of such
violation is hereby declared a public nuisance. Provisions of this division
(D) shall become effective immediately upon adoption of this code.



(Prior Code, § 2.02.004)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 90.024  DANGEROUS DOGS; STATE LAW ADOPTED.



   Dangerous dogs, as defined in Tex. Health and Safety Code, § 822.041,
shall be regulated in accordance with the provisions of Tex. Health and
Safety Code, Ch. 822, subchapter D, §§ 822.041 et seq.



(Prior Code, § 2.02.031)  Penalty, see § 10.99



Statutory reference:



   Authority of city to regulate the keeping of dangerous dogs, see Tex.
Health and Safety Code, § 822.041 et seq.




RABIES CONTROL




§ 90.035  VACCINATION OF DOGS AND CATS.



   Every owner of a dog or cat four months of age or older shall have such
animal vaccinated against rabies, and such dog or cat shall receive a booster
rabies vaccination within the 12-month interval following the initial
vaccination. Every domestic dog or cat must be re-vaccinated against rabies
at a minimum of at least once every three years with a rabies vaccine
licensed by the United States Department of Agriculture. Any person moving
into the city from a location outside of the city shall comply with this
section within ten days after having moved into the city.



(Prior Code, § 2.03.001)  Penalty, see § 10.99



Statutory reference:



   Rabies vaccinations, see Tex. Health and Safety Code, §§ 826.021 et
seq.



§ 90.036  REPORT OF RABID ANIMALS.



   It shall be the duty of the owner or harborer of any animal, and all
practicing veterinarians, to report to the animal control officer or designee
all cases of rabies with which he or she comes in contact or to which his or
her attention has been directed. This report shall be made immediately upon
diagnosis or suspicion of such cases of rabies.



(Prior Code, § 2.03.002)  Penalty, see § 10.99



Statutory reference:



   Reports of rabies, see Tex. Health and Safety Code, § 826.041



§ 90.037  QUARANTINE.



   (A)   The animal control officer or designee shall have the
authority to order the quarantine of animals responsible for bite incidents,
or suspected of having any disease considered to be a hazard to the human
population or other animals.



   (B)   Every animal that bites a human, or attacks another animal in
an unnatural manner, or has rabies or any other disease, or is under
suspicion of having rabies or any other disease, shall be immediately
confined by the owner, who shall promptly notify the animal control officer
or designee of the place where such animal is confined and the reason
therefor. The owner shall not permit such animal to come in contact with any
other person or animal. The owner shall surrender possession of such animal
to the animal control officer or designee on demand for supervised
quarantine. Supervised quarantine shall be at the city pound or veterinary
hospital, or by any other method of adequate confinement approved by the
animal control officer or designee. The quarantine shall be for not less than
ten days. A release from quarantine may be issued if no signs of rabies or
other diseases have been observed during the quarantine period of ten days.



      (1)   Any animal quarantined other than at the city pound
shall be observed by the same veterinarian throughout the entire required
quarantine period, and the owner shall immediately notify the animal control
officer or designee as to the veterinarian supervising the quarantine.



      (2)   If the animal control officer or designee orders
quarantine, it shall be in the city pound or a veterinary hospital.



   (C)   All animal bites reported shall be investigated by the animal
control officer or designee. Without permission of the animal control officer
or designee, it shall be unlawful for any person to kill or remove from the
city limits any animal that has bitten a person or other animal, or that has
been placed under quarantine except when it is necessary to kill such to
protect the life of any person or animal.



   (D)   The animal control officer or designee shall direct the
disposition of an animal suspected of being rabid or having any other disease
considered to be a hazard to any animal or human being.



   (E)   The carcass of any dead animal exposed to rabies, or suspected
of having been rabid, shall, upon demand, be surrendered to the animal
control officer or designee.



   (F)   Every animal that has been bitten by another animal shall be
immediately confined by the owner, who shall promptly notify the animal
control officer or designee of the place where such animal is confined and
the reason therefor. The owner shall not permit such animal to come in
contact with any person or animal.



   (G)   Any animal known exposed to rabies shall be handled in one of
the following manners:



      (1)   Humane destruction with notification to, or under the
supervision of, the animal control officer or designee; or



      (2)   Quarantine in a veterinary hospital for at least six
months immediately following the date of the exposure.



   (H)   No person shall fail to surrender an animal for supervised
quarantine or humane destruction, as required herein, for rabies control when
demand therefor is made by the animal control officer or designee.



(Prior Code, § 2.03.003)  Penalty, see § 10.99



Statutory references:



   Quarantine and impoundment facilities generally, see Tex. Health and
Safety Code, §§ 826.051 et seq.



   Quarantine of animals, see Tex. Health and Safety Code, § 826.042




IMPOUNDMENT




§ 90.050  AUTHORIZED.



   The following dogs or cats may be impounded:



   (A)   Dogs or cats not exhibiting evidence of being vaccinated as
described in § 90.035;



   (B)   Any dog or cat infected or kept under conditions which could
endanger the public or animal health;



   (C)   Any dog or cat that creates a nuisance, as defined in §
90.007;



   (D)   Any dog running at large, as stipulated in § 90.022;



   (E)   Any dog or cat treated in a manner determined by the animal
control officer or designee to be cruel or inhumane;



   (F)   Any dog or cat that has bitten a human being or needs to be
placed under observation for rabies determination as determined by an animal
control officer or designee; and



   (G)   Any dog or cat violating any provision of this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 2.04.001)



§ 90.051  NOTICE TO OWNER.



   Reasonable effort should be made by the animal control officer or
designee to contact the owner of any dog or cat impounded; however, final
responsibility for the location of the dog or cat is that of the owner.



(Prior Code, § 2.04.002)



§ 90.052  REDEMPTION GENERALLY.



   The owner may resume possession of any impounded animal, to include
livestock and fowl, upon payment of impoundment fees, handling fees and any
veterinarian bills which may be incurred by the animal control officer or
designee for the welfare of the animal, to include livestock and fowl, and
upon compliance with the vaccination provisions of this chapter.



(Prior Code, § 2.04.003)



§ 90.053  REDEMPTION AFTER QUARANTINE.



   If any dog or cat is held under quarantine or observation for rabies,
the owner shall not be entitled to possession until it has been released from
quarantine by the animal control officer or designee, and all quarantine fees
are paid. Additionally, handling fees will attach to quarantine fees for
animals not reclaimed after the quarantine period expires. If the fees were
not paid and the dog or cat reclaimed within ten days at the end of the
quarantine period, the dog or cat shall be considered relinquished to the
shelter for disposition.



(Prior Code, § 2.04.004)



§ 90.054  POUND.



   The City Manager shall select and establish a place for impounding all
animals, to include livestock and fowl, impounded under any provision of this
subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 2.04.005)



§ 90.055  RETENTION PERIOD.



   Any impounded animal, to include livestock and fowl, not under
quarantine, will be considered relinquished to the shelter.



(Prior Code, § 2.04.006)



§ 90.056  DISPOSAL.



   (A)   Any animal, including livestock and fowl, not reclaimed by the
owner may be humanely euthanized after being impounded 72 hours.



   (B)   Any nursing animal, including livestock and fowl, impounded
without the mother, or where the mother cannot or refuses to provide a
nutritious milk, may be immediately euthanized to prevent further suffering.



   (C)   Any impounded animal, including livestock and fowl, that
appears to be suffering from extreme injury or illness may be euthanized or
given to a nonprofit humane organization without regard to the 72-hour period
for the purpose of veterinary medical care, as determined by the animal
control officer or designee.



(Prior Code, § 2.04.007)



§ 90.057  IMMEDIATE EUTHANIZATION AUTHORIZED.



   An owner who no longer wishes responsibility for his or her animal,
including livestock and fowl, or believes the animal, including livestock and
fowl, to be in ill or injured condition, may sign a written waiver supplied
by the animal control officer or designee allowing the animal to be
immediately euthanized in a humane manner, provided that no dog or cat that
has bitten a human being shall be euthanized before the expiration of the
ten-day quarantine period.



(Prior Code, § 2.04.008)  (Ord. 94-8-9, passed 8-16-1994)



§ 90.058  FEES.



   (A)   Impoundment fees for animals, including livestock and fowl,
shall be on file in the City Secretary’s office.



   (B)   A daily handling fee shall be charged for every day, or
fraction thereof, that an animal, including livestock and fowl, is at the
pound. Such fee shall be on file in the City Secretary’s office. This fee
shall be paid in addition the impoundment fees.



   (C)   The owner of any dog, cat or dangerous or vicious dog held in
quarantine for observation purposes shall be charged an additional fee, which
is on file in the City Secretary’s office for every day or fraction of a
day a dog or cat is at the pound. This is in addition to the impoundment and
handling fees.



   (D)   If a licensed veterinarian is called to the animal pound to
examine or inspect the dog or cat, this fee shall be charged to the owner.
This fee is in addition to any other fees in this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 2.04.009)




ADOPTION FROM ANIMAL SHELTER




§ 90.070  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   ANIMAL SHELTER.  The animal shelter operated by the city.



   NEW OWNER.  A person who is legally competent to enter into a binding
contract and who is adopting an animal, including livestock and fowl, from
the city animal shelter.



   STERILIZATION.  The surgical removal of the reproductive organs of a
dog or cat to render the animal unable to reproduce.



   VETERINARIAN.  A person licensed to practice veterinary medicine by
the State Board of Veterinary Medical Examiners.



(Prior Code, § 2.05.001)



§ 90.071  REQUIREMENTS FOR ADOPTION.



   (A)   An individual may adopt an animal, including livestock and
fowl, from the city animal shelter if:



      (1)   The individual complies with the requirements of this
code;



      (2)   The animal, including livestock and fowl, has been
classified as adoptable by the animal shelter;



      (3)   The prospective adopter demonstrates that they have
proper facilities to care for the animal;



      (4)   The prospective adopter obtains all necessary
registration and vaccinations for the animal; and



      (5)   The prospective adopter pays the fee set by the City
Council for adoption of an animal, including livestock and fowl. A schedule
of adoption fees shall be kept on file by the city animal control officer or
designee.



   (B)   Except as provided by § 90.075, the city animal shelter may
not release a dog or cat for adoption unless the animal has been sterilized
or the release is made to a new owner who signs an agreement to have the
animal sterilized.



(Prior Code, § 2.05.002)



Statutory reference:



   Sterilization of dog or cat released for adoption, see Tex. Health and
Safety Code, Ch. 828



§ 90.072  DENIAL OF ADOPTION.



   (A)   The city animal control officer or designee may refuse to
allow a person to adopt an animal, including livestock and fowl, if he or she
has reason to believe:



      (1)   Such person would not, in the opinion of the animal
control officer or designee, have the proper facilities to contain or care
for the animal, including livestock and fowl, as required by this code;



      (2)   Such person wants the animal, including livestock and
fowl, for the purpose of resale or for purposes other than for pet ownership;



      (3)   The animal, including livestock and fowl, would be a
hazard or threat to humans or other animals;



      (4)   If, during the course of the interaction/observation
period between the animal and the prospective owner, the animal control
officer or designee observes behavior on the part of the person or animal
that indicates a potential hazard to either;



      (5)   The person refuses to agree to spay or neuter the animal
as required by this subchapter; or



      (6)   The person refuses or fails to pay the adoption fee
required by this chapter.



   (B)   The city animal control officer or designee may refuse to
allow a person to adopt an animal, including livestock and fowl, if the
prospective adopter has, in the past, adopted an animal, including livestock
and fowl, and has failed to have the adopted animal sterilized.



(Prior Code, § 2.05.003)



§ 90.073  STERILIZATION.



   (A)   Agreement. The sterilization agreement used by the animal
shelter must contain:



      (1)   The date of the agreement;



      (2)   The name(s), address(es) and signature(s) of the new
owner or new owners;



      (3)   A description of the animal to be adopted;



      (4)   The sterilization completion date;



      (5)   A description of the letters required if the dog or cat
is not spayed or neutered; and



      (6)   A statement that the sterilization must be done by a
veterinarian licensed by the state.



   (B)   Deadline.



      (1)   Except as provided by this section, a new owner who
signs an agreement under division (A) above shall have the adopted animal
sterilized on or before the sterilization completion date stated in the
agreement.



      (2)   The sterilization completion date contained in the
sterilization agreement must be:



         (a)   The thirtieth day after the date of adoption in
the case of an adult animal; or



         (b)   The thirtieth day after a specified date estimated
to be the date an adopted infant female animal becomes six months old or an
adopted infant male animal becomes eight months old.



      (3)   If the sterilization completion date falls on a
Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday, the deadline is extended to the first day
that is not a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday.



      (4)   The animal shelter may extend the deadline for 30 days
on presentation of a written report from a veterinarian licensed by the state
stating that the life or health of the adopted animal may be jeopardized by
surgery.



   (C)   Confirmation of sterilization.



      (1)   Except as provided by division (D) below, each new owner
who signs a sterilization agreement under division (A) above shall deliver to
the animal shelter from which the animal was adopted a letter signed by the
veterinarian who performed the surgery.



      (2)   The letter must be delivered in person or by mail not
later than the seventh day after the date on which the animal was sterilized.



      (3)   The letter must state that the animal has been
sterilized, briefly describe the animal and provide the date of sterilization.



   (D)   Letter concerning animal’s death or loss.



      (1)   If an adopted animal dies or is lost or stolen on or
before the sterilization completion date agreed to under division (A) above,
the new owner shall deliver to the animal shelter a signed letter stating
that the animal is dead, lost or was stolen.



      (2)   The letter must be delivered not later than the seventh
day after the date of the animal’s death, theft or loss, and must describe
the cause of death, if known, and provide the date of death, loss or theft.



      (3)   The letter required by this subsection is in lieu of the
letter required by division (C) above.



   (E)   Notice of failure to receive letter. A releasing agency that
does not receive a letter required under divisions (C) or (D) above before
the expiration of the seventh day after the sterilization completion date
agreed to under this section shall cause a complaint to be filed against the
new owner. It is a presumption under this subchapter that the failure of the
new owner to deliver to the animal shelter a signed letter, as required under
divisions (C) or (D) above, is the result of the new owner’s refusal to
have the adopted animal sterilized. The new owner may rebut this presumption
at the time of the hearing with the proof required under the above-mentioned
divisions.



(Prior Code, § 2.05.004)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 90.074  RECLAMATION.



   (A)   If the animal control officer or designee does not receive a
letter under § 90.073(C) or (D) after the expiration of the seventh day
after the sterilization completion date agreed to under § 90.073, the animal
control officer or designee may promptly reclaim the animal from the new
owner.



   (B)   A person may not give false information to the animal control
officer or designee regarding an adopted animal, or prevent, obstruct or
interfere with a reclamation under this section.



   (C)   A person who violates division (B) above shall be adjudged
guilty of a Class C misdemeanor and punished as authorized under § 10.99.



(Prior Code, § 2.05.005)



§ 90.075  EXCEPTIONS.



   Nothing herein shall prohibit the sale of unwanted animals to a medical
school or a medical or veterinary facility for medical research or for the
treatment of other animals.



(Prior Code, § 2.05.006)




VICIOUS ANIMALS




§ 90.090  DOGS AT LARGE.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, harbor, raise or allow to
run at large any vicious dog within the city.



(Prior Code, § 2.06.001)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 90.091  ANIMALS AT LARGE.



   It shall be unlawful to allow to run at large any wild or vicious
animal within the city. As used in this section, a WILD ANIMAL shall mean any
animal that is not ordinarily domesticated. A VICIOUS ANIMAL shall mean any
animal, other than a dog, that by its nature or physical makeup is capable of
causing serious physical injury or death to human beings.



(Prior Code, § 2.06.002)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 90.092  IMPOUNDMENT.



   (A)   The animal control officer or designee shall cause to be
seized and impounded any vicious dog found to be running at large or that is
found to be kept or living within the city.



   (B)   The animal control officer or designee shall cause to be
seized and impounded any wild or vicious animal found to be running at large
within the city.



(Prior Code, § 2.06.003)



§ 90.093  TRANQUILIZATION, DESTRUCTION.



   If, during the course of seizing and impounding any animal under this
subchapter, including, but not limited to vicious dogs, the animal poses a
risk of serious physical harm or death to any person, such person authorized
by the animal control officer or designee may render such animal immobile, by
means of tranquilizers or other safe drugs or if that is not safely possible
then such animal may be killed.



(Prior Code, § 2.06.004)



§ 90.094  REDEMPTION RESTRICTED.



   (A)   Any vicious dog or wild or vicious animal shall not be
released from impoundment, unless and until the animal control officer or
designee is satisfied that the owner of such vicious dog or wild or vicious
animal has made arrangements to keep the same outside of the city, and that
the vicious dog or wild or vicious animal will be immediately and permanently
removed from the city and the impoundment and any other applicable fees which
are on file in the City Secretary’s office are paid.



   (B)   No vicious dog or wild or vicious animal may be adopted out of
the city pound; however, the owner of any impounded vicious dog or wild or
vicious animal may resume possession of the same if such owner makes
arrangements for keeping the same outside the city within 72 hours of
impoundment. The animal control officer or designee shall euthanize any such
vicious dog or wild or vicious animal not redeemed by its owner after the
expiration of 72 hours of impoundment.



(Prior Code, § 2.06.005)  Penalty, see § 10.99




KEEPING OF LIVESTOCK




§ 90.105  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   FOWL.  Any heavy bodied, terrestrial bird of the order Galliformes,
including but not limited to chickens, ducks, geese, pheasants, turkey,
grouse, guineas or other common domestic fowl, but not including caged pet
birds kept inside a building and otherwise not a bird defined as fowl.



   LIVESTOCK.  Any horse, swine, cattle, sheep, goat, mule, jack, jenny,
emu, ostrich or rhea.



(Prior Code, § 2.07.001)



§ 90.106  KEEPING OF LIVESTOCK, FOWL, HOGS AND SWINE PROHIBITED.



   (A)   Livestock. It shall be unlawful to own, keep or harbor, any
livestock within the city limits, except as follows.



      (1)   Numerical limitation. In areas zoned RE (Residential
Estates District) and FP (Floodplain District), no more than one livestock
animal per fenced in acre may be kept. In all other zoning districts, no more
than three livestock animals per fenced in acre may be kept.



      (2)   Restraint. The acreage on which such livestock are
maintained must be enclosed by a fence of sufficient height, strength and
construction to keep such livestock from escaping from the premises.



      (3)   Pens and structures. All livestock kept under this
section shall be provided a stable, shed, pen or other structure of adequate
size for the storage, shelter and safekeeping of such animals.



      (4)   Location of pens and structures. Every such stable,
shed, pen or other structure for the storage, shelter and safekeeping of
livestock shall be at least 25 feet from the property of any other property
owner at the nearest point.



   (B)   Fowl. It shall be unlawful to own, keep or harbor any fowl
within the city limits, except as follows.



      (1)   Numerical limitation. In areas zoned RE (Residential
Estates District) and FP (Floodplain District), no more than six fowl may be
kept per acre. In all other zoning districts, no more than six fowl may be
kept per household regardless of lot size.



      (2)   Restraint. All fowl kept under this section shall be
confined in a pen, coop or other structure sufficient to prevent their escape.



      (3)   Location of pens and structures. Every such pen, coop or
other structure required for the confinement of fowl under this section shall
be located at least 50 feet distant from the property of any other property
owner at the nearest point.



   (C)   Hogs and swine. It shall be unlawful to own, keep or harbor
any hogs or swine within the city limits, except as follows.



      (1)   This section shall not be construed to apply to nor to
prohibit the public exhibition or keeping of swine, in a sanitary and clean
enclosure, and in such manner as not to be or constitute a nuisance to the
immediate neighborhood of such enclosure, for experimental or educational
purposes.



      (2)   Notwithstanding anything to the contrary herein, it
shall not be unlawful to keep a small exotic breed of pig (for example, a
Vietnamese potbellied pig) as a household pet; however, no household shall
have more than three pigs at one time. The owner of each pig shall have a
veterinarian’s certificate of vaccination for erysipelas for each pig by
the age of three months.



      (3)   All provisions of § 90.001 inconsistent with this
division (B) are herewith expressly repealed.



(Prior Code, § 2.07.002)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 90.107  PROHIBITIONS AND RESTRICTIONS.



   Prohibitions and restrictions set out in this subchapter shall not
apply to:



   (A)   A zoo, zoological park or animal park;



   (B)   An accredited research institution;



   (C)   A qualified researcher utilizing such livestock or fowl in
connection with defined research objectives;



   (D)   An animal exhibition operating under contract, lease or
special event permit, or otherwise duly approved by the city;



   (E)   Someone lawfully engaged in the transport of livestock or fowl
in an enclosed vehicle in accordance with state law unless such livestock,
fowl, hogs or swine create a nuisance, as defined by § 90.007;



   (F)   Someone engaged in the transport or receipt of livestock or
fowl for processing in connection with the operation of a cattle auction,
slaughterhouse or like facility;



   (G)   A commercial farm and ranch feed and supply business or pet
store;



   (H)   An animal shelter, veterinary clinic or similar facility for
the treatment and temporary shelter of animals in connection therewith; or



   (I)   Livestock, fowl, hogs or swine kept by a student in a primary
or secondary school on a temporary basis as part of a learning project though
his or her school, unless such livestock, fowl, hogs or swine create a
nuisance as defined by § 90.007.



(Prior Code, § 2.07.003)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 90.108  ANNEXATION.



   Areas on which agricultural operations are conducted or livestock are
kept that are annexed into the city after the adoption of this subchapter may
retain such uses as legal uses pursuant to state law. Such agricultural or
livestock operations in such newly-annexed areas can only be altered by the
City Council, by resolution, making findings that such regulations are
necessary to protect the public health.



(Prior Code, § 2.07.004)



§ 90.109  ANIMAL PARADES, HERDING PROHIBITED; DEFENSES.



   It is unlawful to herd, parade or otherwise move livestock from one
location to another along a public street or highway in the city unless the
person is:



   (A)   Doing so pursuant to the conditions of a parade permit duly
issued under this code; or



   (B)   An officer or employee of the federal, state or local
government engaged in the performance of official duties.



(Prior Code, § 2.07.005)  (Ord. 09-07-09, passed 7-28-2009)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99

GENERAL PROVISIONS




§ 91.001  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   CARETAKER.  The person designated to supervise and manage the
operation of the cemetery.



   CEMETERY.  Any cemetery owned and/or operated by the city.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.001)




CEMETERY BOARD




§ 91.015  CREATED.



   A Cemetery Board is hereby created in and for the city.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.031)



§ 91.016  COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS.



   The Cemetery Board shall consist of seven members, who shall be
appointed by the City Council.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.032)



§ 91.017  MEMBERS’ QUALIFICATIONS AND OATH.



   Members of the Cemetery Board shall be qualified voters residing in the
city and, after their appointment, they shall subscribe to the oath of office.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.033)



§ 91.018  TERMS OF MEMBERS.



   The members of the Cemetery Board shall be appointed for a term of two
years from such appointment and until a successor is appointed and qualified.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.034)



§ 91.019  SECRETARY.



   There is hereby created the office of Secretary to the Cemetery Board,
which shall be filled by a person qualified to keep the records of the Board
and to account for the receipt and expenditure of all funds arising from the
operation of the cemeteries.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.035)



§ 91.020  GENERAL POWERS AND DUTIES.



   The Cemetery Board shall act in an advisory capacity to the City
Council relative to the management and operation of the cemeteries. The Board
shall see that the operation of such cemeteries is in conformity with the
laws of the state and the Charter of the city.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.036)




PERMITS




§ 91.035  ORDER AND PERMIT FOR WORK ON LOTS.



   (A)   The city will not allow work of any description to be placed
upon any cemetery lot, unless a written order from the lot holder or his or
her representative is presented and a permit is obtained from the cemetery
caretaker.



   (B)   This section applies to the cutting of inscriptions, setting
of markers and the like, and also to the removal of anything from the lot.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.061)



§ 91.036  PERMIT FOR WORKERS.



   No workers, except those employed in the erection of stone work under a
regular permit, will be allowed to work in the grounds of the cemetery,
except by permission of the caretaker.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.062)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 91.037  EXCLUSION OF PERSONS FROM GROUNDS; REFUSAL OF PERMITS.



   The city shall have the right to exclude from the grounds of the
cemetery any person who disobeys any provision of this chapter. The city
shall also have the right to refuse permission to persons whose work is not
satisfactory, or whose employees disobey the rules of the cemetery.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.063)




REGULATIONS




§ 91.050  AUTHORITY TO LAY OUT AND ALTER WALKS AND AVENUES AND MAKE RULES
AND REGULATIONS.



   The City Council may, from time to time, lay out and alter avenues or
walks and make such rules and regulations for the government of the grounds
and care and control of lots in the cemetery as it may deem requisite and
proper to secure and promote the general objects of the cemetery.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.091)



§ 91.051  SUSPENSION OF WORK WHEN CHAPTER VIOLATED.



   The city shall have the power to suspend work in the cemetery
immediately whenever there is a failure to conform to the rules and
regulations prescribed in this chapter.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.092)



§ 91.052  PRICE OF LOTS.



   All lots sold in the cemetery shall be of such size and for such price
as may be fixed and determined by the City Council and on file in the City
Secretary’s office.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.093)



§ 91.053  GENERAL RESTRICTIONS ON USE.



   The cemetery shall be used for cemetery purposes only.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.094)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 91.054  OPENING HOURS.



   The cemetery will be open from 6:00 a.m. to sunset to all lot owners
and visitors, or at such other times as the City Council may designate.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.095)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 91.055  VEHICLES AND ANIMALS.



   The driving or riding of vehicles or animals will not be allowed on
lots or upon the lawns or walks of the cemetery.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.096)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 91.056  SITTING, STANDING AND THE LIKE ON LOTS, GRAVES AND THE LIKE.



   Sitting, lounging or lying at full length on lots, mounds or ornamental
grounds at the cemetery and sitting or standing on graves therein is strictly
prohibited.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.097)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 91.057  GRAVE-DIGGING.



   The digging of a grave for an interment in the cemetery will only be
permitted by authorized persons, under the direction of the cemetery
caretaker. A notice of not less than five working hours must be given to
ensure proper preparation of the grave.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.098)



§ 91.058  CHANGING LOT GRADES.



   The grades of cemetery lots once established cannot be changed without
the consent of the City Council or appointed authority.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.099)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 91.059  SIGNS AND ADVERTISING.



   No signs indicating that a lot or vault is for sale and no sign, card
or advertisement of any stonecutter, undertaker or other person shall be
permitted in the cemetery.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.100)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 91.060  ENCLOSURES, CURBING, ORNAMENTS, WALKS AND THE LIKE.



   Enclosures of any kind, curbing or coping around a lot, ornaments,
chairs, settees, vases, glass jars, pitchers, artificial flowers, flowers,
toys, watering cans or other articles that may be considered inappropriate
are prohibited in the cemetery, and the right to remove the same without
notice to lot owners is reserved. Objects of wood of any kind will not be
permitted in the cemetery, and no gravel, brick, stone, cement or other kind
of artificial walk will be allowed on any lot, except by permission of the
cemetery caretaker.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.101)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 91.061  BOUNDARY MARKERS.



   All boundary markers set up in the cemetery by the city must remain
undisturbed.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.102)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 91.062  MARKER PLANS.



   Plans for markers must be submitted to the city to secure permission
for erection in the cemetery.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.103)



§ 91.063  MAUSOLEUMS, VAULTS.



   No mausoleums, vaults or tombs above ground shall be allowed within the
cemeteries, except in accordance with the rules and regulations adopted by
the City Council.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.104)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 91.064  LOUD CONVERSATION PROHIBITED; WORKERS TO CEASE OPERATIONS DURING
INTERMENT.



   Loud conversation in the cemetery shall not be permitted, and all
workers must cease operations while in the immediate vicinity of an interment.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.105)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 91.065  ARTICLES PLACED ON LOTS OR GRAVES.



   The city shall not be responsible for any funeral design, floral piece
or other article or thing placed on any lot or grave in the cemetery.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.106)



§ 91.066  RIGHT TO REMOVE AND PLANT TREES AND SHRUBS AND MOW GRASS.



   If any trees or shrubs situated on any cemetery lot shall, by means of
their roots or branches, become detrimental to the adjacent lots or avenues,
or become unsightly or inconvenient for visitors, it shall be the duty of the
cemetery caretaker, and he or she shall have the right to enter the lot for
such purpose, to remove the trees or shrubbery or such part thereof as he or
she shall determine to be detrimental, unsightly or inconvenient. The
cemetery caretaker shall have the right to remove any trees or shrubs that
may be infected by scales or other diseases and to plant and mow the grass on
all lots and graves.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.107)



§ 91.067  REMOVAL OF FUNERAL DESIGNS AND FLORAL PIECES.



   Funeral designs and floral pieces will be removed from the graves when
they become wilted or unsightly. Persons desiring to retain any such design
or piece must remove the same within 48 hours after the interment. In no case
will employees attempt to locate designs or floral pieces after their removal
from the lots.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.108)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 91.068  RIGHT TO FILL AND LEVEL GRAVES, PLANT GRASS THEREON.



   The cemetery caretaker shall have full right to fill and level graves
and plant grass thereon, when desired.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.109)



§ 91.069  USE OF CITY’S TOOLS, LUMBER AND THE LIKE.



   The use of cemetery tools, lumber or other material belonging to the
city by any person not an employee of the city shall not be allowed.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.110)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 91.070  RESTRICTIONS ON BRINGING MARKER WORK, GRANITE AND THE LIKE INTO
GROUNDS.



   (A)   Marker work or any other material shall not be brought into
the cemetery when the ground is not in a suitable condition, or when the
proper foundation has not been prepared.



   (B)   Masons and stonecutters will not be permitted to bring into
the grounds of the cemetery material in large quantities in advance of its
immediate use, nor in any unprepared condition. Blocks of granite or marble
must be dressed to the design and dimensions ready for setting and lime must
be slacked and mortar prepared and brought to the grounds in moderate supply,
and all chips, pruning and rubbish must be gathered up and carried to places
of deposit as required by the cemetery caretaker.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.111)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 91.071  BRINGING HEAVY LOADS INTO GROUNDS.



   The cemetery caretaker must in all cases be consulted before any heavy
load shall enter the cemetery grounds.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.112)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 91.072  GUY ROPES FASTENED TO TREES OR SHRUBS.



   Guy ropes must not be fastened to any trees or shrubs in the cemetery.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.113)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 91.073  MATERIAL TO BE MOVED ON PATHS OR PLANKS.



   All materials must be moved on the paths of the cemetery and over
planks laid for the purpose, and not over adjoining lots.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.114)



§ 91.074  RIGHT TO PROHIBIT ERECTION OF MARKERS AND MONUMENTS.



   The City Council reserves the right to prohibit the erection in the
cemetery of any marker or other monumental work that may be considered by the
members of the Council to be inappropriate, whether in material, design,
workmanship or location, or which might interfere with the general effect or
obstruct any principal view.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.115)



§ 91.075  REMOVAL OF OFFENSIVE MONUMENTS, VAULTS AND THE LIKE.



   If any monument, vault, effigy or any structure whatever is placed in
or upon any cemetery lot which is determined by the cemetery caretaker to be
offensive, improper or injurious to the appearance of the surrounding lots or
grounds, he or she shall have the right, and it shall be his or her duty, to
enter upon such lot and remove the offensive or improper object and he or she
may do so without notice to the owner.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.116)



§ 91.076  RESPONSIBILITY OF FUNERAL DIRECTORS FOR CONDUCT OF EMPLOYEES.



   Funeral directors shall be held responsible for the actions of all
vehicle drivers or others employed by them while within the grounds of the
cemetery.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.117)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 91.077  DESTRUCTION, REMOVAL OF CEMETERY PROPERTY.



   Any person who shall wrongfully destroy, mutilate, deface, injure or
remove any tomb, monument, gravestone or other structure in any cemetery or
other place of burial, or any fence, railing or curb for the protection of
such structure, or any enclosure for any such place of burial, or wrongfully
injure, cut, remove or destroy any tree, shrub or plant growing within any
such enclosure, shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this chapter.



(Prior Code, § 1.07.118)  Penalty, see § 10.99

FIRE MARSHAL




§ 92.01  OFFICE CREATED, INDEPENDENT OF OTHER DEPARTMENTS.



   The Office of Fire Marshal is hereby created, and such office shall be
independent of other city departments, the Fire Marshal reporting directly to
the City Manager.



(Prior Code, § 5.02.001)



§ 92.02  APPOINTMENT, QUALIFICATIONS, REMOVAL AND COMPENSATION.



   The Fire Marshal shall be appointed by the City Manager. The Fire
Marshal shall be properly qualified for the duties of his or her office, and
shall be subject to removal at all times and for any reason. He or she shall
receive such compensation as provided for by the City Council.



(Prior Code, § 5.02.002)



§ 92.03  DUTY TO INVESTIGATE FIRES.



   The Fire Marshal shall investigate the cause, origin and circumstances
of every fire occurring within this city by which property has been destroyed
or damaged, and shall especially make investigation as to whether such fire
was the result of carelessness or design. Such investigation shall be
commenced within 24 hours, not including Sunday, of the occurrence of such
fire.



(Prior Code, § 5.02.003)



§ 92.04  TAKING OF TESTIMONY GENERALLY.



   The Fire Marshal, when in his or her opinion further investigation is
necessary, shall make or cause to be taken the testimony, on oath, of all
persons supposed to be cognizant of any facts or to have means of knowledge
in relation to the matter under investigation, and shall cause the same to be
reduced to writing.



(Prior Code, § 5.02.004)



§ 92.05  AUTHORITY TO SUMMON WITNESSES, REQUIRE PRODUCTION OF EVIDENCE AND
ADMINISTER OATHS.



   The Fire Marshal shall have the power to summon witnesses before him or
her to testify in relation to any matter which is, by the provisions of this
subchapter, a subject of inquiry and investigation, and may require the
production of any book, paper or document deemed pertinent thereto. The Fire
Marshal is hereby authorized and empowered to administer oaths and
affirmations to any persons appearing before him or her as witnesses.



(Prior Code, § 5.02.005)



§ 92.06  INVESTIGATIONS MAY BE PRIVATE; SEPARATION OF WITNESSES.



   All investigations held by or under the direction of the Fire Marshal
may, in his or her discretion, be private, and persons other than those
required to be present may be excluded from the place where such
investigation is held, and witnesses may be kept separate and apart from each
other and not allowed to communicate with each other until they have been
examined.



(Prior Code, § 5.02.006)



§ 92.07  DUTY WHEN EVIDENCE INDICATES CRIME IN CONNECTION WITH FIRE.



   If the Fire Marshal shall be of the opinion that there is evidence
sufficient to charge any person with the crime of arson, or with the attempt
to commit the crime of arson, or of conspiracy to defraud or criminal conduct
in connection with any fire, he or she shall cause such person to be lawfully
arrested and charged with such offense or either of them, and shall furnish
to the proper prosecuting attorney all such evidence, together with the names
of witnesses and all the information obtained by him or her, including a copy
of all pertinent and material testimony taken in the case.



(Prior Code, § 5.02.007)



§ 92.08  MISCONDUCT OF WITNESSES SUMMONED BY FIRE MARSHAL.



   Any witness who refuses to be sworn, or who refuses to appear or
testify, or who disobeys any lawful order of the Fire Marshal or who fails or
refuses to produce any book, paper or document touching any matter under
examination, or who is guilty of any contemptuous conduct during any of the
proceedings of the Fire Marshal in the matter of such investigation or
inquiry, after being summoned to give testimony in relation to any matter
under investigation, shall be deemed guilty of a violation, and it shall be
the duty of the Fire Marshal to cause all such offenders to be prosecuted.



(Prior Code, § 5.02.008)



§ 92.09  RIGHT OF ENTRY.



   The Fire Marshal shall have the authority, at all times of the day or
night, when necessary in the performance of the duties imposed upon him or
her by the provisions of this subchapter, to enter upon and examine any
building or premises where any fire has occurred, and other buildings and
premises adjoining or near the same, which authority shall be exercised only
with reason and good discretion.



(Prior Code, § 5.02.009)



§ 92.10  INSPECTION OF PREMISES; ORDERING REMOVAL OR REPAIR OF DANGEROUS
CONDITIONS.



   (A)   The Fire Marshal, upon the complaint of any person having an
interest in any building or property adjacent thereto, or without any
complaint, shall have the right at all reasonable hours, for the purpose of
examination, to enter into and upon all buildings and premises within the
city, and it shall be his or her duty to enter upon and make or cause to be
entered upon and made a thorough examination of all mercantile, manufacturing
and public buildings together with the premises belonging thereto.



   (B)   Whenever he or she shall find any building or other structure
which is especially liable to fire, and which is so situated as to endanger
other buildings or property, or so occupied that the fire would endanger
persons or property therein, and whenever he or she shall find an improper or
dangerous arrangement of stoves, ranges, furnaces or other heating appliances
of any kind whatsoever, including chimneys, flues and pipes with which the
same may be connected, or a dangerous arrangement of lighting devices or
electrical wiring or a dangerous or unlawful storage of explosives,
compounds, petroleum, gasoline, kerosene, dangerous chemicals, vegetable
products, ashes, combustible, inflammable refuse materials, wastepaper, rags
or other conditions which may be dangerous in character or liable to cause or
promote fire or create conditions dangerous to firefighters combating a fire
or to occupants, he or she shall order the same to be removed or remedied,
and such order shall be forthwith complied with by the owner or occupant of
the building or premises.



   (C)   If the owner or occupant deems himself or herself aggrieved by
such order, he or she may, within 15 days, appeal such order to the City
Council, which shall investigate the cause of the complaint and, unless such
order is revoked by the City Council, such order shall remain in force and be
forthwith complied with by such owner or occupant. Except in case of
emergency, any owner or occupant who fails to comply with such order within a
ten-day period from the date of such notice shall be deemed guilty of a
violation of this code.



(Prior Code, § 5.02.010)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 92.11  RECORD OF FIRES TO BE KEPT.



   The Fire Marshal shall keep in his or her office a record of all fires,
together with all facts, statistics and circumstances, including the origin
of the fires and the amounts of the loss, which may be determined by the
investigation required by this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 5.02.011)



§ 92.12  MONTHLY REPORT.



   At the end of each month, the Fire Marshal shall report to the State
Fire Marshal all existing hazardous conditions, together with a separate
report on each fire in the city during the month.



(Prior Code, § 5.02.012)




FIRE PREVENTION CODE




§ 92.25  ADOPTION.



   A certain document, three copies of which are on file in the office of
the City Secretary, being marked and designated as the International Fire
Code, 2012 edition, including Appendix B, C, D, E, F, G and H, as published
by the International Code Council, be and is hereby adopted as the Fire Code
of the city, for regulating and governing the safeguarding of life and
property from fire and explosion hazards arising from the storage, handling
and use of hazardous substances, materials and devices, and from conditions
hazardous to life or property in the occupancy of buildings and premises as
herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees
therefor; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties,
conditions and terms of said Fire Code on file in the office of the city are
hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in
this chapter, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any,
prescribed in § 92.26.



(Prior Code, § 5.03.001)  (Ord. 06-02-14, passed 2-14-2006; Ord. 13-12-01,
passed 12-10-2013)



§ 92.26  AMENDMENTS.



   The following sections of the International Fire Code are hereby
revised:



   (A)   Section 101.1. Insert: City of Henderson;



   (B)   Section 109.3. Insert: Class C misdemeanor, $2,000; and



   (C)   Section 111.4. Insert: $100 and $2,000.



(Prior Code, § 5.03.002)  (Ord. 06-02-14, passed 2-14-2006)



§ 92.27  GEOGRAPHIC LIMITS.



   The geographic limits referred to in certain sections of the 2012
International Fire Code are hereby established as follows.



   (A)   Section 5504.3-1.1.3: Storage of flammable cryogenic fluids in
stationary containers is prohibited in the City of Henderson, Texas, except
in Zoning Districts I-1 and I-2.



   (B)   Section 5704.2.9.6.1: Storage of Class I and II liquids in
above-ground tanks outside of buildings is prohibited in the City of
Henderson, Texas, except in Zoning Districts I-1, I-2, C-3 and RE.



   (C)   Section 6104.2: Storage of liquefied petroleum gas is
prohibited in the City of Henderson, Texas, except in Zoning Districts I-1
and I-2.



(Prior Code, § 5.03.003)  (Ord. 06-02-14, passed 2-14-2006; Ord. 13-12-01,
passed 12-10-2013)



§ 92.28  RESPONSIBLE OFFICIAL.



   Within such code, when reference is made to the duties of certain
officials named therein, the designated official of the city who has duties
corresponding to those of the named officials in such code shall be deemed to
be the responsible official insofar as enforcing the provisions of such code
is concerned.



(Prior Code, § 5.03.004)



§ 92.29  CONFLICTS.



   In the event of any conflict between the provisions of the code adopted
by this subchapter and the provisions of this code of ordinances, state law
or city ordinances, rules or regulations, the provisions of this code of
ordinances, state law or city ordinances, rules or regulations shall prevail
and be controlling.



(Prior Code, § 5.03.005)



§ 92.30  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   (A)   Wherever the word “municipality” is used in the Fire
Prevention Code, it shall be held to mean the City of Henderson.



   (B)   Wherever the term “corporation counsel” is used in the
Fire Prevention Code, it shall be held to mean the City Attorney.



   (C)   Wherever the words “Chief of the Bureau of Fire
Prevention” are used in the Fire Prevention Code, they shall be held to
mean the Fire Marshal.



(Prior Code, § 5.03.006)



§ 92.31  ENFORCEMENT OF CODE.



   (A)   The Fire Prevention Code shall be enforced by the Fire Marshal.



   (B)   The Fire Marshal may appoint such inspectors as shall from
time to time be necessary to enforce the provisions of such code and the
provisions of this chapter.



(Prior Code, § 5.03.007)



§ 92.32  MODIFICATIONS.



   (A)   The Fire Marshal shall have power to modify any of the
provisions of the Fire Prevention Code upon application in writing by the
owner or lessee, or his or her duly authorized agent, when there are
practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the
code, provided that the spirit of the code shall be observed, public safety
secured and substantial justice done.



   (B)   The particulars of such modification when granted or allowed
and the decision of the Fire Marshal thereon shall be entered upon the
records of the Department, and a signed copy shall be furnished the applicant.



(Prior Code, § 5.03.008)



§ 92.33  APPEALS.



   Whenever the Fire Marshal shall disapprove an application or refuse to
grant a permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the
code do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the code have been
misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal from the
decision of the Fire Marshal to the City Council within 15 days from the date
of the decision appealed.



(Prior Code, § 5.03.009)




OUTDOOR BURNING




§ 92.45  RESTRICTED.



   No person, corporation or other entity may cause or permit any outdoor
burning within the city limits unless such outdoor burning is carried out in
accordance with the regulations of the State Commission on Environmental
Quality.



(Prior Code, § 5.04.001)  Penalty, see § 10.99




FIRE PREVENTION INSPECTION; HISTORIC DISTRICT




§ 92.60  REQUIREMENT OF FIRE MARSHAL INSPECTION.



   Any building located in the historic district of the city that remains
vacant for at least three consecutive months shall be inspected by the Fire
Marshal, or his or her designee, of the city, during the subsequent (or
fourth) month of such vacancy to determine if there are any conditions which
need to be abated to reduce the risk of fire beginning or spreading. Such
inspections shall continue on a regular basis every three months thereafter
until such building is no longer vacant.



(Prior Code, § 5.05.031)



§ 92.61  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   BUILDING.  Any structure or portion of a structure used or intended
for supporting or sheltering any use or occupancy, and includes an enclosed
building, open building and partially open building.



   OWNER.  The owner(s) of record in the county where the real property
is situated, or his or her heirs or his or her devisees or an executor(s), an
administrator(s), a trustee(s) or other person(s) with ownership rights. Any
person who is included in the definition as an OWNER has joint and several
obligations for compliance with the provisions of this subchapter.



   VACANT BUILDING.  A building which is not used as a business (or
residence) where the owner or his or her lessee conducts legitimate business
with the public at least four days a week, maintains offices which are used
at least four days a week, or maintains said building as the primary
residence of the occupant thereof (where permitted by ordinance), and in
which electric and/or gas utilities and water and sewer utilities are not
maintained without interruption of five consecutive days. In other words, it
is not sufficient to keep a building from being labeled as a VACANT BUILDING
by using it three days or less each week as specified above or using it
solely for storage.



(Prior Code, § 5.05.032)



§ 92.62  OWNER’S PRESENCE REQUIRED.



   An owner of any such vacant building or his or her designee is required
to be present with the Fire Marshal, or his or her designee, for such
inspection. If the owner’s or his or her designee’s presence cannot be
obtained for such inspection, after notice by certified mail, return receipt
requested, by the Fire Marshal, the Fire Marshal may then get an order from
the Municipal Court for forced entry into the building upon a showing to the
court the efforts he or she has made to contact the owner(s).



(Prior Code, § 5.05.033)



§ 92.63  FEES.



   (A)   The owner(s) of any such vacant building shall pay a fee as
provided in § 35.40 to the city for each such inspection.



   (B)   This fee is a joint and several liability of each owner of the
building, but shall not exceed $100 per building.



   (C)   Failure to pay such fees can result in a lien being attached
to the subject building by the municipal court.



(Prior Code, § 5.05.034)  (Ord. 08-09-05, passed 9-9-2008)
