FOOD AND FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS, GENERALLY




§ 93.001  SANITARY MAINTENANCE OF PREMISES WHEREIN FOOD IS SOLD.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or carry on any business
for the sale of food or food products in any manner, wherein the premises for
the operation of such business are not at all times kept in a clean and
sanitary condition.



(Prior Code, § 6.02.001)  Penalty, see § 93.999




RESTAURANTS AND FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENTS




§ 93.015  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   APPROVED.  Complying with all applicable state laws and city
ordinances.



   CATERER.  A business delivering food ready to eat away from the
premises of the business.



   FAST-FOOD ESTABLISHMENT.  A business preparing food for consumption on
or off the premises, featuring fast or convenient service.



   FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENT.  Any business involved in the preparation,
distribution or sale of food for human consumption, including, but not
limited to, grocery stores, bars, soft drink stands, drugstores, soda
fountains or meat markets.



   RESTAURANT. Any place where food or drink, other than alcoholic
beverages, is served to the public for consumption on the premises, and any
caterer, fast-food establishment or cafeteria.



(Prior Code, § 6.02.031)



§ 93.016  CERTIFIED FOOD MANAGER.



   (A)   During operating hours, each restaurant, food service
establishment, fast-food establishment and caterer is required to have at
least one person present who is in charge and who has satisfactorily
completed and passed the state-approved certified food management course
pursuant to the requirements of the Department of State Health Services,
Retail Foods Division.



   (B)   The certificate issued by the Department of State Health
Services, showing successful completion of such course must be displayed in
such establishment in a place to which all customers of such establishment
have access.



   (C)   All such establishments must be in compliance with this
section on or before January 1, 2009.



(Prior Code, § 6.02.033)  (Ord. 07-12-23, passed 12-19-2007)



§ 93.017  LICENSE.



   (A)   Required. It shall be unlawful to operate any restaurant,
fast-food establishment, catering service or other food service business
engaged in the preparation, distribution or sale of food for human
consumption in the city without complying with the terms of this subchapter
and obtaining a license therefor.



(Prior Code, § 6.02.061)



   (B)   Exemptions. Specifically exempted from the requirements of
this section are charitable organizations or groups that do not prepare,
distribute or sell food for human consumption on a regular basis.



(Prior Code, § 6.02.062)



   (C)   Religious, nonprofit, charitable organizations. Public
schools, churches and other religious organizations and other nonprofit and
charitable organizations are required to comply with each provision contained
in this subchapter, except that no fee shall be charged or collected from
such organizations for the license required by this section.



(Prior Code, § 6.02.063)



   (D)   Application generally. Application for licenses required by
this section shall be made to the City Health Inspector on a form to be
furnished by the Inspector, and the applicant shall comply with all
applicable provisions of law on licenses.



(Prior Code, § 6.02.064)



   (E)   Fee. The annual fee for licenses required by this section
shall be determined by the City Manager, which fee, or fee schedule, as the
case might be, shall be on file in the offices of the City Secretary and the
City Health Inspector.



(Prior Code, § 6.02.065)



   (F)   Investigation of premises. All applications for a license to
conduct a restaurant or food service establishment shall be referred to the
Health Inspector, who shall make or cause to be made an investigation of the
premises to be used, and report his or her finding thereon, recommending or
advising against the issuance of the license.



(Prior Code, § 6.02.066)



   (G)   Duration. Licenses issued under the authority of this section
shall remain effective for a period of one year from the date of issuance,
unless revoked by the Health Inspector for violation of any provision of this
subchapter prior to the normal expiration date.



(Prior Code, § 6.02.067)



   (H)   Revocation; grounds. Any license issued under this section may
be revoked by the City Health Inspector for repeated violation of the
provisions herein, or for any violation of any other ordinance provision
relating to the conduct of the business, the condition of the premises, the
articles sold or to the license required.



(Prior Code, § 6.02.068)



   (I)   Appeal; public hearing; notice.



      (1)   The owner or operator of any restaurant or food service
establishment from which the required license has been revoked shall have the
right to a public hearing before the City Judge upon written notice to the
City Health Inspector within seven days of the revocation.



      (2)   Both the city and any aggrieved owner or operator shall
have the right to appeal the decision of the City Judge directly to the
District Court of the county.



(Prior Code, § 6.02.069)



(Ord. 12-04-04, passed 4-17-2012)  Penalty, see § 93.999



§ 93.018  HEALTH REGULATIONS.



   (A)   Wholesomeness of food and drink.



      (1)   Generally. All food and drink shall be clean, wholesome,
free from spoilage, and so prepared as to be safe for human consumption. All
milk, fluid milk products, ice cream and other frozen desserts served shall
be from approved sources. Milk and fluid milk products shall be served in the
individual containers in which they were received from the distributor or
from a bulk container equipped with an approved dispensing device; provided,
that this requirement shall not apply to cream, which may be served from the
original bottle or from a dispenser approved for such service. All oysters,
clams and mussels shall be from approved sources, and if shucked, shall be
kept until used in the containers in which they were placed at the shucking
plant.



      (2)   Unwholesome food. No person shall offer for sale, or
keep for the purpose of selling or offering for sale, any food of any kind
intended for human consumption which is spoiled or tainted or is unwholesome
and unfit for human consumption for any reason.



      (3)   Examination and condemnation of unwholesome or
adulterated food or drink. Samples of food, drink and other substances may be
taken and examined by the Health Inspector as often as necessary for the
detection of unwholesomeness or adulteration. The Health Inspector may
condemn and forbid the sale of, or cause to be removed or destroyed, any food
or drink which is unwholesome or adulterated.



(Prior Code, § 6.02.101)



   (B)   Storage, display and serving of food and drink.



      (1)   Generally. All food and drink shall be so stored,
displayed and served as to be protected from dust, flies, vermin, depredation
and pollution by rodents, unnecessary handling, droplet infection, overhead
leakage and other contamination. No animals or fowl shall be kept or allowed
in any room in which food or drink is prepared or stored. All means necessary
for the elimination of flies, roaches and rodents shall be used.



      (2)   Refrigeration. All readily perishable food and drink
shall be kept at or below 50°F, except when being prepared or served.
Wastewater from refrigeration equipment shall be properly disposed of.



(Prior Code, § 6.02.102)



   (C)   Employees.



      (1)   Cleanliness. All persons engaged in handling or coming
in contact with food intended for sale for human consumption shall keep
themselves clean, both as to person and clothing. It shall be unlawful for
any restaurant or food service establishment to permit any person who is not
clean to be employed in or about any premises where food is stored, prepared
or sold, or to deliver such food.



      (2)   Infectious diseases. It shall be unlawful for any person
who is afflicted with or is a carrier of any infectious disease to handle or
be engaged in the care or preparation of any such food, and it shall be
unlawful to permit any such person to be employed in or about any premises
where food is stored, prepared or sold, or to deliver such food.



(Prior Code, § 6.02.103)



   (D)   Inspections.



      (1)   Generally.



         (a)   At least every six months, the Health Inspector
shall inspect every food service establishment and restaurant located within
the city.



         (b)   In case the Health Inspector discovers the
violation of any item of sanitation, he or she shall make a second inspection
after the lapse of such time as he or she deems necessary for the defect to
be remedied, and the second inspection shall be used in determining
compliance with the requirements of this subchapter.



      (2)   Copies of inspection report. One copy of the inspection
report shall be given to the manager of the restaurant or food service
establishment on duty at the time of the inspection. Another copy of the
inspection report shall be filed with the records of the Health Inspector.



      (3)   Access to establishment and records. The person
operating any food service establishment or restaurant shall, upon request of
the Health Inspector, permit access to all parts of the establishment and
shall permit copying of any and all records of food purchased.



(Prior Code, § 6.02.104)



   (E)   Utensils and equipment.



      (1)   Construction. All multi-use utensils and all show and
display cases or windows, counters, shelves, tables, refrigerating equipment,
sinks and other equipment or utensils used in connection with the operation
of a restaurant shall be constructed as to be easily cleaned and shall be
kept in good repair. Utensils containing or plated with cadmium or lead shall
not be used, provided that solder containing lead may be used for jointing.



      (2)   Cleaning and bactericidal treatment.



         (a)   All equipment, including display cases or windows,
counters, shelves, tables, refrigerators, stoves, hoods and sinks, shall be
kept clean and free from dust, dirt, insects and other contaminating
material. All cloths used by waiters, chefs and other employees shall be
clean. Single-service containers shall be used only once.



         (b)   All multi-use eating and drinking utensils shall
be thoroughly cleaned and effectively subjected to an approved bactericidal
process after each usage. All multi-use utensils used in the preparation or
serving of food and drink shall be thoroughly cleaned and effectively
subjected to an approved process immediately following the day’s operation.
Drying cloths, if used, shall be kept clean and shall be used for no other
purpose.



         (c)   No article, polish or other substance containing
any cyanide preparation or other poisonous material shall be used for the
cleaning or polishing of utensils.



      (3)   Storage and handling. After bactericidal treatment,
utensils shall be stored in a clean, dry place protected from flies, dust and
other contamination, and shall be handled in such a manner as to prevent
contamination as far as practicable. Single-service utensils shall be
purchased only in containers; shall be stored therein in a clean, dry place
until used; and shall be handled in a sanitary manner.



(Prior Code, § 6.02.105)



   (F)   Toilet and lavatory facilities.



      (1)   Every restaurant and food service establishment shall be
provided with adequate and conveniently located toilet facilities for its
employees, conforming with the ordinances of the city. In restaurants
constructed, toilet rooms shall not be open directly into any room in which
food, drink or utensils are handled or stored. The doors of all toilet rooms
shall be self-closing. Toilet rooms shall be kept in a clean condition, in
good repair, and well lighted and ventilated. Handwashing signs shall be
posted in each toilet room used by employees.



      (2)   Adequate and convenient handwashing facilities shall be
provided, including hot and cold running water, soap and approved sanitary
towels. The use of a common towel is prohibited. No employee shall resume
work after using the toilet room without first washing his or her hands.



(Prior Code, § 6.02.106)



   (G)   Water supply. Running water under pressure shall be easily
accessible to all rooms in which food is prepared or utensils are washed, and
the water supply shall be adequate, and of a safe, sanitary quality.



(Prior Code, § 6.02.107)



   (H)   Disposal of wastes. All wastes shall be properly disposed of,
and all garbage and trash shall be kept in suitable receptacles, in such
manner as not to become a nuisance.



(Prior Code, § 6.02.108)



   (I)   Handwashing; gloves.



      (1)   No person working in a restaurant, a food service
establishment, a fast-food establishment or as a caterer shall touch uncooked
or ready-to-eat foods with their bare hands, but must use a clean utensil
such as a tong or deli tissue or single-use disposable gloves when touching
such uncooked or ready-to-eat foods.



      (2)   Handwashing, as provided for elsewhere in this section,
is required even though disposable gloves are worn.



(Prior Code, § 6.02.110)



(Ord. 07-12-23, passed 12-19-2007)  Penalty, see § 93.999



§ 93.019  FOOD SERVICE SANITATION.



   (A)   The Texas Food Establishment Rules of the Department of State
Health Services, as amended from time to time, are hereby adopted in their
entirety for purposes of regulation of food service and food service
establishments located within the city. The City Secretary shall maintain a
current version of the state rules on file in the offices of the City
Secretary.



   (B)   All food service and food service establishments located
within the city shall comply with the requirements of the state rules, as
amended from time to time.



   (C)   The City Building Official and the City Health Officer shall
enforce the state rules adopted herein.



   (D)   All persons, firms and corporations found to be in violation
of any provision of the state rules adopted hereby shall be punished as
described in § 10.99.



(Prior Code, § 6.02.141)  (Ord. 99-3-5, passed 4-13-1999)




UNSANITARY, UNSIGHTLY CONDITIONS ON PRIVATE PREMISES




§ 93.030  STAGNANT WATER.



   It shall be unlawful for the owner of any lot or other premises in the
city to allow or permit holes or places where water may accumulate and become
stagnant to be or remain on such lot or premises or to allow or permit the
accumulation of stagnant water thereon, or to permit the same to remain
thereon.



(Prior Code, § 6.03.001)  Penalty, see § 93.999



Statutory reference:



   Municipal power concerning stagnant water and other unsanitary
conditions, see Tex. Health and Safety Code, §§ 342.001, 342.005 et seq.



§ 93.031  ACCUMULATION OF CARRION, FILTH AND THE LIKE.



   It shall be unlawful for the owner of any lot, building, house,
establishment or premises in the city to allow or permit any carrion, filth
or any other impure or unwholesome matter of any kind to accumulate or remain
thereon.



(Prior Code, § 6.03.002)  Penalty, see § 93.999



Statutory reference:



   Municipal power concerning filth, carrion and other unwholesome matter,
see Tex. Health and Safety Code, §§ 342.003, 342.005 et seq.



§ 93.032  GROWTH OR ACCUMULATION OF WEEDS, RUBBISH AND THE LIKE.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person owning, leasing, claiming,
occupying or having supervision and control of any real property within the
limits of the city, to allow:



      (1)   On developed property (including, but not limited to,
any right-of-way, easement or drainage ditch), any weeds, grass or brush in
excess of 12 inches in height to grow uncultivated;



      (2)   On undeveloped property (including, but not limited to,
any right-of-way, easement or drainage ditch), any weeds, grass or brush in
excess of 12 inches in height to grow uncultivated within ten feet of the
edge of any improved roadway or public street within the limits of the city;
or



      (3)   On any lot or tract of land within the city, regardless
of the size of said lot or tract of land (whether developed or undeveloped,
commercial or residential, occupied or unoccupied), to accumulate or remain
any refuse, rubbish, junk, litter, trash, debris (including, but not limited
to, vegetative and building debris), garbage, discarded items, carrion,
filth, animal or human feces, or any other objectionable, unsightly or
unsanitary matter of whatever nature.



   (B)   (1)   For purposes of this section, the term DEVELOPED
PROPERTY shall mean any lot or tract of land which meets any of the following
criteria:



         (a)   Any structure or paving currently exists or has
previously existed on the lot or tract of land; or



         (b)   Any grading, mining, drilling, dredging, filling
or excavation has taken place on the lot or tract of land.



      (2)   Clearing of trees or vegetation from a lot or tract of
land shall not, by itself, be construed to render the affected lot or tract
of land DEVELOPED PROPERTY within the meaning of this section.



   (C)   For the purposes of this section, the term UNDEVELOPED
PROPERTY shall mean any lot or tract of land which is not developed property
as defined in division (B) above.



   (D)   For purposes of this section, the term OBJECTIONABLE,
UNSIGHTLY OR UNSANITARY MATTER shall mean any matter, condition or object
which is or should be objectionable, unsightly or unsanitary to a person of
ordinary sensitivities.



(Prior Code, § 6.03.003)  (Ord. 01-10-23, passed 10-23-2001)  Penalty, see
§ 93.999



Statutory reference:



   Authority of municipality to regulate weeds, grass and the like, see
Tex. Health and Safety Code, §§ 342.004 et seq.



   Local regulation of sanitation, see Tex. Health and Safety Code, Ch. 342



§ 93.033  NOTICE TO OWNER TO REMEDY OR REMOVE CONDITION, GENERALLY.



   Whenever any condition described in this subchapter is found to exist
on any premises within the city, the owner of such premises shall be notified
by the city, in writing, to correct, remedy or remove the condition within
seven days after such notice. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to
comply with such notice.



(Prior Code, § 6.03.004)  Penalty, see § 93.999



§ 93.034  NOTICE; FAILURE TO REMOVE OR REMEDY CONDITIONS.



   (A)   (1)   If any person owning, claiming, occupying or having
supervision or control of any real property, occupied or unoccupied, within
the corporate limits of the city fails to comply with the provisions of this
subchapter, it shall be the duty of the person designated by the City Manager
to give seven days’ notice in writing personally to the owner of the
property by letter addressed to the owner at the owner’s address as
recorded in the appraisal district records of the appraisal district in which
the property is located.



      (2)   If personal service cannot be obtained, it shall be the
duty of the person designated by the City Manager to give notice as follows:



         (a)   By publication at least once;



         (b)   By posting the notice on or near the front door of
each building on the property to which the violation relates; or



         (c)   By posting the notice on a placard attached to a
stake driven into the ground on the property to which the violation relates.



   (B)   In the notice herein provided for, the city shall have the
right to inform the owner by regular mail and a posting on the property that
if the owner commits another violation of the same kind or nature that poses
a danger to the public health and safety on or before the first anniversary
of the date of the notice, the city without further notice may correct the
violation at the owner’s expense and assess the expense against the
property.



(Prior Code, § 6.03.005)



§ 93.035  CORRECTION OR REMOVAL OF CONDITIONS BY CITY, GENERALLY.



   In the event the owner of any lot or premises upon which a condition
described in this subchapter exists fails to correct, remedy or remove such
condition after notice to do so is given in accord with this subchapter, the
city may do such work or make such improvements as are necessary to correct,
remedy or remove such condition, or cause the same to be done, and pay
therefor and charge the expenses incurred thereby to the owner of such lot.
Such expenses shall be assessed against the lot or real estate upon which the
work was done or the improvements made. The doing of such work by the city
shall not relieve such person from prosecution for failure to comply with
such notice in violation of § 93.033.



(Prior Code, § 6.03.006)



§ 93.036  FILING OF STATEMENT OF EXPENSES INCURRED.



   Whenever any work is done or improvements are made by the city under
the provisions of § 93.035, the Mayor or Health Officer, or other city
official designated by the Mayor on behalf of the city, shall file a
statement of the expenses incurred thereby with the County Clerk. Such
statement shall give the amount of such expenses and the date or dates on
which the work was done or the improvements were made.



(Prior Code, § 6.03.007)



§ 93.037  LIEN FOR AND COLLECTION OF EXPENSES.



   (A)   After the statement provided for in § 93.036 is filed, the
city shall have a privileged lien on the lot or real estate upon which the
work was done or improvement made, to secure the expenses thereof. Such lien
shall be second only to tax liens and liens for street improvements, and the
amount thereof shall bear interest at the rate of 10% per annum from the date
the statement was filed.



   (B)   For any such expenditures and interest, suit may be instituted
and recovery and foreclosure of the lien may be had in the name of the city
and the statement of expenses made in accord with § 93.036, or a certified
copy thereof, shall be prima facie proof of the amount expended for such work
or improvements.



(Prior Code, § 6.03.008)



§ 93.038  ADDITIONAL AUTHORITY TO ABATE DANGEROUS WEEDS.



   (A)   The city may abate, without notice, weeds that:



      (1)   Have grown higher than 48 inches; and



      (2)   Are an immediate danger to the health, life or safety of
any person.



   (B)   Not later than the tenth day after the date the city abates
weeds under this section, the city shall give notice to the property owner in
the manner required by Tex. Health and Safety Code, § 342.006.



   (C)   The notice shall contain:



      (1)   An identification, which is not required to be a legal
description, of the property;



      (2)   A description of the violations of the ordinance that
occurred on the property;



      (3)   A statement that the city abated the weeds; and



      (4)   An explanation of the property owner’s right to
request an administrative hearing about the city’s abatement of the weeds.



   (D)   The city shall conduct an administrative hearing on the
abatement of weeds under this section if, not later than the thirtieth day
after the date of the abatement of the weeds, the property owner files with
the city a written request for a hearing.



   (E)   An administrative hearing conducted under this section shall
be conducted not later than the twentieth day after the date a request for a
hearing is filed. The owner may testify or present any witnesses or written
information relating to the city’s abatement of the weeds.



   (F)   The city may assess expenses and create liens under this
section as it assesses expenses and creates liens under Tex. Health and
Safety Code, § 342.007. A lien created under this section is subject to the
same conditions as a lien created under Tex. Health and Safety Code, §
342.007.



   (G)   The authority granted the city by this section is in addition
to the authority granted by Tex. Health and Safety Code, § 342.006.



(Prior Code, § 6.03.009)



Statutory reference:



   Additional authority to abate dangerous weeds without notice, see Tex.
Health and Safety Code, § 342.008




SMOKING




§ 93.050  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   BAR. An enclosed indoor establishment that is open to the public and is
devoted primarily to the sale and service of alcoholic beverages for
on-premises consumption.



   BUSINESS.



      (1)   A sole proprietorship, partnership, joint venture,
corporation, or other business entity, either for-profit or not-for-profit,
including a retail establishment, where goods or services are sold;



      (2)   A professional corporation or other entity where legal,
medical, dental, engineering, architectural, or other professional services
are delivered; or



      (3)   A private club.



   EMPLOYEE. An individual who:



      (1)   Is employed by an employer for direct or indirect
monetary wages or profit; or



      (2)   Volunteers the individual's services for an employer.



   EMPLOYER. A person who employs one or more individuals or uses the
volunteer services of one or more individuals. The term includes:



      (1)   A nonprofit entity, and



      (2)   Any political subdivision of this state.



   ELECTRONIC SMOKING DEVICE. Any product containing or delivering
nicotine or any other substance intended for human consumption that can be
used by a person to simulate smoking through inhalation of vapor or aerosol
from the product. The term includes any such device, whether manufactured,
distributed, marketed, or sold as an e-cigarette, e-cigar, e-pipe, e-hookah,
or vape pen, or under any other product name or descriptor.



   ENCLOSED AREA. All space between a floor and ceiling that is bounded on
at least two sides by walls, doorways or windows, whether open or closed. A
wall includes any retractable divider, garage door, or other physical
barrier, whether temporary or permanent, and whether or not containing
openings of any kind.



   HEALTH CARE FACILITY. An office or institution in which care or
treatment is provided for physical, mental, or emotional diseases or other
medical, physiological, or psychological conditions.



   PLACE OF EMPLOYMENT. An area under the control of an employer that is
used by employees of the employer but is not generally open to the public.



   PRIVATE CLUB. An organization that:



      (1)   Owns, leases, or occupies a building used exclusively
for club purposes at all times;



      (2)   Is operated solely for a recreational, fraternal,
social, patriotic, political, benevolent, or athletic purpose, but not for
pecuniary gain;



      (3)   Sells alcoholic beverages only incidentally to its
operation;



      (4)   Is managed by a board of directors or similar body
chosen by the members at an annual meeting;



      (5)   Has established bylaws or a constitution to govern the
club's activities; and



      (6)   Is exempt from federal income taxation under § 501(a),
Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as a club described by § 501(c)(7) of that
code.



   PUBLIC PLACE.



      (1)   An enclosed indoor area the public is invited or
permitted to enter, including all or part of the following:



         (a)   A restaurant;



         (b)   A bar;



         (c)   A retail or service establishment;



         (d)   A facility of a business or nonprofit entity;



         (e)   A shopping mall;



         (f)   A convention facility;



         (g)   A theater or other facility primarily used for
exhibiting a performance;



         (h)   A sports arena;



         (i)   A health care facility;



         (j)   A licensed child-care or adult day-care facility;



         (k)   A room in which a public meeting under the control
of this state, an agency or branch of government of this state, or a
political subdivision of this state is in progress;



         (l)   A common area in a multiple-unit residential
facility;



         (m)   A public transportation facility, including a bus
or taxicab, and a ticket, boarding, or waiting area of a public
transportation depot;



         (n)   A waiting room, hallway, room, or ward in a health
care facility; or



         (o)   A restroom, lobby, reception area, service line,
hallway, elevator, or other common-use area the public is invited or
permitted to enter.



      (2)   A facility of the state or of a local government,
including a building or vehicle owned, leased, or operated by the state or
local government, regardless of whether the public is invited or permitted to
enter.



   RESTAURANT. An enclosed indoor establishment that is open to the public
and is devoted primarily to the sale and service of food for immediate
consumption. The term includes a bar located at the establishment.



   RETAIL or SERVICE ESTABLISHMENT. An establishment that sells goods or
services to the public.



   SERVICE LINE. An indoor line in which one or more persons wait for or
receive service, whether or not the service involves the exchange of money.



   SHOPPING MALL. An enclosed public walkway or hall area that connects
retail, service, or professional establishments.



   SMOKING. To inhale, exhale, burn, or carry a lighted cigar, cigarette,
pipe, tobacco product, electronic cigarette or e-cigarette or liquid nicotine
of any kind, which is burning or emitting a vapor or the exhalation of any
smoke or vapor produced from any cigar, cigarette, pipe, tobacco product,
electronic cigarette or e-cigarette, cigarette, pipe, or other smoking
equipment in any manner.



   SPORTS ARENA. A place in which a person engages in physical exercise,
participates in athletic competition, or witnesses sports or other events.



(Prior Code, § 6.04.001) (Ord. 16-11-14, passed 12-13-2016)



Statutory reference:



   Smoking tobacco in certain public places or conveyances, see Tex. Penal
Code, § 48.01



§ 93.051  PROHIBITED IN PUBLIC PLACES.



   Smoking shall be prohibited in all public places within the city,
including, but not limited to, the following places:



   (A)   Elevators;



   (B)   Restrooms, lobbies, reception areas, hallways and any other
common-use areas;



   (C)   Buses, bus terminals, taxicabs, and other facilities and means
of public transit under the authority of the city, as well as ticket,
boarding, and waiting areas of public transit depots;



   (D)   Service lines;



   (E)   Retail stores;



   (F)   Food establishments, nightclubs and bars;



   (G)   Galleries, libraries, and museums;



   (H)   Any facility which is primarily used for exhibiting any motion
picture, stage, drama, lecture, musical recital or other similar performance,
except that performers may smoke when the smoking is part of a stage
production;



   (I)   Sports arenas and convention halls, including bowling
facilities;



   (J)   Every room, chamber, place of meeting or public assembly,
including school buildings under the control of any board, council,
commission, committee, including joint committees, or agencies of the city or
any political subdivision of the state during such time as a public meeting
is in progress, to the extent such place is subject to the jurisdiction of
the city;



   (K)   Waiting rooms, hallways, wards and semi-private rooms of
health facilities, including, but not limited to, hospitals, clinics,
physical therapy facilities, doctors' offices, and dentists' offices;



   (L)   Lobbies, hallways, and other common areas in apartment
buildings, condominiums, trailer parks, retirement facilities, nursing homes,
and other multiple-unit residential facilities; and



   (M)   Polling places.



(Prior Code, § 6.04.002) (Ord. 16-11-14, passed 12-13-2016) Penalty, see §
93.999



§ 93.052  PROHIBITED IN PLACE OF EMPLOYMENT.



   (A)   A person may not smoke in a place of employment.



   (B)   It shall be the responsibility of employers to provide a
smoke-free workplace for all employees.



(Ord. 16-11-14, passed 12-13-2016)



§ 93.053  PROHIBITION OF SMOKING IN SEATING AREA AT AN OUTDOOR EVENT.



   A person may not smoke in:



   (A)   The seating area of an outdoor arena, stadium, or
amphitheater; or



   (B)   Bleachers or grandstands for use by spectators at a sporting
or other public event.



(Ord. 16-11-14, passed 12-13-2016)



§ 93.054  REASONABLE DISTANCE; EXCEPTIONS.



   (A)   A person may not smoke within a distance of 30 feet from a
primary public pedestrian entrance to or an operate window of an enclosed
area in which smoking is prohibited.



   (B)   Exceptions. A person may smoke within 30 feet of an entrance
of an enclosed area where smoking is prohibited if the entrance is not a
primary public pedestrian entrance to the premises.



(Ord. 16-11-14, passed 12-13-2016)



§ 93.055  EXCEPTIONS.



   This subchapter does not apply to:



   (A)   A private residence, except if used as a child-care, adult
day-care or health care facility;



   (B)   A hotel or motel room rented to a guest and designated as a
smoking room, if:



      (1)   Not more than 20% of rooms rented to guests in a hotel
or motel are designated as smoking rooms;



      (2)   All smoking rooms in the hotel or motel on the same
floor are contiguous; and



      (3)   Smoke from smoking rooms does not enter an area in which
smoking is prohibited;



   (C)   A private or semi-private room in a nursing home or long-term
care facility occupied by one or more persons, all of whom are smokers and
have requested in writing to be placed in a room where smoking is permitted,
provided that smoke from the room does not enter an area where smoking is
prohibited;



   (D)   Any and all correctional facilities located within the city
limits of the city, including the Rusk County Jail; or



   (E)   Outdoor places of employment except those covered by §§
93.053 and 93.054.



(Ord. 16-11-14, passed 12-13-2016)



§ 93.056  DECLARATION OF ESTABLISHMENT AS NONSMOKING.



   (A)   An owner, operator, manager, or other person in control of an
establishment, facility, or outdoor area may declare that entire
establishment, facility, or outdoor area as a nonsmoking place.



   (B)   A person may not smoke in a place in which a sign conforming
to the requirements of § 93.057 is posted.



(Ord. 16-11-14, passed 12-13-2016)



§ 93.057  POSTING OF SIGNS.



   (A)   The owner, manager or other person having control of such
building or other area where smoking is prohibited by this subchapter shall
have a conspicuously posted sign clearly stating that smoking is prohibited
at each entrance and within the building or other areas where smoking is
prohibited.



   (B)   Such “No Smoking" signs shall have bold lettering of not
less than 1-inch in height. The international "No Smoking" symbol may also be
used (consisting of a pictorial representation of a burning cigarette
enclosed in a red circle with red bar across it).



   (C)   All ashtrays and other smoking paraphernalia shall be limited
in facilities to that required for the enforcement of extinguishing of
smoking materials in public places.



(Ord. 16-11-14, passed 12-13-2016)



§ 93.058  ENFORCEMENT.



   (A)   Enforcement of this subchapter shall be implemented by the
planning and community development department, fire and law enforcement
agencies.



   (B)   Any owner, manager, operator or employee of any establishment
regulated by this chapter shall be responsible for enforcement.



(Ord. 16-11-14, passed 12-13-2016)



§ 93.059  RETALIATION PROHIBITED.



   No person or employee shall discharge, refuse to hire or in any manner
retaliate against any employee, applicant for employment or customer because
such employee, applicant or customer exercises any right to a smoke free
environment afforded by this subchapter.



(Ord. 16-11-14, passed 12-13-2016)




MOSQUITO CONTROL




§ 93.065  DEFINITION.



   For the purposes of this subchapter, COLLECTIONS OF WATER shall be
defined and held to be those contained in ditches, pools, ponds, excavations,
holes, depressions, open cesspools, privy vaults, fountains, cisterns, tanks,
shallow wells, barrels, troughs (except horse troughs in frequent use), urns,
cans, boxes, bottles, tubs, buckets, defective house roof gutters, tanks or
flush closets or other similar water containers.



(Prior Code, § 6.05.001)



§ 93.066  TREATMENT REQUIRED.



   It shall be unlawful to have, keep, maintain, cause or permit within
the city any collection of standing or flowing water in which mosquitoes
breed or are likely to breed, unless such collection of water is treated so
as effectually to prevent such breeding.



(Prior Code, § 6.05.002)  Penalty, see § 93.999



§ 93.067  METHODS OF TREATMENT.



   The method of treatment of any collections of water directed toward the
prevention of breeding of mosquitoes shall be approved by the accredited
Health Officer, and may be any one or more of the following:



   (A)   Screening with wire netting of at least 16 meshes to the inch
each way or with any other material which will effectually prevent the
ingress or egress of mosquitoes;



   (B)   Complete emptying every seven days of unscreened containers,
together with their thorough drying or cleaning;



   (C)   Using a larvicide approved and applied under the direction of
the Health Officer;



   (D)   Cleaning and keeping sufficiently free of vegetable growth and
other obstructions, and stocking with mosquito-destroying fish;



   (E)   Filling or draining to the satisfaction of the Health Officer;
and/or



   (F)   Proper disposal, by removal or destruction, of tin cans, tin
boxes, broken or empty bottles and similar articles likely to hold water.



(Prior Code, § 6.05.003)



§ 93.068  PRESENCE OF LARVAE.



   The natural presence of mosquito larvae in standing or running water
shall be evidence that mosquitoes are breeding therein, and failure to
prevent such breeding within three days after notice by the Health Officer
shall be deemed a violation of this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 6.05.004)



§ 93.069  FAILURE TO ABATE.



   Should the person responsible for conditions giving rise to the
breeding of mosquitoes fail or refuse to take necessary measures to prevent
the same within three days after due notice has been given to him or her, the
Health Officer is hereby authorized to do so, and all necessary cost incurred
by him or her for this purpose shall be a charge against the property owner
or other person offending, as the case may be.



(Prior Code, § 6.05.005)



§ 93.070  RIGHT OF ENTRY.



   For the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this subchapter, the
Health Officer, or his or her duly accredited agent, acting under his or her
authority, may at all reasonable times enter in and upon any premises within
his or her jurisdiction. Any person or persons charged with any of the duties
imposed by this subchapter failing within the time designated by this
subchapter, or within the time stated in the notice of the Health Officer, as
the case may be, to perform such duties, or to carry out the necessary
measures to the satisfaction of the Health Officer, shall be deemed guilty of
a separate violation of this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 6.05.006)  Penalty, see § 93.999




RODENT CONTROL




§ 93.085  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   BUSINESS BUILDING.  Any structure, whether public or private, that is
adopted for occupancy, for transaction or business, for rendering of
professional service, for amusement, for the display, sale or storage of
goods, wares, or merchandise, or for the performance of work or labor,
including hotels, apartment buildings, tenement houses, roominghouses, office
buildings, public buildings, stores, theaters, markets, restaurants, grain
elevators, abattoirs, warehouses, workshops, factories and all outhouses,
sheds, barns and other structures on premises used for business purposes.



   HEALTH OFFICER.  The Superintendent, Commissioner or Director of
Health or his or her duly authorized representative.



   OCCUPANT.  The individual, partnership or corporation that uses or
occupies any business building or part or fraction thereof, whether the
actual owner or tenant. In the case of vacant business buildings or vacant
portions thereof, the owner, agent or custodian shall have the responsibility
as OCCUPANT.



   OWNER.  The actual owner, agent or custodian of the business building,
whether individual, partnership or corporation. The lessee shall be construed
as the OWNER for the purpose of this subchapter when business building
agreements hold the lessee responsible for maintenance and repairs.



   RAT ERADICATION. The elimination or extermination of rats within
buildings or residences by any or all of the accepted measures, such as
poisoning, fumigation, trapping, clubbing and the like.



   RAT HARBORAGE.  Any condition which provides shelter or protection for
rats, thus favoring their multiplication and continued existence in, under or
outside of any structure.



   RAT-PROOFING.  A form of construction to prevent the ingress of rats
into business buildings or residences from the exterior or from one business
building, residence or other establishment to another. It consists
essentially of treatment with material, impervious to rat gnawing, all actual
or potential openings in exterior walls, ground or first floors, basements,
roof and foundations that may be reached by rats from the ground by climbing
or burrowing.



   RESIDENCE.  Any structure used by a person or persons for a dwelling
or used for storage or any other use incident to a dwelling, including all
portable and permanent structures and all single- and multiple-family
structures.



(Prior Code, § 6.06.001)



§ 93.086  RAT-PROOFING BUSINESS BUILDINGS AND RESIDENCES; REQUIRED.



   All business buildings and residences in the city shall be rat-proofed,
freed of rats and maintained in a rat-proof and rat-free condition to the
satisfaction of the Health Officer.



(Prior Code, § 6.06.002)



§ 93.087  NOTICE TO, COMPLIANCE BY OWNER.



   Upon receipt of written notice and/or order from the Health Officer,
the owner of any business building or residence specified herein shall take
immediate measures for rat-proofing the building, and unless such work and
improvements have been completed by the owner in the time specified in the
written notice, in no event to be less than 15 days, or within the time to
which a written extension may have been granted by the Health Officer, then
the owner shall be deemed guilty of an offense under the provisions of this
subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 6.06.003)



§ 93.088  NOTICE TO, COMPLIANCE BY OCCUPANT.



   Whenever the Health Officer notifies the occupant of a business
building or residence in writing that there is evidence of rat infestation of
the building, the occupant shall immediately institute rat eradication
measures and shall continuously maintain such measures in a satisfactory
manner until the premises is declared by the Health Officer to be free of rat
infestation. Unless such measures are undertaken within five days after
receipt of notice, it shall be construed as a violation of the provisions of
this subchapter and occupant shall be held responsible therefor.



(Prior Code, § 6.06.004)



§ 93.089  MAINTENANCE.



   The owners of all rat-proofed business buildings and residences shall
maintain the premises in a rat- proofed condition and repair all breaks or
leaks that may occur in the rat-proofing without a specific order of the
Health Officer.



(Prior Code, § 6.06.005)



§ 93.090  CLOSURE OF OCCUPIED BUILDINGS AND RESIDENCES.



   Whenever conditions inside or under any occupied business buildings or
residences within the city provide extensive harborage for rats in the
opinion of the Health Officer, the Health Officer is empowered, after due
notification in accordance with § 93.088, to close such business buildings
until such time as the conditions are abated by rat-proofing and harborage
removal including, if necessary, the installation of suitable concrete floors
in basements or replacement of wooden first or ground floors with concrete or
other major repairs necessary to facilitate rat eradication.



(Prior Code, § 6.06.006)



§ 93.091  CONDEMNATION OF UNOCCUPIED BUILDINGS OR RESIDENCES.



   Whenever conditions inside or under any unoccupied business buildings
or residences provide extensive harborage for rats in the opinion of the
Health Officer, the Health Officer is empowered to require compliance with
the provisions of § 93.089 and, if such conditions are not corrected in a
period of 60 days, or within the time to which a written extension may have
been granted by the Health Officer, the Health Officer is empowered to
institute condemnation and destruction proceedings.



(Prior Code, § 6.06.007)



§ 93.092  WHERE FOODSTUFFS STORED, KEPT AND THE LIKE.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to occupy any new or existing
business buildings wherein foodstuffs are to be stored, kept, handled, sold,
held or offered for sale without complying with the provisions of this
subchapter; unless the provisions of this section are complied with, no city
license or permit to conduct or carry on any business mentioned above will be
issued.



(Prior Code, § 6.06.008)  Penalty, see § 93.999



§ 93.093  STORAGE OF FOOD, FEED.



   All food and feed within the city for feeding chickens, cows, pigs,
horses and other animals shall be stored in rat-free and rat-proof
containers, compartments or rooms, unless stored in a rat-proof building.



(Prior Code, § 6.06.009)



§ 93.094  INSPECTIONS.



   The Health Officer is empowered to make unannounced inspections of the
interior and exterior of business buildings to determine full compliance with
this subchapter, and the Health Officer shall make periodic inspections at
intervals of not more than 45 days of all rat-proofed buildings to determine
evidence of rat infestation and the existence of new breaks or leaks in the
rat-proofing. The Health Officer may also make inspections of a residence to
determine the need for rat-proofing upon receipt of a written complaint from
any citizen. When any evidence of it is found indicating the presence of rats
or openings through which rats may again enter business buildings or
residences, the Health Officer shall serve the owners or occupants with
notice and/or orders to abate the conditions found.



(Prior Code, § 6.06.010)



§ 93.095  RESTORATION OF RAT-PROOFING FOLLOWING REPAIR, RECONSTRUCTION AND
THE LIKE.



   It shall be unlawful under the provisions of this subchapter for the
occupant, owner, contractor, public utility company, plumber or any other
person to remove and fail to restore in condition the rat- proofing from any
business building or residence for any purpose. It shall be unlawful any
person or agent to make any new openings that are not closed or sealed
against entrance of rats.



(Prior Code, § 6.06.011)  Penalty, see § 93.999



§ 93.096  STORAGE OF LUMBER, BOXES AND THE LIKE.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to permit to accumulate on any
premises, improved or vacant, or on any open lot or alley in the city, any
lumber, boxes, barrels, bottles, cans, containers or similar materials that
may be permitted to remain thereon unless same shall placed on open racks
that are elevated not less than 18 inches above the ground, and evenly piled
or stacked.



(Prior Code, § 6.06.012)  (Ord. 99-8-18, passed 8-24-1999)  Penalty, see
§ 93.999




ILLEGAL SMOKING PRODUCTS




§ 93.110  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   ILLEGAL SMOKING PRODUCT.



      (1)   Any substance, whether described as tobacco, herbs,
incense, spice or any blend thereof, regardless of whether the substance is
marketed for the purpose of being smoked, which includes any one or more of
the following chemicals:



         (a)   Salvia divinorum salvinorin A; all parts of the
plant presently classified botanically as salvia divinorum, whether growing
or not, the seeds thereof, any extract from any part of such plant, and every
compound, manufacture, salts derivative, mixture or preparation of such
plant, its seeds or extracts;



         (b)   2-(lR,
3S)-3-hydroxycyclohexyl)-5-(2-methyloctan-2-yl) phenol (also known as CP47,
497) and homologues;



         (c)   (6aS, 10aS)-9-(hydroxmethyl)-6,
6-dimethyl-3-(2-methyloctan-l-yl)-6a, 7, 10, 10a-tetrahyrobenzo [c]
chomien-l-ol) (also known as HU-211 or Dexanabino);



         (d)   l-pentyl-2-(l-naphthoyl) indole (also known as
JWH-018);



         (e)   l-butyl-3-(l-naphthoyl) indole (also known as
JWH-030); or



         (f)   l-pentyl-3-(4-methoxynaphthoyl) indole (also known
as JWH-081).



      (2)   Products containing some or all of the above substances
are currently being marketed under the following commercial names: Spice,
Spice Gold, Spice Diamond, Yucatan Fire, Solar Flare, Pep Spice, Fire N Ice,
K-2 Summit, K-2 Sex and KO Knock-Out 2.



      (3)   Any ILLEGAL SMOKING PRODUCT containing any of the
chemical compounds set forth above shall be subject to the provisions of this
subchapter, regardless of whether they are marketed under alternative names.



   PERSON.  An individual, group of individuals, proprietorship,
corporation, partnership, wholesaler, retailer or any licensed or unlicensed
business.



(Prior Code, § 6.07.001)



§ 93.111  SALE, OFFER, GIFT, DISPLAY OR POSSESSION.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer to sell, deliver to
or to give any illegal smoking product to any person.



(Prior Code, § 6.07.002)  Penalty, see § 93.999



§ 93.112  USE OR POSSESSION.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his or her possession or
to use illegal smoking products.



(Prior Code, § 6.07.003)  Penalty, see § 93.999



§ 93.113  AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE TO PROSECUTION.



   (A)   It shall be a defense to prosecution for a violation of this
subchapter if the possession or use of the illegal smoking product is at the
direction of or under a prescription issued by a licensed physician or
dentist authorized to prescribe controlled substances within the state.



   (B)   It shall be a defense to prosecution for a violation of this
subchapter if the sale, use or possession of the illegal smoking product was
in conjunction with ornamental landscaping and used solely for that purpose.



   (C)   It shall be a defense to prosecution for a violation of this
subchapter if any individual charged with a violation can provide proper and
complete historic documentation that the possession or use of such illegal
smoking product is a portion of a religious undertaking or activity of a
religious denomination which has long standing historic membership supported
by documentation from clergy or a spiritual leader recognized by the state.



(Prior Code, § 6.07.004)



§ 93.999  PENALTY.



   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which
no specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to § 10.99.



   (B)   Any person violating any provision of §§ 93.015 through
93.018 shall, upon conviction, be punished pursuant to § 10.99.



(Prior Code, § 6.02.032)



   (C)   (1)   Any person who violates any provision of §§ 93.050
through 93.059 shall be guilty of a class "C" misdemeanor and shall be
punished by a fine of not less than $25 nor more than $200. If a defendant
has previously been convicted under §§ 93.050 through 93.059, the defendant
shall be fined an amount of not less than  $50 nor more than $500 for a
second conviction hereunder, and shall be fined an amount of not less than 
$100 nor more than $1,000 for a third conviction hereunder and for each
conviction thereafter.



      (2)   Each day an offense occurs is a separate violation



(Prior Code, § 6.04.004)



   (D)   Violations of §§ 93.110 through 93.113 shall be a
misdemeanor, and subject to a penalty as provided for in this code.



(Prior Code, § 6.07.005)  (Ord. 10-11-22, passed 11-23-2010)



CHAPTER 94:  PARKS AND RECREATION



Section



   94.01   Definitions



   94.02   Enforcement



   94.03   Hours when parks are open to the public; unlawful entry



   94.04   Conduct of persons



   94.05   Littering and dumping prohibited



   94.06   Smoking prohibited



   94.07   Traffic regulations



   94.08   Behavior



   94.09   Glass containers



   94.10   Recreation activities



   94.11   Dogs; owner’s responsibility



   94.12   Livestock and fowl



   94.13   Policy regarding advertising inside city parks



   94.14   Vendors



Charter reference:



   Parks, see Art. II, § 17



§ 94.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES.  The same as defined in the Tex. Alcoholic
Beverage Code, § 1.04.



   CONTROLLED SUBSTANCE.  Any substance defined as a controlled substance
by the Texas Controlled Substances Act (Tex. Health and Safety Code, Ch. 481).



   DANGEROUS DRUG.  Any substance defined as a dangerous drug by Tex.
Health and Safety Code, §§ 483.001 et seq.



   PARK.  A park, reservation, playground, recreation center or any other
area in the city owned, used or designated by the city and devoted to active
or passive recreation.



   SUPERINTENDENT.  The Public Services Director and Parks Superintendent
of the city.



(Prior Code, § 1.08.001)



§ 94.02  ENFORCEMENT.



   (A)   Officials. The Superintendent, code enforcement officers of
the Community Development Department, or the Chief of Police, or his or her
designee, shall, in connection with their duty imposed by law, diligently
enforce the provisions of this chapter.



   (B)   Ejectment. The Superintendent, code enforcement officers or
the Chief of Police, or his or her designee, shall have the authority to
eject from any park any person acting in violation of this chapter or in
violation of any rules and regulations promulgated by the Council and to
determine the length of time during which such person shall be excluded from
such park. No person shall come in or upon any park from which he or she has
been excluded in accordance with the provisions of this section.



   (C)   Appeal of ejectment. Any person aggrieved by the enforcement
of division (B) above may appeal such action within ten days from the date
thereof by filing written notice of appeal with the City Secretary. Within
ten days of the receipt of the notice of appeal, the City Manager shall set a
time and place for a hearing on the appeal which shall be held no later than
40 days from the date of receipt of the notice of appeal.



   (D)   Notice. Notice of the time and place of the appeal hearing
shall be delivered to the person in person, by mail, or by publication at
least once in the official newspaper of the city if service in person or by
mail are unsuccessful in notifying the aggrieved person of the hearing.



   (E)   Decision final. The decision of the City Manager on the appeal
is final. No other administrative procedure shall be provided by the city.



   (F)   Appeal. A person aggrieved by the City Manager’s decision
may appeal the decision to the county court at law no later than ten days
after receipt by certified mail of the City Manager’s decision and not
thereafter for a trial de novo.



(Prior Code, § 1.08.002)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 94.03  HOURS WHEN PARKS ARE OPEN TO THE PUBLIC; UNLAWFUL ENTRY.



   (A)   Park hours. Except for events sponsored by the city or
unforeseen emergencies, parks shall be only open to the public every day of
the year during the hours of 5:00 a.m. until 11:00 p.m. unless different
opening and closing hours for each individual park shall be posted therein.



   (B)   Unlawful entry. It shall be unlawful for any person, other
than an employee of the city in the course of his or her employment, or
except while anyone is traveling on an established roadway through a park, to
be or remain in any park during any time it is not open.



   (C)   Unlawful use. It shall be unlawful to use any park at any time
for any unlawful meetings or purposes.



   (D)   Closed areas. Any section or part of any park may be declared
closed to the public by the Superintendent at any time for any interval of
time, either temporarily or at regular and stated intervals.



   (E)   Entrance to parks or recreation areas restricted. No person
shall enter a park or recreational area by climbing over, under or through
any fence surrounding the same; or entering the same through or by way of the
water on the lake side or from the dam site; or by any other manner except
through the designated gates or parking facilities.



(Prior Code, § 1.08.003)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 94.04  CONDUCT OF PERSONS.



   No person in a park shall:



   (A)   Willfully or intentionally mark, deface, disfigure, injure,
tamper with or displace or remove any building, bridge, table, bench,
fireplace, railing or paving material, water line or other public utilities
or parts or appurtenances thereof, signs, notices or placards, whether
temporary or permanent, monuments, stakes, posts or other boundary markers,
or other structures or equipment, facilities or park property or
appurtenances, either real or personal;



   (B)   Fail to cooperate in maintaining restrooms and washrooms in a
neat and sanitary condition;



   (C)   Dig or remove any soil, rock, stones, trees, shrubs or plants
or other wood or materials, or make any excavation by tool, equipment,
blasting or other means or agency;



   (D)   Damage, cut, carve, transplant or remove any tree or plant or
injure the bark or pick the flowers or seeds of any tree or plant;



   (E)   Dig in or otherwise disturb grass areas, or in any other way
injure or impair the natural beauty or usefulness of the area; or



   (F)   Willfully interfere with, disrupt or prevent the orderly
conduct of any supervised play or amusement program being conducted by the
city.



(Prior Code, § 1.08.004)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 94.05  LITTERING AND DUMPING PROHIBITED.



   (A)   It is unlawful for any person to throw, discard, dump, deposit
or leave in and upon the grounds or waters of a public park or recreation
area any litter, garbage, trash or debris except in receptacles provided for
this purpose. Where public receptacles are not provided, all such litter,
garbage, refuse and the like shall be picked up, carried away from the park
grounds, and otherwise disposed of in accordance with this code.



   (B)   Persons placing litter in public receptacles shall prevent the
litter from being carried or deposited by the elements upon the park grounds
or other public places.



   (C)   It is unlawful for any person, while a driver or passenger in
or upon a motor vehicle, to throw or deposit litter, garbage or refuse onto
the grounds of a city park.



   (D)   All trash receptacles located within parks shall be used for
the disposal of waste generated from within the parks and not for disposal of
waste generated elsewhere.



(Prior Code, § 1.08.005)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 94.06  SMOKING PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke within a park as defined
in § 93.050.



(Prior Code, § 1.08.006)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 94.07  TRAFFIC REGULATIONS.



   No person in a park shall:



   (A)   Fail to comply with all applicable provisions of the state
motor vehicle traffic laws in regard to the equipment and operation of
vehicles, together with such regulations as are contained in this chapter and
other ordinances;



   (B)   Fail to obey all traffic officers and park employees, such
persons being hereby authorized and instructed to direct traffic whenever
needed in the parks and on the highways, streets or roads immediately
adjacent thereto;



   (C)   Fail to observe carefully all traffic signs indicating speed,
direction, caution, stopping or parking and all others posted for proper
control and to safeguard life and property;



   (D)   Operate or drive any vehicle at a speed in excess of ten mph,
except upon such roads as the Superintendent may designate, by posted signs,
for speedier travel;



   (E)   Park a vehicle in other than an established or designated
parking area, and such use shall be in accordance with the posted directions
there at and with the instructions of any attendant who may be present;



   (F)   Double park any vehicle on any road or parkway unless directed
by a park official or in any manner block any roadway within a park;



   (G)   Drive any motor vehicle on any area except the paved park
roads or parking area;



   (H)   Ride a bicycle on other than a paved vehicular road or path
designated for that purpose and ride a bicycle other than on the right-hand
side of the road paving as close to the edge as conditions permit. A
bicyclist shall at all times operate his or her machine with reasonable
regard to the safety of others, signal all turns, pass to the right of any
vehicle he or she is overtaking and pass to the right of any vehicle he or
she may be meeting; or



   (I)   Operate a motor vehicle of any kind on the walking trails.



(Prior Code, § 1.08.007)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 94.08  BEHAVIOR.



   No person in a park shall, unless authorized by the Superintendent:



   (A)   Bring alcoholic beverages into a park, nor shall any person
consume alcoholic beverages at any time in a park; however, alcoholic
beverages may be served and consumed inside the city civic center building
located at Lake Forest Park in the city in accordance with all laws of the
state and ordinances of the city concerning alcoholic beverages and public
intoxication. Service and/or consumption of alcoholic beverages outside said
building and inside the respective park in which said building is located are
prohibited;



   (B)   Enter or remain in a park while under the influence of
alcoholic beverages, controlled substances or dangerous drugs;



   (C)   Discharge, set off or otherwise cause to explode or discharge
or burn any firecracker, torpedo, rocket or any other fireworks or explosives
of inflammable material;



   (D)   Build or attempt to build a fire, except in such areas and
under such regulations as may be designated by Superintendent; or



   (E)   Gamble or participate in or aid any game of chance.



(Prior Code, § 1.08.008)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 94.09  GLASS CONTAINERS.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to bring into, have in
one’s possession or leave any glass containers within any city park.



   (B)   Should any person, firm or corporation or his, her or their
agent, servant or employee violate the terms and/or provisions of this
sections, such persons, firm or corporation, their agents, servants or
employees shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction
thereof, by a court of competent jurisdictions, such person, firm or
corporation, their agents, servants or employees may be fined as provided in
§ 10.99.



(Prior Code, § 1.08.009)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 94.10  RECREATION ACTIVITIES.



   No person in a park shall:



   (A)   Swim, bathe or wade in any water or waterways in or adjacent
to any park, except in such water and at such places as are provided
therefore, and in compliance with such regulations as are set forth in this
chapter;



   (B)   Must wear a bathing suit or other clothing as defined in
Ordinance 95-6-5 so as not to indecently expose his or her person;



   (C)   Bring into or operate any boat or other watercraft, whether
motor powered or not, upon any waters, except at places designated by the
Superintendent;



   (D)   Fish in any waters, except in waters designated by the
Superintendent for that use and under such regulations and restrictions as
have been or may be prescribed by the Superintendent. Traps, nets and seines
are prohibited;



   (E)   Hunt, stalk, trap or kill any bird, animal or other wildlife
in or upon the grounds of a public park or recreation area;



   (F)   Possess, carry or discharge any firearm, except as allowed by
state law;



   (G)   Possess or discharge any bow and arrow, crossbow or other
archery equipment;



   (H)   Drive, putt or otherwise hit a golf ball in or upon the
grounds of any public park;



   (I)   Skateboard or skate in any areas other than designated for
that purpose; or



   (J)   Occupy tennis courts for any purpose other than playing tennis
or handball.



(Prior Code, § 1.08.010)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 94.11  DOGS; OWNER’S RESPONSIBILITY.



   (A)   All dogs entering city parks shall be leashed at all times.



   (B)   Owners shall be responsible for collecting and disposing of
their dog’s solid waste at all times within park property.



(Prior Code, § 1.08.011)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 94.12  LIVESTOCK AND FOWL.



   It shall be unlawful for any person, being the owner of or having
control thereof, and without the permission of the city, to suffer or permit
any chickens, ducks, geese, hogs, swine, cattle, horses, sheep, goats or any
other livestock or fowl, as defined in Chapter 90, to stray into or to run at
large or unattended or to trespass upon any park. If any of the livestock or
fowl prohibited by this section, straying into, running at large or
unattended or trespass onto park property, such animals may be impounded by
animal control.



(Prior Code, § 1.08.012)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 94.13  POLICY REGARDING ADVERTISING INSIDE CITY PARKS.



   Businesses, firms, organizations and individuals are allowed to
advertise their respective businesses by displaying a four-foot by eight-foot
banner located on the softball fields from the left field foul pole to the
right field foul pole. An annual fee, which is on file with the City
Secretary, is charged for the advertisement and the banner material must
comply with the city’s zoning ordinance. The banners must be installed by
the city and removed if renewal payment is not received the following year.
The advertiser shall be responsible for the condition of the banner, whether
or not deterioration is caused by vandalism or by the weather. The city shall
not be responsible for damaged or stolen banners, once installed. No
alcoholic beverage, foods or others beverages, other than water, may be
advertised on the outside of a building located in the park or on the outside
of a vending trailer acting as a concession stand or on the banners. The City
Manager will review all applications prior to approval.



(Prior Code, § 1.08.013)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 94.14  VENDORS.



   Vendors will be allowed into parks by permit only. Applications must be
made through the Community Development Department and must meet the
requirements described in Title XI. No advertisements of foods or beverages,
other than water, may be made in the park, except for advertisements erected
inside of a building or enclosed trailer acting as a concession stand.



(Prior Code, § 1.08.014)  (Ord. 11-09-14, passed 9-13-2011)
