Code, § 215.004




GENERALLY




§ 115.001  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   CRUISE or CRUISING.  The movement of unoccupied taxicabs over the
public streets of the city, in search of or soliciting prospective passengers
for hire; except, however, unoccupied taxicabs proceeding to answer a
telephone call for taxicab service from an intending passenger, and taxicabs
returning to a taxi stand or subtaxi stand, by the most direct route, after
having discharged a passenger or passengers, to the garage where such taxicab
is housed or to the place of discharge of the passenger or passengers, shall
not be considered to be CRUISING.



   DRIVER or CHAUFFEUR.  Every person in actual charge of the operation
of a taxicab, whether as owner or agent, servant or employee of the owner.



   FRANCHISE or GRANT.  An authority issued by the Chief of Police or the
City Council, after a finding that public convenience and necessity so
require it, which may be issued to an owner or owners of taxicabs. The term
FRANCHISE shall apply to an owner or operator of taxicabs which authorizes
such owner or operator of taxicabs to engage in the business of
transportation by taxicab. The term FRANCHISE shall also mean the award of a
certificate of public convenience and necessity; and an application as well
as an authority to operate more vehicles than originally granted by the
certificate of public convenience and necessity within a franchise is
tantamount to an amendment of the franchise by granting additional licenses
for additional taxicabs.



   LICENSE.  When used alone, shall apply to the authorization made to
the franchise holder, which is a license to operate one or more taxicabs, and
although a franchise may be held by an owner and taxicab operator for a
designated number of licenses to operate a specified number of taxicabs,
application must be made by the franchise holder for placing more taxicabs
within his or her license to operate.



   OWNER or TAXICAB OPERATOR. Any person who has the control, direction,
maintenance and the benefit of the collection of revenue derived from the
operation of taxicabs on or over the streets or public ways of the city,
whether as owner or otherwise, except a driver.



   PUBLIC CONVENIENCE AND NECESSITY.  A public convenience which is
fitting and suited to public need, and a public necessity which embraces a
great and urgent public convenience. This term as applied to a proposed
service by an applicant shall mean that applicant is fit, able and willing to
perform transportation by taxicabs in accordance with the requirements of
this chapter and that public CONVENIENCE AND NECESSITY require the service
proposed by such applicant.



   TAXICAB.  Every automobile or motor-propelled vehicle used for
transportation of passengers for hire over the public streets of the city,
and not over a defined or fixed route, and irrespective of whether or not the
operations extend beyond the city limits, at rates for distance traveled, or
for wait time, or for both, or at rates per hour, per week, or per month,
which such vehicle is routed to destinations under the direction of such
passenger or passengers, or such person hiring the same; provided, however,
the term TAXICAB shall not apply to motorbuses operated within the city under
a franchise from the city, over a fixed or definite route, nor shall such
term apply to motorbuses regularly operated in the city along fixed routes to
and from points outside the incorporated limits of the city, nor shall such
term apply to motor vehicles regularly engaged in interstate commerce.



   TERMINAL.  The taxi depot at which place the taxicabs shall be housed
or parked, and at which place the telephone calls and requests for service
shall be made, and at which place a dispatcher shall control the movements of
the taxicabs to the points of request for taxicab service; this term shall
likewise be synonymous with TAXI TERMINAL, and shall mean and embrace that
space and area of land and buildings off of the streets of the city, and upon
private property, and shall be and constitute the main office of the owner
and taxicab operator. The term TERMINAL shall also mean and include any place
at which the drivers of taxicabs, or chauffeurs of taxicabs, shall use to
receive calls from the dispatcher as such calls may be relayed from the
terminal, and shall likewise mean and embrace that space and area used by
taxicabs in waiting for passengers.



   WAITING TIME.  Such time as may be consumed or lost at the special
instance and request of a passenger after such passenger has first entered
the taxicab to make a trip and before reaching his or her final destination;
and no charge will be made against a passenger for any time lost on account
of any other delay whatsoever.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.001)



§ 115.002  PROSECUTION FOR VIOLATION.



   In a prosecution for violation of this chapter, it shall not be
necessary for the complaint to allege, or for proof to be made, that the act
was knowingly done; nor shall it be necessary for the complaint to negate any
exception contained in this chapter concerning any prohibited act.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.002)



§ 115.003  LIABILITY OF CITY.



   The city shall not be liable for any reason for an amount due to any
claim or on account of any act or omission of any officer of the city in
connection with any matter relating to taxicabs.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.003)




ADMINISTRATION




§ 115.015  CHIEF OF POLICE; ENFORCEMENT GENERALLY.



   It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to enforce the provisions
of this chapter, and all other applicable provisions of this code, state law
and city ordinances, rules and regulations.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.031)



§ 115.016  RECOMMENDATIONS OF CHIEF.



   The Chief of Police shall recommend to the City Council reasonable
rules and regulations which, when approved by the City Council by appropriate
measures, shall become binding upon the holder of any franchise granted under
the provisions of this chapter.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.032)



§ 115.017  ADMINISTRATIVE DUTIES OF CHIEF.



   Without limiting the power or authority of the City Council, the Chief
of Police shall perform the following normal functions of office affecting
the holder of any franchise issued under the provisions of this chapter:



   (A)   Make reasonable orders respecting character, extent, quality
and standard of service;



   (B)   Recommend to be fixed by the City Council such rates as are
not in conflict with the express provisions hereof and make reasonable orders
respecting same;



   (C)   Prescribe the number of cabs to be operated by such grantee
and prescribe the number of cabs to be operated on various days of the week
and hours of the days, applying thereto the principles of public necessity
and convenience;



   (D)   Inspect any and all equipment used or proposed to be used by
grantee for the purpose of exercising any right or privilege under such
franchise;



   (E)   Require examination and recommend the licensing of all drivers
or operators of any cab or vehicle operated or maintained by such grantee
under the provisions hereof;



   (F)   Inspect the books of such grantee at all reasonable times and
prescribe reasonable rules and regulations concerning the method of keeping
such records by such grantee;



   (G)   Receive from owners all applications for franchises to operate
taxicabs, receive applications for chauffeurs’ licenses, conduct hearings
thereon, and from time to time inspect the operations of taxicabs within the
incorporated limits of the city; and



   (H)   Make such other rules and regulations as may be reasonably
necessary to facilitate the service to be rendered to the public under such
franchise, which rules when approved by the City Council shall become binding
on the grantee.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.033)




FRANCHISE




§ 115.030  REQUIRED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, use or operate on any
street within the city any taxicab, unless a written franchise for such
taxicab shall have first been obtained from the City Council by the person
owning or controlling such taxicab, and unless such franchise shall be in
effect at such time.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.061)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 115.031  APPLICATION.



   Any applicant for a taxicab franchise under the provisions of this
subchapter shall make proper application therefor on blanks to be furnished
by the Chief of Police.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.062)



§ 115.032  NOTICE OF APPLICATION.



   Upon the filing of any application for a taxicab franchise, the Chief
of Police shall cause a notice thereof to be published in one of the daily
newspapers of the city, the cost of publishing such notice shall be advanced
in full by the applicant. Such notice shall set out the facts that the
certain application has been filed for a taxicab franchise, the name of the
applicant, kind of equipment and all other pertinent data from such
application, which the Chief of Police may deem necessary. Such publication
shall constitute a notice of all holders of existing taxicab franchises and
to the public that a public hearing will be held at a public place in the
city, to be designated by the Chief of Police in such notice, and at a
designated time given in such notice, which such designated time shall not be
less than five days nor more than 15 days after the date of the first
publication of such notice, and such notice shall be published for three
successive days.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.063)



§ 115.033  OBJECTIONS TO ISSUANCE.



   All holders of existing taxicab franchises or any other citizen shall
be entitled to file any complaints or protests that such party may see fit
against the issuance of a franchise to the applicant therefor.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.064)



§ 115.034  HEARING.



   (A)   At the time of the holding of the investigation and hearing
with reference to whether the public convenience and necessity requires the
operation of such additional vehicle or vehicles covered in the application
filed under the provisions of this subchapter, the Chief of Police shall
consider all of the complaints and protests and, in conducting the hearing,
shall have the right to call such witnesses as he or she shall see fit.



   (B)   In all such hearings, the burden of proof shall be upon the
applicant to establish by clear, cogent and convincing evidence that the
public convenience and necessity require such operation of the vehicle or
vehicles for which such application has been made and that the applicant is
fit, able and willing to perform such transportation of persons and property
by taxicab as proposed in the application.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.065)



§ 115.035  FACTORS IN DETERMINING PUBLIC CONVENIENCE AND NECESSITY.



   (A)   In determining whether public convenience and necessity
require the licensing of taxicabs for which application may be made, the
Chief of Police shall take into consideration:



      (1)   Whether the demands of public convenience and necessity
require such proposed or such additional taxicab service within the city;



      (2)   The financial responsibility of the applicant;



      (3)   The number, kind, type and equipment, the color scheme
to be used by applicant;



      (4)   The increased traffic congestion on the streets of the
city which may result;



      (5)   Whether the safe use of the streets of the city by the
public, both vehicular and pedestrian, will be unduly endangered by the
granting of such additional licenses;



      (6)   Whether applicant is fit, able and willing to perform
transportation by taxicabs; and



      (7)   Such other relevant facts as the Chief of Police may
deem advisable or necessary, which may throw light on public necessity and
convenience.



   (B)   No application will be granted and no finding shall be made of
public convenience and necessity unless and until there is a finding that
such applicant is fit, able and willing to perform transportation by taxicab
as provided in this chapter and that there is public demand and need for the
type of service proposed.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.066)



§ 115.036  FINDINGS BY CHIEF OF POLICE.



   If the Chief of Police finds from his or her investigation and hearing
that the public convenience and necessity justify the operation of the
additional taxicabs for which franchise is desired, he or she shall notify
the applicant of his or her finding. Within five days thereafter, the
applicant shall furnish to the Chief of Police any and all relevant
information which may be required. If the Chief of Police then finds that the
applicant is the owner or lessee of and intends to become the bona fide
operator of the taxicabs for which franchise is desired, he or she shall
require of such applicant a policy of public liability, bodily injury and
property damage insurance and a performance bond as provided, and if he or
she shall further find that such policy of insurance and performance bond has
been filed and deposited with the City Secretary, and that such taxicabs
comply with and the applicant has complied with all relevant ordinances of
the city and all of the rules and regulations established by the Chief of
Police to more effectively carry out the purpose and intent of this chapter,
he or she shall issue his or her written certificate to the City Secretary,
not less than ten days after his or her findings have been declared,
certifying that the public convenience and necessity require operation of
said taxicabs, or any number thereof which the applicant desires and proposes
to operate, and that the applicant is entitled to have such franchise to
operate taxicabs upon complying with all other provisions of this chapter.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.067)



§ 115.037  ISSUANCE.



   If the Chief of Police finds that the public convenience and necessity
would be served by the issuance of a franchise under the provisions of this
subchapter and so notifies the City Secretary to that effect, the City
Secretary shall then issue such franchise to the applicant therefor.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.068)



§ 115.038  DENIAL.



   If the Chief of Police finds from his or her investigation and hearing
that the public convenience and necessity do not justify the operation of the
taxicabs for which franchise is desired, he or she shall forthwith notify the
applicant of such finding and the franchise applied for shall be denied.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.069)



§ 115.039  FRANCHISE FEE.



   The franchise fee for each franchise shall be due and payable on
October 1. The franchise fee is to remain the same, regardless of the number
of taxicabs operated by the franchise holder.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.070)



§ 115.040  INSPECTION OF RECORDS.



   The Chief of Police shall have the authority to inspect the business
records of any owners and operators of taxicabs during regular business
hours, which records each taxicab owner and operator must make available for
inspection during regular business hours.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.071)



§ 115.041  ASSIGNMENT PROHIBITED.



   No franchise issued under the provisions of this subchapter shall be
transferable or assignable.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.072)



§ 115.042  REVOCATION OF FRANCHISE, LICENSES, PERMITS.



   Any franchise, license or permit issued under the provisions of this
chapter may be revoked for the violation of or the failure to perform any
duty required by the provisions of this chapter or other applicable
provisions of this code, state law or city ordinance, rule or regulation.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.073)



§ 115.043  TERMINALS.



   (A)   Every franchise owner shall maintain within the city limits an
off-street terminal of sufficient size to accommodate all of the franchise
owner’s taxicabs. The franchise owner shall maintain at such terminal, 24
hours per day, telephone service and all records pertaining to the operation
of his or her franchise. Such records shall be open for inspection to any
police officer, City Auditor and Chief of Police.



   (B)   Subtaxi stands at hotels, depots and other places shall be
designated by the Chief of Police. No subterminal in any residential section
of the city shall be installed or approved by the Chief of Police which will
violate the peace and quietude; provided, however, that a prima facie case
reflecting such peace and quietude shall be considered to have been
introduced upon the introduction of written consent of 90% of the lot owners
within 300 feet of such subtaxi stand.



   (C)   The form and type of terminal shall be of such a nature as
best meets public convenience and necessity and affords a safe, sanitary and
lawful operation of transportation by taxicabs. The site, location, type of
proposed buildings and the sanitary conditions of the taxi stand shall be
reflected in an application to the Chief of Police. The equipment, site and
place of a terminal must be found by the Chief of Police to best meet public
convenience and necessity prior to an authorization to a franchise holder to
operate such terminal. An affirmative finding in favor of the applicant,
reflecting adequate sufficiency of the place of any off-street terminal,
shall be considered as having an established prima facie case thereon, upon
it appearing within the application that the operator of taxicabs is
presently operating for his or her own exclusive use such off-street terminal
in the commercial areas of the city.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.074)  Penalty, see § 10.99




REGULATIONS




§ 115.055  CRUISING.



   It shall be unlawful for the grantee, its officers, agents or
employees, operating any automobile for hire within the city to cruise,
except between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. Cruising shall consist of
seeking, searching or soliciting employment while operating an automobile for
hire by repeatedly and persistently driving such automobile for hire to and
fro on the public streets of the city and offering accommodations thereof to
prospective passengers, either by signal, word of mouth, or by carrying a
sign with the word “vacant” thereon, or some other word of similar import
or otherwise, in any manner whatsoever operating such vehicle upon the public
streets of the city for the purpose of soliciting passengers, or driving an
automobile for hire upon the public streets while unoccupied by a passenger
without having a fixed destination thereof; however, a vacant cab may pick up
a passenger on signal, when returning to his or her regular taxi stand or
terminal after delivering a passenger.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.101)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 115.056  ACTUAL OPERATION RESTRICTED



   It shall be unlawful for any taxicab to be driven or operated within
the corporate limits of the city by any person except the owner of such
taxicab or the authorized agent or employee of the owner.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.102)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 115.057  DISPOSITION OF PROPERTY LEFT IN VEHICLE.



   It shall be the duty of every taxicab driver to immediately return to
the owner, if known, any luggage, merchandise or other property left in
taxicabs. If the owner is not known, the driver shall immediately, upon
return to his or her terminal, turn over to the manager of the terminal any
property whatsoever left in his or her taxicab with a complete report of when
it was left in his or her taxicab. Such article shall be tagged, and if not
called for within seven days, shall be turned over to the Chief of Police
with all available information as to the probable owner.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.103)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 115.058  TRANSPORTATION FOR UNLAWFUL PURPOSES.



   It shall be unlawful for any driver of a taxicab, knowingly, to
transport any passenger to the abode of a prostitute, or to knowingly
transport any known criminal, narcotic peddler, prostitute, bootlegger, in
the commission of a crime or the infraction of the law in any manner, or act
in any manner as a pimp for prostitutes, or a contact man for unlawful
establishments of any character.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.104)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 115.059  PAYMENT OF AD VALOREM TAXES.



   No operator of taxicabs shall engage in the transportation of persons
by taxicab at any time when the ad valorem taxes assessed against such
terminal, taxicabs and taxicab equipment shall be delinquent.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.105)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 115.060  SOLICITATION OF PASSENGERS AT DEPOTS.



   When any taxicab is at any rail, air or bus depot within the city, it
shall be unlawful for the driver or person in charge thereof to leave the
same and enter the depot or go upon the sidewalk or private property of any
railroad company, airfield or bus station for the purpose of soliciting the
transportation of any passengers arriving on the trains, planes or buses at
such depot.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.106)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 115.061  DRIVERS TO STAY WITH VEHICLES.



   The drivers of taxicabs using subterminals shall remain seated in their
vehicles at all times while such vehicle is at a public stand; provided,
however, such drivers may leave their vehicles when actually necessary to
assist passengers to enter or leave same, or in any case of accident,
necessity or emergency beyond the control of such driver.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.107)



§ 115.062  INSPECTION OF VEHICLES.



   Every taxicab which is or may be licensed under the provisions of this
chapter shall be inspected at least once every month for the purpose of
determining whether such vehicle is in a safe and sanitary condition to be
operated as a taxicab; and to such inspection the owner of such vehicle shall
submit the same, at such time and place that may be specified by the Chief of
Police. If the Chief of Police finds it to be in a safe condition, he or she
shall paste a paper seal of a type and design adopted by the Chief of Police
on some portion of such vehicle, stating the date such vehicle was inspected,
and that such vehicle was approved by the Chief of Police. No taxicab shall
be operated in the city without the approval seal of the Chief of Police
being attached thereto. No inspection fee shall be charged. No taxicab found
to be unsafe by the Chief of Police shall be operated over the streets of the
city. Nothing herein, however, shall prevent the Chief of Police from
inspecting any taxicab at any reasonable time that he or she sees fit, and he
or she is expressly given power to do so, and upon finding such taxicab to be
in a defective condition he or she shall order its use as a taxicab
discontinued until the same has been approved by him or her.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.108)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 115.063  IDENTIFICATION OF VEHICLES; GENERALLY.



   (A)   Every taxicab shall have painted on each side and the rear of
the cab the name of the owner or the name under which the owner operates,
together with the company’s telephone number, the franchise number and the
cab number.



      (1)   All of the lettering mentioned in this division (A)
shall not be less than two and one-half inches in height and not less than
five-sixteenths-inch stroke, and the paint used therefor shall be either
enamel or oil paint that will weather the elements and must be kept legible
at all times.



      (2)   All lettering on all taxicabs owned by the same
franchise owner shall be the same wording, same color, same size letters, and
on the same place on each taxicab.



      (3)   All taxicab franchise owners shall adopt a standard
color or combination of colors and shall not operate a taxicab until all of
such taxicabs are painted the color or combination of colors adopted by the
franchise owner. The color or combination of colors shall be filed with the
Chief of Police and shall be approved by him or her. After the color or
combination of colors has been approved by the Chief of Police, the same
shall not be changed without his or her consent.



   (B)   Whenever any taxicab shall have been discontinued in use and
no longer designated as one of the cars permitted to be operated under the
franchise, such taxicab shall not be driven upon the streets of the city by
any person with such taxicab company identification thereon.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.109)



§ 115.064  SUBSTITUTE VEHICLES.



   In the event that a franchise owner shall purchase and put in operation
for taxicab service a substitute car for one of its regular cars, a period of
five days from the date of placing such substitute car in service shall be
allowed within which to paint such car and equip same with the identification
required by § 115.063; provided, however, at all times such substitute car
shall be equipped with a lighted sign with the word “taxi” or
“taxicab”, installed on the top and front part of such car, so as to
clearly designate the same as being in taxi service. The franchise owner,
immediately when such substitute car is placed in service, shall notify the
Chief of Police of such substitution and shall present evidence that such car
is covered by the liability insurance policy required by the provisions of
this chapter.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.110)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 115.065  RECEIPT, DISCHARGE OF PASSENGERS.



   No driver of a taxicab shall receive or discharge passengers in the
roadway of any street, but shall drive to the right-hand sidewalk, as nearly
as possible, or, in the absence of a sidewalk, to the extreme right-hand side
of the road, and there receive or discharge passengers.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.111)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 115.066  MAXIMUM SEATING.



   It shall be unlawful to carry more than five passengers in any taxicab,
and in no event shall more than two passengers ride in the front seat with
the driver.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.112)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 115.067  USE OF STREETS FOR TAXICAB STAND PURPOSES.



   It shall be unlawful for any taxicab owner or operator to use the
public streets or any part thereof as a taxi stand.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.113)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 115.068  ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES; TRANSPORTATION PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful to transport alcoholic beverages, not owned and in
the exclusive possession and control of a fare-paying passenger, in the
taxicab or for any taxicab driver to have on his or her person any alcoholic
beverage while driving and operating a taxicab in service.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.114)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 115.069  CONSUMPTION IN VEHICLE.



   It shall be unlawful for any driver of any taxicab to drink alcoholic
beverages of any kind while inside the taxicab.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.115)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 115.070  SALE OF ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES.



   No driver of a taxicab or owner of a taxicab shall engage in selling
intoxicating liquors or soliciting business for any person selling
intoxicating liquors.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.116)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 115.071  TRANSPORTATION OF PERSONS OTHER THAN FOR HIRE.



   No taxicab driver or owner shall permit any other person to occupy or
ride in a taxicab, except a passenger for hire. No taxicab driver or owner
shall carry any person in such taxicab while on the streets of the city
unless such person has agreed to pay for the use and hire of such taxicab.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.117)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 115.072  APPEARANCE.



   It shall be the responsibility of every person operating a taxicab
business or service in the city to require the drivers in his or her employ
to be neat and clean in appearance while on duty.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.118)



§ 115.073  INSURANCE REQUIRED.



   Before any franchise shall be issued under this chapter to any owner of
a taxicab, or before any renewal of such a franchise shall be granted, the
owner shall file with the City Secretary, and thereafter keep in full force
and effect, a policy of public liability insurance approved by the Chief of
Police and executed by an insurance company duly authorized to do business in
the state, and performable in this county, insuring the public against any
loss or damage that may result to any person or property from the operation
of the taxicab covered or to be covered by such license.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.119)



§ 115.074  MINIMUM AMOUNT OF COVERAGE.



   (A)   The maximum amount of recovery in a policy of insurance
required by this subchapter shall not be less than the following sums:



      (1)   For the injury or death of any one person in any one
accident, $10,000;



      (2)   For total liability in any one accident or personal
injuries or death, $20,000; and



      (3)   For injury or destruction of property in any one
accident, $5,000.



   (B)   The minimum amount of insurance liability shall never be less
than the amount established by the statutes of the state under the Texas
Motor Vehicle Safety Responsibility Act, being Tex. Transportation Code, Ch.
601 or amendments thereto.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.120)



§ 115.075  PERSONS PROTECTED.



   The above public liability insurance required by this subchapter shall
be for the protection of the passengers of the insured taxicab and for the
public, but shall not cover personal injuries sustained by the servants,
agents or employees of the person filing the insurance.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.121)



§ 115.076  PROVISION FOR CONTINUING LIABILITY.



   All policies of public liability insurance required by this subchapter
shall contain a provision for a continuing liability thereon up to the full
amount thereof, notwithstanding any recovery thereon.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.122)



§ 115.077  INCREASING AMOUNT UPON RETURN OF EXECUTION UNSATISFIED.



   In the event of the return unsatisfied of any execution issued on any
final judgment rendered against any taxicab owner in any suit for damages on
account of injury to person or property occasioned by the operation of any
taxicab, such owner, within ten days after the return of such execution
unsatisfied, provided the judgment is still unpaid, shall increase the amount
of his or her insurance by the amount of such judgment, and failing to do so
shall forthwith cease the operation of taxicabs in the city until such
additional insurance is deposited or such judgment is paid.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.123)



§ 115.078  CANCELLATION.



   (A)   In the event that any insurer desires to be released from any
insurance filed under this subchapter, it may give written notice of such
desire to the Director of Transportation at least 30 days before it desires
its liability released, and the Chief of Police shall thereupon give written
notice, by personal delivery or by mail, to the insured and demand that he or
she furnish new assurance by the expiration of the 30-day period above
provided for, and shall discharge such first insurer from any liability which
shall accrue after the time of approval of such new policy, or shall
discharge such first insurer after the expiration of such 30-day period.



   (B)   In the event any policy is so canceled upon the request of the
insurer, and no new insurance policy is filed before the cancellation of the
original insurance, the license to operate taxicabs granted to the insured
shall be automatically revoked.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.124)



§ 115.079  CITY NOT LIABLE FOR SOLVENCY OF INSURER; OWNER’S LIABILITY NOT
AFFECTED; SUITS ON POLICY.



   Neither the city nor any officer thereof shall be held liable for the
pecuniary responsibility or solvency of any insurer under the provisions of
this subchapter, or in any manner become liable for any sum on account of any
such claim or act or omission relating to the insured vehicle, nor shall the
liability of the owner of any such vehicle be in any manner limited or
changed by reason of the provisions of this subchapter, but the judgment
creditors having causes of action secured thereby shall be authorized to sue
directly on such policy of insurance without impleading the city, and all
persons known to any insurer to have been injured or damaged in the same
accident and claiming damages thereunder may be made parties without priority
of claim on payment in any suit had or instituted on account of such matters.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.125)



§ 115.080  COUNCIL TO FIX RATES.



   The City Council shall have the power to fix the rates, charges and
fares of all taxicabs operating within the city.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.126)



§ 115.081  MULTIPLE PASSENGERS.



   The first passenger employing a taxicab shall be entitled to its
exclusive use until delivered to his or her destination by the most practical
direct route, and no other passenger may be carried unless the passenger
first engaging the taxicab shall consent to additional passengers who are not
with him or her or his or her party.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.127)



§ 115.082  REFUSAL TO PAY FARE.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to pay the legal fare of
any taxicab after having hired the same, and it shall be unlawful for any
person to hire any taxicab with intent to defraud the person from whom it is
hired of the value of such service.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.128)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 115.083  DUTY TO ISSUE RECEIPT.



   It shall be unlawful for the driver of any taxicab within the city to
fail or refuse to issue a receipt for any fare or charge collected by him or
her from any passenger who shall request such receipt.



(Prior Code, § 4.12.129)  Penalty, see § 10.99



CHAPTER 116:  OIL, GAS AND SALT WATER DISPOSAL WELLS

   Oil and gas, see Tex. Natural Resources Code, Ch. 52, 81 et seq.




GENERAL PROVISIONS




§ 116.001  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. All
technical or oil and gas industry words or phrases used herein and not
specifically defined herein shall have the meanings customarily attributable
thereto by prudent operators in the oil and gas industry.



   LEASE.  Any tract of land subject to an oil, gas and mineral lease or
other oil and gas development contract, or any unit composed of several
tracts and leases but operated as one lease, and any tract of land in which
the minerals are owned by an operator or someone holding under it or him or
her, but which, due to the fee royalty ownership, is developed and operated
as a separate tract.



   PERMITTEE.  The person to whom is issued a permit for the drilling and
operation of a well under the provisions of this chapter, and his or her
administrators, executors, heirs, successors and assigns.



   WELL.  Any hole or bore to any sand, formation, strata or depth for
the purpose of producing and recovering any oil, gas, liquid hydrocarbon, or
any of them, or for disposing of salt water, in any form or consistency
whatsoever, into such subsurface sand, formation, strata or depth.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.001)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)



§ 116.002  APPOINTMENT OF OIL AND GAS INSPECTOR.



   The city designee is hereby designated the Oil and Gas Inspector and
shall enforce the provisions of this chapter.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.002)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)



§ 116.003  PREMISES TO BE KEPT CLEAN AND SANITARY.



   The premises of each oil, gas and/or salt water disposal well shall be
kept in a clean and sanitary condition, free from rubbish of every character,
to the satisfaction of the Health Officer at all times drilling operations or
reworking operations are being conducted, and as long thereafter as oil
and/or gas are being produced therefrom or salt water disposed of therein.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.003)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)



§ 116.004  FENCE.



   The owners of each oil, gas and/or salt water disposal well(s) shall,
upon completion thereof, enclose said well, together with all surface
facilities and storage tanks, with a heavy steel fence of cyclone type, a
minimum of six feet high, with all gates to be kept locked, except when the
permittee or his or her employees are in actuality within the enclosure.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.004)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)



§ 116.005  VIOLATION OF STATE LAWS OR REGULATIONS.



   Any violation of the laws of the state or any rules, regulations or
requirements of any state or federal regulatory body having jurisdiction in
reference to drilling, completing, equipping, operating, producing,
maintaining or abandoning an oil, gas and/or salt water disposal well(s) or
related appurtenances, equipment or facilities, or in reference to firewalls,
fire protection, blowout protection, safety protection or convenience of
persons or property, shall also be a violation of this chapter.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.005)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)



§ 116.006  AUTHORITY TO PROHIBIT DRILLING AT PARTICULAR LOCATION.



   The City Council shall have the power, and hereby reserves the
authority, to refuse any application for a permit to drill and operate any
well at any particular location within any drilling block where, by reason of
such particular location, the character and value of the permanent
improvements already erected on or approximately adjacent to the particular
location in question, and the use to which the land and surroundings are
adapted for school, college, university, hospital or civic purpose, or for
health reasons, or for safety reasons, or any of them, the drilling or
operation of such well on such particular location might be injurious or a
disadvantage to the city, or to its inhabitants as a whole, or to a
substantial number of its inhabitants or visitors as a group.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.006)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)



§ 116.007  NECESSITY OF CONTRACT WITH SURFACE OWNER.



   Neither the provisions of this chapter nor any permit issued hereunder
shall be interpreted to grant any right or license to the permittee to enter
upon, use or occupy in any respect to the drilling or operation of any well,
any surface land except by the written contract of the surface owner; nor
shall it limit or prevent the free right of any owner to contract for the
amount of damages, rights or privileges with respect to his or her own land
and property.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.007)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)



§ 116.008  STREETS AND ALLEYS.



   No oil, gas and/or salt water disposal well(s) shall be drilled, and no
permit shall be issued for any well to be drilled, at any location which is
within any of the streets or alleys of the city. No street or alley shall be
blocked or encumbered or closed in any drilling or production operation
except by special permit by order of the City Council and then only
temporarily.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.008)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)



§ 116.009  WELL LOCATION.



   (A)   No oil, gas and/or salt water disposal well(s) shall be
drilled, and no permit shall be issued for any well to be drilled at any
location which is nearer than 750 feet of any residence or commercial
building without the applicant having first secured the written permission of
the owner or owners thereof.



   (B)   If, however, the applicant cannot obtain such written
permission from 100% of the owners of all residences and commercial buildings
located within 750 feet of the proposed oil, gas and/or salt water disposal
well(s) (measured from the center of where the well will actually be drilled
to the nearest part of the residence or commercial building) and such
proposed well will be located at least 200 feet from the nearest residence or
commercial building, then the applicant may request a public hearing before
the City Council to determine whether a variance to drill such oil, gas
and/or salt water disposal well(s) should be granted. The City Council may
grant or deny such application for such reasons as it might see fit.



   (C)   At least 20 days prior to such variance hearing, the applicant
shall by certified mail, return receipt requested, give notice of the date,
time and fact of such hearing to all owners of residences and commercial
buildings located within 750 feet of the proposed oil, gas and/or salt water
disposal well(s) who have not agreed in writing to such proposed well
drilling location, and publish notice, at least 20 days and not more than 30
days prior to such hearing, in a local newspaper in a form acceptable to the
city of the date, time and fact of such hearing. Proof of satisfaction of all
such notice requirements shall be provided to the Oil and Gas Inspector at
least ten days prior to such hearing.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.009)  (Ord. 07-04-03, passed 4-24-2007; Ord. 09-10-17,
passed 10-13-2009)



§ 116.010  DRIVEWAY APPROACH TO STREET FROM WELL LOCATION.



   (A)   No actual drilling operations shall be commenced on any oil,
gas or salt water disposal well until the driller and/or operator constructs
a driveway approach to any city street which the driller or operator, with
the approval of the City Public Service Director, intends to use to access
said well. Such driveway approach must be constructed of concrete with a
thickness of a minimum of five inches and with rebar reinforcement of a
minimum of three-eighths inch. Such concrete approach must be a minimum of 15
feet long (beginning at the edge of the paved street) and a minimum of 30
feet wide, and built according to the specifications furnished by the
City’s Public Service Director.



   (B)   Before reworking operations are begun on any currently
existing oil, gas or salt water disposal well, such driveway approach must be
constructed by the operator of such well.



   (C)   Such driveway approach must be constructed as provided above,
even though the driller or operator of such new well may elect to use a
driveway approach already in existence, unless the existing driveway approach
was constructed according to the above specifications, and is in acceptable
condition, as determined by the City Public Service Director.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.010)  (Ord. 11-06-07, passed 6-28-2011; Ord. 12-06-07,
passed 6-12-2012)  Penalty, see § 10.99




PERMIT




§ 116.025  REQUIRED.



   It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person, acting either for
himself or herself or acting as agent, employee, independent contractor or
servant of any other person, to commence to drill or to operate any well
within the city or to work upon or assist in any way in the prosecution or
operation of any such well without a permit for the drilling and operation of
such well having first been issued by the authority of the City Council in
accordance with the provisions of this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.036)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 116.026  APPLICATION.



   (A)   Every application for a permit to drill and operate an oil,
gas and/or salt water disposal well(s) shall be in writing, signed by the
applicant or by some person duly authorized to sign the same on his or her
behalf, and shall be filed with the City Secretary. No application shall
request a permit to drill and operate but one well.



   (B)   The application shall include full information, including the
following:



      (1)   The date of the application;



      (2)   Name of the applicant;



      (3)   Address of the applicant;



      (4)   Proposed site of the well, including:



         (a)   Name of the fee owner;



         (b)   Name of the lease owner; and



         (c)   Brief description of the land.



      (5)   Type of derrick to be used; and



      (6)   The proposed depth of the well pursuant to § 116.045.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.037)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)



§ 116.027  FILING FEE.



   Each application for a permit required by the provisions of this
subchapter shall be accompanied by a filing fee as provided in the fee
schedule.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.038)  (Ord. 09-05-06, passed 5-12-2009; Ord. 09-10-17,
passed 10-13-2009)



§ 116.028  ISSUANCE OR REFUSAL.



   (A)   The City Council, within 20 days after the filing of the
application for a permit to drill and operate an oil, gas and/or salt water
disposal well(s), shall determine whether or not such application complies in
all respects with the provisions of this chapter, and, if it does, the City
Council shall then fix the amount of the principal of the bond and insurance
provided for in § 116.029.



      (1)   After such determination, the Council shall issue a
permit for the drilling and operation of the well applied for.



      (2)   Each permit issued shall:



         (a)   By reference have incorporated therein all the
provisions of this chapter with the same force and effect as if this chapter
were copied verbatim in said permit;



         (b)   Specify the well location with particularity to
lot number, block number, name of addition or subdivision, or other available
correct legal description;



         (c)   Contain and specify that the term of such permit
shall be for a period of one year from the date of the permit and as long
thereafter as the permittee is engaged in drilling operations with no
cessation of such operations for more than 90 days, or oil or gas is produced
in commercial quantities from the well drilled pursuant to such permit, or
salt water disposed of into a salt water disposal well at least once every 90
days, provided that, if at any time after discovery of oil or gas the
production thereof in commercial quantities shall cease, the term shall not
terminate if the permittee commences additional reworking operations within
90 days thereafter, and if they result in the production of oil or gas, so
long thereafter as oil or gas is produced in commercial quantities from such
well;



         (d)   Contain and specify such conditions as are by this
chapter authorized;



         (e)   Specify the total depth to which the well may be
drilled, not exceeding the projected depth; and



         (f)   Contain and specify that no actual operations
shall be commenced until the permittee shall file and have approved an
indemnity bond in the designated principal amount as so determined by the
City Council and conditioned as specified in § 116.029.



   (B)   Such permit, in duplicate originals, shall be signed by the
City Secretary and, prior to delivery to the permittee, shall be signed by
the permittee (with one original to be retained by the city and one by the
permittee). When so signed the permit shall constitute the permittee’s
drilling and operating license and the contractual obligation of the
permittee to comply with the terms of such permit, and such bond, and this
chapter.



   (C)   If the permit for the well shall be refused, or if the
applicant notifies the City Council in writing that he or she does not elect
to accept the permit as tendered and wishes to withdraw his or her
application or if the bond of the applicant be not approved and the applicant
notifies the City Council in writing that he or she wishes to withdraw his or
her application, the cash deposit provided for to be filed with the
application shall be returned to the applicant, except that the city shall
retain a processing fee.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.039)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)



§ 116.029  INSURANCE AND BOND.



   (A)   In the event a permit is issued by the City Council under the
provisions of this subchapter for the drilling and operation of a well, no
actual drilling operations shall be commenced until the permittee shall file
with the City Secretary a bond and a certificate of insurance, as follows:



      (1)   A bond in the principal sum of such number of dollars as
has been so determined by the City Council, but not to be less than $50,000.
Such bond shall be a cash bond and running to the city for the benefit of the
city and all persons concerned, conditioned that the permittee will comply
with the terms and conditions of this chapter in the drilling and operation
of the well. Such bond shall become effective on or before the date the same
is filed with the City Secretary, and remain in force and effect for at least
a period of six months subsequent to the expiration of the term of the permit
issued, and, in addition, the bond will be conditioned that the permittee
will promptly pay off fines, penalties and other assessments imposed upon the
permittee by reason of his or her breach of any of the terms, provisions and
conditions of this chapter, and that the permittee will promptly restore the
streets and sidewalks and other public property of the city, which may be
disturbed or damaged in their operations, to their former condition; and that
the permittee will promptly clear all premises of all litter, trash, waste
and other substances used, allowed or occurring in the drilling or producing
operations, and will, after abandonment, grade, level and restore such
property to the same surface condition, as nearly as possible, as existed
when operations for the drilling of the well or wells were commenced; and
that the permittee will indemnify and hold the city harmless from any and all
liability growing out of or attributable to the granting of such permit. If,
at any time, the City Council shall deem any permittee’s bond to be
insufficient for any reason, it may require the permittee to replenish the
amount of cash on deposit with the city in order to restore the cash on
deposit to the amount of the original bond, or, if circumstances warrant,
increase the amount of such bond; and



      (2)   In addition to the bond required in division (A)(1)
above, the permittee shall carry a policy of standard comprehensive public
liability insurance, including contractual liability covering bodily injuries
and property damage, naming the permittee and the city, in an insurance
company authorized to do business within the state; such policy in the
aggregate shall provide for the following maximum coverages: general
liability of $2,000,000.



   (B)   The permittee shall file with the City Secretary certificates
of said insurance as above stated, and shall obtain the written approval
thereof by the City Secretary, who shall act thereon within ten days from the
date of such filing. Such insurance policy or policies shall not be cancelled
without written notice to the City Secretary at least ten days prior to the
effective date of such cancellation. In the event said insurance policy or
policies are cancelled, the permit granted shall terminate, and permittee’s
rights to operate under such permit shall cease until permittee files
additional insurance as provided herein. If, after completion of a well,
permittee has complied with all of the provisions of this chapter, such as
removing derrick, clearing premises and the like, he or she may apply to the
City Council to have such insurance policies reduced as follows:



      (1)   General liability of $1,000,000; and



      (2)   During reworking operations, the amount of the insurance
policy or policies shall be increased to the original amount.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.040)  (Ord. 11-06-07, passed 6-28-2011)



§ 116.030  TERMINATION.



   When a permit shall have been issued under the provisions of this
subchapter, the same shall terminate and become inoperative without any
action on the part of the city unless, within 90 days from the date of
issuance, actual drilling of the well shall have commenced. The cessation for
a like period of the drilling operations, or the cessation of the production
of oil and gas from the well after production shall have commenced, or
disposal of salt water in a salt water disposal well after such injection
shall have likewise commenced, shall operate to terminate and cancel the
permit, and the well shall be considered as abandoned for all purposes of
this chapter. It shall be unlawful thereafter to continue the operation or
drilling of such well without the issuance of another permit.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.041)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 116.031  ANNUAL USAGE FEE.



   Each driller and/or operator of an oil, gas and or salt water disposal
well(s) that uses one or more city streets to access such well(s) in any way,
his or her successors and assigns, shall pay an annual fee as provided for in
§ 35.40 or each such well, measured from the well or well site along the
city street to the state or county maintained highway or road over which
vehicles servicing that particular well primarily travel, for each oil, gas
and/or salt water disposal well within the city. Such street footage on which
said fee shall be assessed shall be the measurement from the center of the
roadway entrance to the well site to the nearest paved edge of said state or
county maintained highway or road. This fee shall be assessed against the
driller and/or operator, his or her successors and assigns, as to each oil,
gas and/or salt water disposal well(s) that has not been plugged and
abandoned, whether or not it has already been drilled, is in the process of
being drilled, or might be the subject of a future application for permit to
drill such a well, unless vehicles accessing such well or well site do not
obtain access to such well or well site by traveling at anytime on city
streets, alleys or other city owned passageways, in obtaining such access.
Said fee shall be assessed annually, beginning with the commencement of
operations to drill and operate such well and terminating when the well is
determined to be dry hole and abandoned or production has ceased and such
well is plugged and abandoned. Such fee shall be assessed against the driller
or operator of the well, his or her successors and assigns, by the tax
assessor collector of the city on each oil, gas and/or salt water disposal
well(s) referenced herein annually, on January 1 and be due and payable on or
before March 1 of that same year. Any fees not paid by said due date shall
bear the same interest and penalties as are provided for ad valorem taxes on
mineral interests and shall be subject to the same liens on property of the
permittee, its successors and assigns, and collection procedures as provided
for such ad valorem taxes in the Tax Code of the state. The payment of this
fee will in no manner relieve the driller or operator, his or her successors
or assigns, of any responsibility or liability for any and all damages to the
streets, curbs, gutters, water lines, fire hydrants and other city property
occasioned in any manner by the driller and/or operator, his or her successor
or assigns, in the drilling, operation or abandonment of each such well.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.042)  (Ord. 09-05-06, passed 5-12-2009; Ord. 09-10-17,
passed 10-13-2009; Ord. 12-06-07, passed 6-12-2012)




DRILLING REGULATIONS




§ 116.045  MAXIMUM DEPTH.



   It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to drill an oil, gas
and/or salt water disposal well(s) within the city limits to a true vertical
depth in excess of 12,000 feet, and no drilling and operating permit shall be
granted for any well to a true vertical depth in excess of 12,000 feet.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.061)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 116.046  PERMIT FOR DEEPER DRILLING.



   (A)   Once any oil, gas and/or salt water disposal well(s) has
either been completed as a producer or abandoned as a dry hole, it shall be
unlawful and an offense for any person to drill such well to a deeper depth
than that reached in the prior drilling operations without the permittee, as
to such well, obtaining a supplemental permit after filing a supplemental
application with the City Secretary, specifying:



      (1)   The then condition of the well and the casing therein;



      (2)   The depth to which it is proposed such well be deepened,
not to exceed in any event a total true vertical depth from the surface in
excess of 12,000 feet;



      (3)   The proposed casing program to be used in connection
with proposed deepening operations; and



      (4)   Evidence of adequate current tests showing that the
casing strings in such well currently pass the same tests as are in this
chapter provided for in the case of drilling the original well.



   (B)   In the event the City Council is satisfied that the well may
be deepened with the same degree of safety as existed in the original well, a
supplemental permit may be issued without an additional filing fee to the
permittee authorizing the deepening and operation of the well to such
specified depth as applied for, not exceeding in any event a total true
vertical depth from the surface in excess of 12,000 feet. In any deeper
drilling or any deeper completion or any deeper production operations, the
permittee shall comply with all other provisions contained in this chapter
and applicable to the drilling, completion and operation of a well or wells.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.062)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 116.047  DERRICK AND RIG.



   It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to use or operate,
in connection with the drilling or reworking of any oil, gas and/or salt
water disposal well(s) within the city limits, any wooden derrick or any
steam-powered rig, and all engines shall be equipped with adequate mufflers
approved by the Oil and Gas Inspector; or to permit any drilling rig or
derrick to remain on the premises or drilling site for a period longer than
60 days after completion or abandonment of the well. At all times from start
of erection of a derrick, or a mast, or a gin-pole, until the well is
abandoned and plugged or completed as a producer and enclosed with a fence as
herein provided, the permittee shall keep a watchman on duty on the premises
at all times; provided, however, it shall not be necessary to keep an extra
watchman on duty on the premises when other workmen of the permittee are on
the premises.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.063)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 116.048  PITS.



   Either earthen or steel slush pits shall be permitted in connection
with the drilling operation. In the event a steel pit is used, such pit and
its contents shall be removed from the premises and the drilling site within
30 days after completion of the well. In the event an earthen slush pit is
used, all mud shall be removed, and the pit shall be filled and leveled
within 30 days after completion of the well. No drilling mud or chemicals
shall be turned into any storm sewer or sanitary sewer.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.064)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)



§ 116.049  CASING.



   (A)   All casing, including surface protection and production
strings, shall be either seamless steel or equivalent quality oil well
casing. No lap weld casing will be permitted. Each production string of
casing must comply with at least the following minimum internal pressure
yield strength, computed in accordance with the A.P.I. standards:

2,720 pounds



3,400’ to 4,400’

4,400’ to 5,850’

5,850’ to 7,650’
