8,000’ to 10,005’
 


 

7,740 pounds





 



   (B)   Each joint and length of each particular casing string shall
have, prior to setting, unconditionally passed a complete cold water test.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.065)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)



§ 116.050  SETTING AND CEMENTING CASING.



   No well shall be drilled within the city limits without properly
setting ten-inch surface casing to a minimum depth of 1,000 feet. No well
shall be drilled within the city without cementing the surface casing by the
pump and plug method with sufficient cement to completely fill all of the
annular space behind such casing to the surface of the ground; and without
cementing the production string by the pump and plug method with sufficient
cement to completely fill all the annular space behind the production string
to at least 600 feet above the highest oil and/or gas bearing horizon; and in
the event a protection string of casing be required under the terms of this
chapter, without cementing the protection string by the pump and plug method
with sufficient cement to completely fill all the annular space behind the
protection string to at least 600 feet above the highest oil and/or gas
bearing horizon.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.066)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 116.051  VALVES AND BLOWOUT PREVENTERS.



   No well shall be drilled within the city limits without properly
equipping the surface casing when set with at least one master valve, and
without properly equipping the protection casing when set with at least one
master valve and one manual or fluid-operated ram type blowout preventer; and
without properly equipping the production casing during completion operations
and workover operations with at least one master valve and at least one
manual or fluid-operated ram type blowout preventer. On each well drilled, a
valve cock or kelly cock shall be installed on the kelly used. Each blowout
preventer shall test 6,000 pounds and its mechanical operation shall be
tested at least once every eight-hour period, and all control equipment shall
be in good working condition and order at all times.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.067)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 116.052  DRILLING FLUID.



   No well shall be drilled within the city limits without using mud as
the drilling fluid after the setting of surface casing as provided in §
116.050. Prior to the time the well reaches a total depth of 5,000 feet or
the depth of the first known or encountered oil or gas bearing horizon,
whichever is the lesser depth, the weight of the mud-laden drilling fluid
shall be at all times maintained at not less than ten pounds per gallon.
After the well reaches a total depth of 5,000 feet or the depth of the first
known or encountered oil or gas bearing horizon, whichever is the lesser
depth, the weight of the mud-laden drilling fluid shall be at all times
maintained at such weight as will provide a hydrostatic head of not less than
500 pounds per square inch in excess of the formation pressure. In reworking
a well, a drilling fluid shall be at all times maintained at such weight as
will provide a hydrostatic head of not less than 500 pounds per square inch
in excess of the formation pressure.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.068)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)



§ 116.053  DRILL STEM TESTS.



   It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person, in connection with
the drilling or reworking operations of any well within the city limits, to
take and to complete any drill test or tests, except during daylight hours,
and then only if the well effluent during the test is produced through an
adequate oil and gas separator to storage tanks, and the effluent remaining
in the drill pipe at the time the tool is closed is flushed to the surface by
circulating drilling fluid down the annulus and up the drill pipe.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.069)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 116.054  TUBING.



   All tubing used in any oil, gas and/or salt water disposal well(s)
within the city limits shall be seamless steel tubing having not less than a
minimum internal pressure yield strength of 5,280 pounds per square inch if
used in connection with a well completion at a depth not exceeding 7,000
feet, or less than a minimum internal pressure yield strength of 7,260 pounds
per square inch if used in connection with a well completion at a depth in
excess of 7,000 feet.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.070)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 116.055  BRADENHEAD.



   Each well drilled within the city limits shall be equipped with a
bradenhead with a working pressure of not less than 3,000 pounds per square
inch. Bradenheads shall not be welded. The bradenhead installed on the
surface casing shall be set above ground level and shall be equipped with a
fitting having a working pressure rating of not less than 3,000 pounds per
square inch. The bradenhead pressure shall be checked at least once each
calendar month and, if pressure is found to exist, proper remedial measures
shall be taken immediately to eliminate the source and the existence of the
pressure.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.071)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)



§ 116.056  CHRISTMAS TREE AND WELLHEAD CONNECTIONS.



   (A)   The Christmas tree and all wellhead connections on each well
drilled within the city limits shall be as follows.



      (1)   On all flowing wells completed at a depth of above 4,000
feet, the Christmas tree and wellhead connections shall have at least a
minimum working pressure of 2,000 pounds per square inch and a minimum test
pressure of at least 4,000 pounds per square inch.



      (2)   On all wells completed to a depth of from 4,001 to 7,000
feet, the Christmas tree and wellhead connections shall have at least a
minimum working pressure of 3,000 pounds per square inch and a minimum test
pressure of at least 6,000 pounds per square inch.



      (3)   On all wells completed below a depth of 7,000 feet, the
Christmas tree and wellhead connections shall be at least a minimum working
pressure of 5,000 pounds per square inch and a minimum test pressure of at
least 10,000 pounds per square inch.



   (B)   All piping and fittings connecting the wellhead to an oil and
gas separator shall have at least the same minimum working pressure and
minimum test pressure as herein above specified for Christmas tree and
wellhead connections.



   (C)   In the event the surface shut-in pressure of any well in the
city limits exceeds 2,000 pounds per square inch, the flowing of the
Christmas tree shall be equipped with an automatic closing safety valve in
addition to the regular control valves.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.072)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)



§ 116.057  MUFFLERS REQUIRED.



   Motive power for all operations after completion of drilling operations
shall be electricity or properly muffled gas, gasoline or diesel engines;
such mufflers to be approved by the Oil and Gas Inspector prior to their use.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.073)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)



§ 116.058  STORAGE TANKS AND SEPARATORS.



   It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to use, construct or
operate in connection with any producing well within the city limits any
storage tanks, except to the extent of two steel tanks not exceeding 500
barrels’ capacity each, and so constructed and maintained as to be
vapor-tight with connecting overflow, and each surrounded separately with an
earthen firewall at such distance and at such height as will, under any
circumstances, hold and retain at least one and one-half times the maximum
capacity of each tank. Separators shall be of high test of the minimum of
6,000 pounds and shall be equipped with both a regulation pressure relief
safety valve and a bursting head.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.074)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 116.059  VENTING AND FLARING OF GAS.



   No person engaged in drilling or operating any well shall permit gas to
escape or be vented in the air unless such gas is flared and burned. All gas
flared or burned from a torch, pipe or any other burning device within the
city limits must be done in such manner so as not to constitute a fire hazard
to any property; and the location of the torch, pipe or any other burning
device, the construction thereof, the maintenance thereof, and the operation
thereof, shall at all times be in full compliance with such regulations as
may, from time to time, be issued by the Oil and Gas Inspector.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.075)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 116.060  ABANDONMENT AND PLUGGING.



   Whenever any well is abandoned, it shall be the obligation of the
permittee and the operator of the well to set a 200-foot cement plug in the
bottom of the surface casing with the bottom of the plug 100 feet below the
surface casing section, and the top of the plug 100 feet above the surface
casing section; and to set a 50-foot cement plug in the top of the surface
casing. No surface or conductor string of casing may be pulled or removed
from a well. During initial abandonment operations, it will be the obligation
of the permittee and the operator of the well to flood the well with
mud-laden fluid weighing not less than ten pounds per gallon, and the well
will be kept filled to the top with mud-laden fluid at all times; mud-laden
fluid of the above specifications will be left in the well bore below and
between cement plugs. Any additional provisions or precautionary measures
prescribed by the state or the state railroad commission in connection with
the abandonment and plugging of a well shall be complied with by the
permittee.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.076)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)



§ 116.061  DISPOSAL OF SALT WATER.



   The permittee shall make adequate provisions for the disposal of all
salt water or other impurities which he or she may bring to the surface, and
such disposal to be made in such manner as to not contaminate the water
supply, present or prospective, or to injure surface vegetation.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.077)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)




POLLUTION CONTROL




§ 116.075  DEFINITION.



   For the purposes of this subchapter, the phrase THE WATERSHED or SOURCE
OF WATER SUPPLY OF THE CITY is defined to be all areas of the freshwater
sands commonly known as the Carrizo Sand and Wilcox Sand from or through
which water flows or percolates to the wells maintained and operated by the
city as the source of its water supply within the city limits and within
5,000 feet of the city limits.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.101)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)



§ 116.076  APPLICATION OF SUBCHAPTER PROVISIONS.



   All wells or holes of any type or size drilled through the impervious
stratum beneath the Wilcox Sand within the city limits shall conform to the
terms of this subchapter except that the City Council may, in its discretion,
waive all or any part of the permit fee and bond and insurance requirements
of this subchapter insofar as applicable to wells or holes drilled solely for
exploration purposes and not suitable for production of oil, gas or other
minerals.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.102)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)



§ 116.077  APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS WITHIN 5,000 FEET OF CITY LIMITS.



   As to all wells or holes to which this subchapter is applicable,
located within 5,000 feet outside of the city limits, the driller or person
responsible for such operation shall give written notice of the location and
proposed depth of such well or hole to the Oil and Gas Inspector.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.103)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)



§ 116.078  PREREQUISITES WHEN WELL IS WITHIN 5,000 FEET OF CITY LIMITS.



   Before any oil, gas and/or salt water disposal well(s) or hole to which
this chapter may be applicable is commenced outside of, but within, 5,000
feet of the city limits, the driller or person responsible for such operation
shall furnish the Oil and Gas Inspector with complete, full and accurate
information as to the location and proposed depth of such well or hole and
shall pay to the city a fee as provided in § 35.40 to defray its expenses in
connection with the inspection of such operations to determine their
compliance herewith and that all laws and regulations for the protection of
the city’s water supply are properly observed.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.104)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)



§ 116.079  INSPECTOR’S RIGHT OF ENTRY.



   The Oil and Gas Inspector shall have the right to inspect all drilling,
digging or excavating operations to which this chapter may be applicable as
frequently and to such extent as may be necessary to ensure full compliance
with the terms of this chapter.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.105)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)



§ 116.080  POLLUTION PROHIBITED.



   All operations under the provisions of this chapter shall be conducted
in such a manner as to assure that there will be no interference with or
pollution of any of the sands or strata from which the water supply of the
city or of any individual or corporation in the city is produced. The
pollution of the watershed or source of water supply of the city shall be a
violation of this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.106)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 116.081  SETTING OF SURFACE CASING.



   It shall be unlawful to drill, dig or excavate any well or hole of any
size or type penetrating the first impervious stratum below the Wilcox Sand
at any location within the watershed or source of water supply of the city
unless surface casing shall be set into the first impervious stratum or shale
body immediately below the lowest freshwater producing sands and cemented
with sufficient cement to fill the annular space back of the casing to the
surface. This is to mean that if it is necessary to set additional casing in
excess of the 1,000 feet provided for in § 116.050 to protect the water
producing sands, said casing shall be set to required depth according to the
rules of the State Railroad Commission and/or the State Board of Water
Engineers. Such surface casing shall be set into the impervious stratum as
shown by electric log, copy of which shall be furnished to the Oil and Gas
Inspector after the setting of such casing, and such casing shall be set at a
point within such impervious stratum, approved by the Inspector. Cementing
shall be by pump and plug method, Halliburton method or equal. Cement shall
be allowed to stand a minimum of 24 hours under pressure and a total of 48
hours before drilling the plug or commencing deeper operations. All casing
used hereunder shall be of standard type and weight, approved by the
Inspector and such casing must be in such condition as is acceptable to the
Inspector.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.107)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 116.082  NOTICE, PROCEDURE UPON DRILLING TO WILCOX SAND.



   When any oil, gas and/or salt water disposal well(s) or hole being
drilled within the watershed or source of water supply of the city reaches
the impervious stratum below the Wilcox Sand, immediate notice of the
reaching of such stratum shall be given to the Oil and Gas Inspector, and an
electric log of the well or hole to the bottom of such impervious stratum
shall be given to the Inspector. No further drilling operations shall be
conducted until the casing required under this chapter has been set and
cemented as required herein, and a copy of the report or certificate of the
cementing company has been furnished to the Inspector.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.108)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 116.083  NONCONFORMING WELLS DECLARED NUISANCE.



   All oil, gas and/or salt water disposal well(s) or holes, and the
drilling, digging and excavating thereof below the impervious stratum below
the Wilcox Sand, which is the lowest known freshwater-producing sand used by
the city, without the setting and cementing of casing as required herein, are
hereby individually and severally declared to be a nuisance, and future
operations thereon may be enjoined on application of the city by any court
having jurisdiction over such cases. The application of any penal provision
for the violation of this chapter shall not preclude the enforcement hereof
by injunction.



(Prior Code, § 4.03.109)  (Ord. 09-10-17, passed 10-13-2009)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



CHAPTER 117:  SOLICITORS



Section




General Provisions




   117.01   Purpose



   117.02   Definitions



   117.03   Solicitation by minors



   117.04   Restrictions on activity



   117.05   Solicitation from vehicle




Registration




   117.20   Required



   117.21   Application



   117.22   Bond



   117.23   Application review and acceptance



   117.24   Issuance of certificate and identification badge



   117.25   Revocation or suspension



   117.26   Appeal of denial, revocation or suspension



 



   117.99   Penalty



Statutory reference:



   Authority of municipality to license, tax, suppress, prevent or
otherwise regulate peddlers, hawkers and pawnbrokers, see Tex. Local Gov’t
Code, § 215.031




GENERAL PROVISIONS




§ 117.01  PURPOSE.



   The purpose of this chapter is to:



   (A)   Protect the citizens against deceptive practices and fraud;



   (B)   Minimize the unwelcome disturbance of citizens and the
disruption of citizens’ privacy; and



   (C)   Preserve the public health, safety and general welfare by
registering and regulating solicitors.



(Prior Code, § 4.07.001)



§ 117.02  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   CITY OFFICIAL.  The city official designated to issue registration
certificates and enforce this chapter.



   HANDBILL. Any printed or written matter, any sample or device, dodger,
circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet or any other printed or otherwise
reproduced original or copies of any matter.



   INTERSTATE COMMERCE.  Soliciting, selling or taking orders for or
offering to take orders for any goods, wares or merchandise, or acting in any
function as a solicitor, which, at the time the order is taken, are in or
will be produced in any federal district or territory, any commonwealth or
any state other than this state and shipped or introduced into this city in
the fulfillment of such orders.



   MINOR.  A person under the age of 18.



   NONPROFIT ORGANIZATION. An organization or entity that is exempt from
the payment of tax pursuant to I.R.C. § 501(c)(3).



   POLICE CHIEF.  The Police Chief or the Police Chief’s designated
representative.



   SELLING.  To sell, dispense, peddle, hawk, display, offer to sell or
solicit for sale by offering or exposing for sale any goods, wares,
merchandise or services.



   SOLICITATION ACTIVITIES.  Traveling either by foot or vehicle, going
door to door, house to house or building to building personally contacting
persons to ask, barter or communicate in any manner, whether orally, by
written or printed materials, including but not limited to handbills or
leaflets, hand signing or by any other method, direct or implied, for the
purpose of selling or taking orders for goods, wares, merchandise or services
or collecting money for any purpose. The term does not include:



      (1)   The activity of a salesperson with an appointment
calling upon or dealing with manufacturers, wholesalers, distributors,
brokers or retailers at their places of business or homes and in the usual
course of business;



      (2)   The activity of a person acting on behalf of an
organization that is only directed at the members of the organization; or



      (3)   The activity of a person collecting money or soliciting
funds only from foundations.



   SOLICITOR.  A person who engages in solicitation activities.



(Prior Code, § 4.07.002)



§ 117.03  SOLICITATION BY MINORS.



   (A)   A minor who conducts solicitation activities shall be
sponsored or employed by a person over the age of 18, a corporation, firm or
organization. The person, corporation, firm or organization that is
sponsoring or employing the minor is responsible for controlling the conduct
of the minor, and the minor shall be under the constant supervisor of a
person 18 years of age or older.



   (B)   A person, corporation, firm or organization that sponsors or
employs one or more minors as solicitors may submit one application and pay
one nonrefundable application fee for the registration of the minors,
regardless of the number of minors who conduct solicitation activities. The
sponsor or employer shall provide the city official the names, dates of
birth, addresses and driver’s license numbers, if applicable, and a
notarized parental consent for each minor who will be conducting solicitation
activities. The parental consent form, which shall be provided by the city
official, shall acknowledge the release of the information set forth above,
and shall state that the city is authorized to photograph the minor child.



   (C)   An exception to divisions (A) and (B) above shall be any minor
soliciting under the supervision of a school, church or any other 501(c)3
qualified organization.



(Prior Code, § 4.07.004)



§ 117.04  RESTRICTIONS ON ACTIVITY.



   (A)   A person commits an offense if the person engages in
solicitation activity at a residence before 8:30 a.m. or after 9:00 p.m.



   (B)   A person commits an offense if the person engages in
solicitation activity at a premises with a posted notice that such activity
is not welcomed or invited. It shall be presumed that there is notice that
solicitation activity is not welcomed or invited when there is exhibited in a
conspicuous place, on or near the main entrance of the premises, a sign, not
less than four inches by three inches in size, containing the words “no
solicitors”, “no trespassing” or words of similar meaning in letters
not less than two-thirds of one inch in height.



   (C)   A person, who is not the owner or tenant of a residence,
commits an offense if the person removes, defaces or otherwise renders
illegible a sign placed by the owner or tenant of the residence pursuant to
division (B) above.



   (D)   A person commits an offense if the person engages in
solicitation activities and remains or lingers on a premises after being
informed by the owner or tenant that he or she is not welcome.



   (E)   A person commits an offense if the person engages in
solicitation activities in an aggressive or intimidating manner. The term
AGGRESSIVE OR INTIMIDATING MANNER means:



      (1)   Blocking the path of a person who is the object of the
activity; or



      (2)   Following behind, ahead or alongside a person who walks
away from the solicitor after being solicited, approached, accosted or
offered a handbill, leaflet or any other item.



   (F)   A person commits an offense if the person solicits edible
merchandise without keeping all articles for sale to the public as well as
the wagons, vehicles or other conveyances used in the transportation of such
merchandise in a clean and sanitary condition.



   (G)   A person commits an offense if that person sells or offers to
sell any unsound or unwholesome merchandise or give a false weight or measure
to such offered for sale.



(Prior Code, § 4.07.005)



§ 117.05  SOLICITATION FROM VEHICLE.



   (A)   A person commits an offense if the person conducts
solicitation activities from a vehicle and:



      (1)   The solicitation is conducted at a location within the
right-of-way of any street or highway in the city which is designated as an
arterial or collector on the city’s thoroughfare plan; or



      (2)   The person stops the vehicle within a roadway to conduct
business before the vehicle has been approached, called or waved down by a
prospective customer.



   (B)   A person commits an offense if the person operates a vehicle
from which solicitation activities are conducted upon any street or highway
within the city in a manner that blocks or impedes access to or from any
alley, street or driveway or impedes the flow of traffic on any public street
or highway.



(Prior Code, § 4.07.006)  Penalty, see § 117.99




REGISTRATION




§ 117.20  REQUIRED.



   (A)   A person commits an offense if the person engages in
solicitation activities in the city without first registering with the city
official and obtaining a registration certificate and city-issued
identification badge from the city.



   (B)   A registration certificate shall be valid for one year
following the date of its issuance, unless a shorter period is requested by
the applicant.



   (C)   An applicant for a registration certificate shall pay a
nonrefundable application fee at the time the application is submitted and,
if required, shall submit a bond.



   (D)   The amount of the nonrefundable application fee shall be as
established by the City Council and on file in the City Secretary’s office.
The nonrefundable application fee shall be used for the purpose of defraying
administrative expenses incident to the issuing of registration certificates
and identification badges.



   (E)   A nonprofit organization, a person conducting solicitation
activity on behalf of a nonprofit organization or a person engaged in
interstate commerce is exempt from payment of the application fee.



(Prior Code, § 4.07.031)  Penalty, see § 117.99



§ 117.21  APPLICATION.



   (A)   A person desiring to conduct solicitation activities within
the city shall make a written application on a form provided by the city
official for a registration certificate.



   (B)   The application shall contain or be submitted with the
following information:



      (1)   The full name, date of birth, phone number and address
of the applicant;



      (2)   A valid state driver’s license number or a
state-approved identification card number of the applicant (the city will
make a photocopy and attach it to the application);



      (3)   If a vehicle is used to conduct the solicitation
activity, a description of each vehicle, its license plate number and vehicle
identification number, and the name and license number of the driver who will
operate each vehicle;



      (4)   Copies of all such licenses and permits which, under
federal, state or local laws or regulations, the applicant is required to
have in order to conduct the proposed solicitation;



      (5)   If the applicant is acting as an employee, agent or
volunteer, the name and physical street address (not a post office box) and
telephone number of the employer, principal or organization, with credentials
in written form establishing the relationship and authority of the employee,
agent or volunteer to act for the employer, principal or organization;



      (6)   If applicable, the merchandise to be sold or offered for
sale or the nature of the services to be furnished;



      (7)   The approximate time period within which the
solicitation is to be made, stating the date of the beginning of the
solicitation activity, its projected conclusion and the proposed dates and
times of solicitation;



      (8)   Whether the applicant, upon any order obtained, will
demand, accept or receive payment or the deposit of money in advance of final
delivery and, if so, a copy of the bond required by § 117.22;



      (9)   If the applicant, the applicant’s employer or
principal or minor solicitor who is 17 years of age or older has plead
guilty, or nolo contendere to, or has been convicted of a felony or
misdemeanor involving fraud, deceit, misrepresentation, within five years
preceding the date of application, a description of each such conviction or
plea and the date of the offense;



      (10)   If the solicitation activity is to be conducted on
behalf of a nonprofit organization, proof of such status shall be attached to
the application; and



      (11)   If the applicant is an entity or organization that
sponsors or employs minors as solicitors and is submitting one application
for those minors, the information set forth in § 117.03(B).



(Prior Code, § 4.07.032)  Penalty, see § 117.99



§ 117.22  BOND.



   (A)   Solicitors who require cash deposits or advance payments for
future delivery of goods or for services to be performed in the future or who
require an agreement to finance the sale of goods for future delivery or for
services to be performed in the future shall furnish to the city a bond with
the application in the amount determined in division (C) below, signed by the
applicant and a surety company authorized to do business in the state:



      (1)   Conditioned upon the final delivery of goods or services
in accordance with the terms of any order obtained;



      (2)   To indemnify purchasers for defects in material or
workmanship that may exist in the goods sold and that are discovered within
30 days after delivery; and



      (3)   For the use and benefit of persons, firms or
corporations that may make a purchase or give an order to the principal of
the bond or to the agent or employee of the principal of the bond.



   (B)   If a person, firm or corporation is engaging in solicitation
activities through one or more agents, employees or volunteers, only one bond
is required for the activities of all the agents, employees or volunteers.



   (C)   The amount of the bond is determined by the number of
solicitors as follows:



 


(1)

 
1 to 3 solicitors
 

$500




(2)

 
4 to 6 solicitors
 

$750




(3)

 
7 or more solicitors
 

$1,000




 



(Prior Code, § 4.07.033)



§ 117.23  APPLICATION REVIEW AND ACCEPTANCE.



   (A)   Upon receipt of an application, the city official shall review
the application to ensure compliance with this chapter.



   (B)   The city official shall authorize the registration within 30
days of receipt of the application unless:



      (1)   An investigation reveals that the applicant or the
applicant’s employer, principal or organization falsified information on
the application;



      (2)   Within five years preceding the date of application, the
applicant or the applicant’s employer, principal or organization has plead
guilty or nolo contendere to, or has been convicted of, a felony or
misdemeanor involving fraud, deceit or misrepresentation;



      (3)   A judgment based upon fraud, deceit or misrepresentation
has been entered against the applicant or the applicant’s employer,
principal or organization within five years preceding the date of application;



      (4)   The applicant provided no proof of authority to act on
behalf of the employer, principal or organization;



      (5)   The type of solicitation activity requires a bond, and
the applicant or the applicant’s employer, principal or organization has
not complied with the bond requirements; or



      (6)   The application does not contain the information or
documents required by § 117.21.



   (C)   The denial and the reasons for the denial shall be noted on
the application, and the applicant shall be notified of the denial by notice
mailed to the applicant and the applicant’s employer, principal or
organization at the address shown on the application or the last known
address. The notice of denial shall be mailed within 30 days of the receipt
of the application.



(Prior Code, § 4.07.034)



§ 117.24  ISSUANCE OF CERTIFICATE AND IDENTIFICATION BADGE.



   (A)   Upon authorization of the registration, the city official
shall deliver a registration certificate and identification badge for each
solicitor, and shall forward a copy of the certificate to the Police Chief.



   (B)   The registration certificate shall show:



      (1)   The name and address of the solicitor;



      (2)   The solicitor’s employer, principal or organization,
if applicable;



      (3)   The kind of goods or services to be sold or offered for
sale, if applicable;



      (4)   A description and license plate number of any vehicle to
be used in carrying out the solicitation activities, if applicable;



      (5)   A registration number; and



      (6)   The dates of issuance and expiration of the certificate.



   (C)   The original or a copy of the registration certificate must be
carried by a solicitor while engaged in solicitation activities.



   (D)   The identification badge issued by the city shall be worn by a
solicitor while engaging in solicitation activities so that it may be easily
read by those being solicited. Lost or damaged badges may be replaced for a
nonrefundable fee per badge.



   (E)   A registration certificate and an identification badge shall
be used only by the solicitor to whom they were issued and may not be
transferred to another person.



(Prior Code, § 4.07.035)



§ 117.25  REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION.



   A registration certificate issued pursuant to this subchapter may be
revoked or suspended by the city official, after notice and hearing, for any
of the following reasons:



   (A)   Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the
application for registration;



   (B)   Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made by a
solicitor in the course of conducting solicitation activities;



   (C)   Plea or conviction of a crime described in § 117.23(B)(2);



   (D)   A judgment involving a matter described in § 117.23(B)(3); or



   (E)   A violation of the regulations described in § 117.04.



(Prior Code, § 4.07.036)



§ 117.26  APPEAL OF DENIAL, REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION.



   (A)   A person who is denied a registration certificate or whose
registration is revoked or suspended by the city official may appeal the
decision to the City Council by filing notice of appeal with the city
official within 15 days after the notice of the decision is mailed to the
address indicated on the application or the last known address.



   (B)   Within ten days of the receipt of the notice of appeal, the
city official shall set a time and place for a hearing on the appeal which
shall be not later than 40 days from the date of receipt of the notice of
appeal.



   (C)   Notice of the time and place of the hearing shall be delivered
to the person by mail, sent to the address indicated on the application or
the last known address of the appellant.



   (D)   The decision of the City Council on the appeal is final. No
other administrative procedures are provided by the city.



(Prior Code, § 4.07.037)



§ 117.99  PENALTY.



   Any person, firm or corporation who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects
or refuses to comply with or who resists the enforcement of any of the
provisions of this chapter shall be fined as provided in § 10.99. Each day a
solicitor engages in solicitation activities without having obtained a
registration certificate or in which a continuing violation occurs shall be a
separate offense.



(Prior Code, § 4.07.003)



CHAPTER 118:  PRECIOUS METAL AND GEM DEALERS



Section



   118.01   Definitions



   118.02   Permit required



   118.03   Permit issuance



   118.04   Bond required



   118.05   Permit not transferable



   118.06   Records of purchases



   118.07   Holding period required



   118.08   Purchases at temporary locations



§ 118.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   BUSINESS.  An activity carried on by any person who buys from or
trades with the public for used jewelry, money, silverware or precious metal,
as defined in this section, for profit. The term BUSINESS shall not include
occasional purchases, sales or trades made by a hobbyist, nor shall it
include activities regulated by the Texas Pawnshop Act (Tex. Finance Code,
Ch. 371). Further, the term BUSINESS shall not include either banks or
dealers in gold or silver bullion, including minted bullion.



   DEALER.  Any person who buys or trades for used jewelry, money,
silverware or precious metal in the course of business.



   MONEY.  Money which has numismatic value.



   PERMITTEE.  A dealer who has been issued a permit hereunder.



   PRECIOUS GEMS.  Includes, but is not limited to, such gems as
diamonds, sapphires, rubies, emeralds and pearls.



   PRECIOUS METAL.  Gold, silver or platinum.



   SEMIPRECIOUS GEMS.  Includes, but is not limited to, such gems as
jade, tanzanite, tsavorite garnets and aquamarines.



   SILVERWARE.  Silver or silver-plated flatware, trays, goblets, dishes
or serving pieces.



   TEMPORARY LOCATION.  Any place or premises which has not been hired,
rented or leased for at least 30 days, in, upon and from which business is
conducted.



   USED JEWELRY.  Previously owned articles made from precious metals or
precious or semiprecious gems, or any combination thereof, and includes such
personal ornaments as watches, earrings, rings, pendants, chains, fobs,
broaches and necklaces.



(Prior Code, § 4.05.001)



Statutory reference:



   Sale of crafted precious metal to dealers, see Tex. Occupations Code,
§§ 1956.051 et seq.



§ 118.02  PERMIT REQUIRED.



   (A)   Any dealer who engages in the business of buying or trading
for used jewelry, money, silverware or precious metal shall possess a valid
permit issued in accordance with this chapter before engaging in such
business within the city. A dealer doing business at more than one location
within the city shall obtain a permit for each location. Additional permits
shall be issued with charge.



   (B)   Any person desiring such a permit shall make application in
writing to the Chief of Police on a form provided for that purpose. Such form
shall be sufficient if it includes the following information:



      (1)   Name, date of birth, address and business telephone
number of applicant and all employees;



      (2)   Business address of applicant;



      (3)   Normal business hours during which business will be
conducted;



      (4)   Location or locations where business will be conducted;



      (5)   Whether or not the applicant, or any co-principal or
employee has been found guilty of any criminal offense as defined in Tex.
Penal Code, Title 7, or its equivalent in another state, by any court of
competent jurisdiction and, if so, the place where convicted and the penalty
imposed;



      (6)   Whether or not the applicant has been or is currently a
party to any civil litigation arising out of sales or purchases of any goods
or services and, if so, the identity of other parties to the suit, the
location of the suit, and the status or outcome of the suit;



      (7)   Whether the applicant has ever before engaged in
business under an assumed name and, if so, the name assumed by such business;
and



      (8)   The place within the city where the jewelry, money,
silverware, precious metal or semiprecious gems are to be stored in
accordance with § 118.07.



   (C)   Any permittee who employs any person to engage in business and
whose name does not appear on such permittee’s current application on file
with the Police Department shall, within three business days of such
employment, amend such application in writing to reflect the addition of such
employee.



   (D)   In the event the permittee desires to operate outside of the
normal business hours specified in the permit, he or she shall notify the
Chief of Police in writing in advance of such operation.



   (E)   It shall be unlawful to knowingly give false information on an
application.



(Prior Code, § 4.05.002)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 118.03  PERMIT ISSUANCE.



   (A)   Upon receipt of the application, the Chief of Police shall
issue a permit upon the payment of a fee which is on file in the City
Secretary’s office. No permit shall be issued to any applicant if the
applicant has been found guilty by a court of competent jurisdiction within
the preceding ten years of the violation of any provision of this chapter or
of a criminal offense against property as defined in Tex. Penal Code, Title
7, provided further that violation of any provision of this chapter shall be
grounds for denial of such permit. Permits issued hereunder shall be valid
for a period of one year from the date of issuance.



   (B)   A permit issued hereunder may be revoked, or suspended, for up
to six months by the Chief of Police for violation of any provision of this
chapter or if a permittee is found guilty of a criminal offense as defined in
Tex. Penal Code, Title 7, or its criminal equivalent in another state, by a
court of competent jurisdiction. A permit that has been revoked or suspended
shall not be reissued unless the applicant is currently qualified under the
terms of this chapter to receive a permit. A permit shall be revoked if the
permittee fails to meet any of the necessary qualifications to receive a
permit. Within ten days of such revocation or suspension by the Chief of
Police, the permittee shall have the right of appeal to the City Council
whose decision shall be final. A written statement setting forth the basis
for such appeal shall be filed with the City Secretary within the ten-day
time period.



   (C)   Upon receipt of an application, the Chief of Police may, upon
request, issue a temporary permit upon the payment of a fee which is on file
in the City Secretary’s office which shall be issued upon the same terms
and conditions as one-year permits, but which shall only be valid for 30 days
from the date of issuance.



   (D)   Any permit issued hereunder shall be prominently displayed at
the place of business so as to be plainly visible by persons transacting
business with a dealer.



(Prior Code, § 4.05.003)



§ 118.04  BOND REQUIRED.



   A bond in the sum of not less than $5,000 cash or a surety bond through
a solvent surety company authorized to do business in the state, executed by
the applicant for a permit or by his or her authorized representative,
conditioned that the principal and surety shall pay to any person all damages
caused by or arising out of the wrongful, fraudulent or illegal conduct of
the applicant or his or her agents or employees while conducting business
under this chapter, shall be required prior to the issuance of any permit
hereunder. Such bond shall remain in full force and effect during the permit
period. Failure to maintain a sufficient bond shall be grounds for the
revocation or suspension of any permit.



(Prior Code, § 4.05.004)



§ 118.05  PERMIT NOT TRANSFERABLE.



   A permit granted under this chapter shall not be transferable.



(Prior Code, § 4.05.005)



§ 118.06  RECORDS OF PURCHASES.



   (A)   Upon the purchase from or trade with any person of any goods
defined in this chapter, permittees shall record in a well-bound book kept
exclusively for such purpose the following information:



      (1)   The name, address, age, sex, race, height, weight, color
of hair and driver’s license number or personal identification certificate
issued by the State Department of Public Safety of the person selling or
trading any used jewelry, money, silverware or precious metal; and



      (2)   A description of the property purchased, including the
name of the maker and serial number, if available, and all other identifiable
characteristics, such as type, number and size of gems and type and color of
metal.



   (B)   No permittee shall purchase or trade for any used jewelry,
coins, silverware or precious metal from any person or persons under the age
of 17 years.



   (C)   The permittee purchasing used jewelry, coins, silverware or
precious metal shall obtain a signed warranty from the seller that the seller
has the right or authority to sell the property, which statement shall be
retained and recorded by the permittee.



   (D)   All books and records required to be kept under the terms
herein shall be open to inspection at all reasonable hours by any bona fide
peace officer.



   (E)   All books and records required to be kept under the terms
herein shall be maintained continuously at the permittee’s place of
business for a minimum of two years.



(Prior Code, § 4.05.006)



§ 118.07  HOLDING PERIOD REQUIRED.



   No dealer shall sell, trade, dispose of or alter the form of any
precious metal or jewelry unless at least ten working days have elapsed since
the purchase of such goods. For purposes of this section, WORKING DAYS shall
be defined as Monday through Friday, exclusive of such days recognized as
national holidays. A record shall be kept of all items sold, traded or
otherwise disposed of.



(Prior Code, § 4.05.007)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 118.08  PURCHASES AT TEMPORARY LOCATIONS.



   Any dealer who conducts business from a temporary location within the
city and who does not maintain a permanent location within the city shall
furnish a forwarding address and deliver the records of purchases to the
Chief of Police within 24 hours of terminating the temporary location.



(Prior Code, § 4.05.008)



CHAPTER 119:  WRECKER SERVICE



Section




General Provisions




   119.01   Definitions



   119.02   Power and duties of Chief of Police



   119.03   Obligation of Police Department and wrecker service to
customer



   119.04   Method of determining rotation services



   119.05   Dispatch procedures



   119.06   Impounded and abandoned vehicles



   119.07   Removal of debris at accident scene



   119.08   No wrecker at scene unless called by police or owner of
vehicle



   119.09   Solicitation of wrecker business prohibited



   119.10   City employees not to recommend wrecker service



   119.11   Applicability of provisions



   119.12   Rates posted with Chief of Police



   119.13   Authority in event of emergency




License




   119.25   Required for all rotation wrecker services



   119.26   Application; required information



   119.27   Required insurance



   119.28   Required equipment for police rotation



   119.29   Action on application



   119.30   Required fees; expiration



   119.31   Number displayed; sticker



   119.32   Denial or refusal



   119.33   Suspension for failure to provide insurance



   119.34   Suspension or revocation, generally



   119.35   Procedure; appeal



Cross-reference:



   General business provisions, see Chapter 110




GENERAL PROVISIONS




§ 119.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   DISABLED VEHICLE.  A vehicle which has been rendered unsafe to be
driven as a result of some occurrence other than a wreck, including, but not
limited to, mechanical failures or breakdowns, fire, vandalism or a vehicle
which is in an unsafe driving condition, but the owner is not present or able
or permitted to drive so as to reasonably necessitate that the vehicle be
removed by a wrecker.



   FIT AND PROPER PERSON.  A person not convicted of a felony, any crime
of moral turpitude, or of a driving while intoxicated offense, as defined by
Tex. Penal Code, § 49.04.



   LICENSEE.  A person licensed to engage in the wrecker police rotation
service.



   OFFICE.  A building with the company name of the applicant affixed to
the front and with a telephone installed with the licensee’s telephone
number.



   VEHICLE.  Every device in, upon or by which any person or property is
or may be transported or drawn upon a street except devices moved by human
power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks.



   WRECKED VEHICLE.  A vehicle that has been damaged as a result of
overturning or colliding with another vehicle or object(s) so as to
reasonably necessitate that the vehicle be removed by a wrecker.



   WRECKER.  A vehicle designed to be used primarily for removing wrecked
or disabled vehicles.



   WRECKER SERVICE.  The business of towing, moving or removing wrecked
or disabled vehicles for compensation, regardless of whether the purpose for
removal is to repair, wreck, store, trade or purchase such wrecked or
disabled vehicles.



(Prior Code, § 4.11.001)



Statutory reference:



   Tow trucks, see Tex. Occupations Code, Ch. 2308



§ 119.02  POWER AND DUTIES OF CHIEF OF POLICE.



   The Chief of Police of the city shall:



   (A)   Adopt and enforce reasonable written rules and regulations for
wreckers where necessary to implement this chapter;



   (B)   Inspect the offices, storage lots and wrecker equipment of
each licensee as deemed necessary by the Chief of Police, in his or her sole
discretion, to administer and enforce all provisions of this chapter;



   (C)   Keep records of all license applications and wrecker licenses
denied, issued, suspended or revoked; and



   (D)   Administer and enforce this chapter and issue, suspend and
revoke licenses as required by this chapter.



(Prior Code, § 4.11.002)



§ 119.03  OBLIGATION OF POLICE DEPARTMENT AND WRECKER SERVICE TO CUSTOMER.



   (A)   Generally. Any vehicle owner or operator request for a
particular wrecker service must be adhered to by the Police Department and
wrecker service, so long as it does not violate this chapter or the state tow
truck regulations or rules promulgated by the state pursuant to such
regulations. Such request shall be adhered to as long as it does not create
or unreasonably extend the time of a public hazard such as a vehicle or an
abandoned vehicle in the roadway. It shall be the investigating officer’s
responsibility to determine if the requested wrecker service responds within
a reasonable time, depending upon the degree of hazard the public is
subjected to. In any event the response time shall not be more than 20
minutes from time of dispatch.



   (B)   Exception. Division (A) above shall not be construed to
prohibit the consented to transportation by any wrecker service company of a
wrecked or disabled vehicle from any point within the city to any point
inside or outside the city, nor shall it be construed to prohibit the
transportation of a wrecked or disabled vehicle from a point outside the city
to a point inside the city.



(Prior Code, § 4.11.003)



§ 119.04  METHOD OF DETERMINING ROTATION SERVICES.



   The Chief of Police shall see that a list of all licensed rotation
wrecker services is furnished to all police dispatchers for the purpose of
dispatching wreckers. The rotation device to be used as a means of
determining which wrecker service is called shall be designed by the Chief of
Police. This device will allow all calls to be divided equally among the
licensee wrecker services on rotation.



(Prior Code, § 4.11.004)



§ 119.05  DISPATCH PROCEDURES.



   (A)   When a police officer investigates an accident or disabled
vehicle in the city and determines that any vehicle involved should be
removed by a wrecker, the officer shall first determine whether the owner,
operator or his or her authorized representative has already made
arrangements for its removal.



   (B)   If no arrangements have been made, the investigating officer
will cause the following steps to be taken in sequence to expedite the
removal of the vehicle.



      (1)   The officer shall request that the operator or other
vehicle occupant designate the place to which he or she desires the vehicle
removed.



      (2)   The officer shall request that the operator of the
vehicle or other vehicle occupant designate which wrecker service he or she
desires to remove and transport the vehicle.



      (3)   The officer shall then immediately notify the police
dispatcher of the information contained in divisions (B)(1) and (B)(2) above,
and the dispatcher shall immediately notify the wrecker operator selected and
shall give him or her the necessary information and direct that he or she
immediately proceed to the scene of the accident; provided that the wrecker
service is licensed by the state.



      (4)   If for any reason no wrecker operator is selected, the
officer shall notify the police dispatcher and the dispatcher shall direct a
wrecker operator on the police rotation list to go to the scene and remove
the vehicle.



(Prior Code, § 4.11.005)



§ 119.06  IMPOUNDED AND ABANDONED VEHICLES.



   (A)   Vehicles that are impounded by the Police Department shall
have a vehicle inventory form completed on the same by the officer in charge
of the scene. If an investigative hold is placed on the vehicle by the Police
Department, it will be the responsibility of the officer filing the inventory
form to note this on the form and verbally inform the wrecker operator. The
wrecker operator, by signing the form, accepts the responsibility for all
property in and on the vehicle and in case of a “hold” on the vehicle,
the wrecker operator must contact or be contacted by the Police Department in
order to release the vehicle. Vehicles that are impounded by the Police
Department shall be stored with the wrecker service that responded to the
call. The wrecker operator is to be furnished from the Police Department a
release slip stating that the bearer of the slip may have the impounded
vehicle released to him or her after charges against the vehicle have been
paid by the bearer.



   (B)   Vehicles that have been towed by reason of being abandoned,
illegally parked or in an unsafe place shall be stored at the wrecker service
lot that responded to the call. At the end often days, the vehicle may be
declared an abandoned vehicle as described in the state abandoned motor
vehicle regulations, and such action as described in the regulations shall be
executed.



(Prior Code, § 4.11.006)



§ 119.07  REMOVAL OF DEBRIS AT ACCIDENT SCENE.



   Each wrecker company called to the scene of an accident shall
completely remove from the street all resulting wreckage and debris,
including all broken glass, before leaving the site.



(Prior Code, § 4.11.007)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 119.08  NO WRECKER AT SCENE UNLESS CALLED BY POLICE OR OWNER OF VEHICLE.



   No wreckers shall arrive at the scene of an accident within the city
unless such wrecker has been called to the scene by the owner or operator of
the vehicle or his or her authorized representative or by the City Police
Department.



(Prior Code, § 4.11.008)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 119.09  SOLICITATION OF WRECKER BUSINESS PROHIBITED.



   No person shall solicit any wrecker business in any manner, directly or
indirectly, on the streets of the city at the scene of a wrecked or disabled
vehicle, regardless of whether the solicitation is for the purpose of
soliciting the business of towing, repairing, wrecking, storing, trading or
purchasing the vehicle.



(Prior Code, § 4.11.009)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 119.10  CITY EMPLOYEES NOT TO RECOMMEND WRECKER SERVICE.



   No employee of the city shall recommend to any person, directly or
indirectly, either by word, gesture, sign or otherwise, any particular
wrecker service, but may, upon request, furnish a list of licensed police
rotation wrecker services.



(Prior Code, § 4.11.010)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 119.11  APPLICABILITY OF PROVISIONS.



   The prohibitions and requirements of this chapter shall apply to all
accidents and disabled vehicles regardless of whether the final resting place
of a disabled vehicle is upon a street or upon private property.



(Prior Code, § 4.11.011)



§ 119.12  RATES POSTED WITH CHIEF OF POLICE.



   (A)   Each wrecker company on rotation must post its rates for
towing services with the Chief of Police.



   (B)   All rates shall be comparable to the rates in surrounding
cities.



(Prior Code, § 4.11.012)



§ 119.13  AUTHORITY IN EVENT OF EMERGENCY.



   In the event of an emergency, in the sole discretion of the City
Manager, the City Manager may temporarily suspend any portion of this chapter
as may be necessary for the health, safety and welfare of the public.



(Prior Code, § 4.11.013)




LICENSE




§ 119.25  REQUIRED FOR ALL ROTATION WRECKER SERVICES.



   (A)   Any wrecker service that wishes to be on police rotation must
be licensed by the city and adhere to all requirements contained in this
chapter. In addition, rotation wrecker licensees must have an office and
storage lot inside the city limits. The storage lot shall be fenced and
lighted. Each licensee wrecker service shall provide 24-hour service 365 days
a year. All wrecker services on police rotation shall have a minimum of two
or more wreckers of at least 10,000 pounds gross vehicle weight, as defined
by the manufacturer. When the city is being served with less than two wrecker
companies on rotation, the Police Chief may suspend this requirement to a
minimum of one wrecker per licensee until the Police Chief determines the
city is being adequately protected again.



   (B)   Only one police rotation wrecker license shall be required for
each licensed wrecker service company; each licensed wrecker company may add
to or delete equipment as its business dictates so long as it complies with
this chapter.



   (C)   Each wrecker used for police rotation must have its dispatch
point, both day and night, located within the city limits or within one mile
driving distance from the city limits, and the maximum response time shall
not be longer than 20 minutes from the time of dispatch by the Police
Department.



(Prior Code, § 4.11.041)



§ 119.26  APPLICATION; REQUIRED INFORMATION.



   (A)   Any person desiring a license to operate on police rotation as
set forth in this chapter shall file with the Chief of Police a written
application.



   (B)   The application shall be filled out on forms obtained from the
Chief of Police, verified by oath of the applicant and giving the following
information:



      (1)   The name, age and residence of the applicant. If the
applicant is a partnership, the name, age and residence of each partner. If
the applicant is a corporation, its name and place of incorporation; the
address of its principal place of business; a certified copy of its charter
and further, if the applicant is a foreign corporation, a duly certified copy
of its permit to do business in this state;



      (2)   The assumed or trade name, if any, under which the
applicant proposes to operate;



      (3)   The location of the business office and storage lot and
the telephone number(s) of the business office;



      (4)   An equipment list consisting of make, model, capacity
and condition of each wrecker to be permitted;



      (5)   Full disclosure pertaining to the extent of the wrecker
and related services the applicant proposes to render;



      (6)   A full and complete statement of the experience, if any,
that the applicant has had in rendering such wrecker service in the city or
elsewhere; and



      (7)   In order to obtain a license from the city, the
applicant, shall be required to execute the following agreement:



      “The undersigned covenants and agrees to, and by these
presents, does fully indemnify, hold harmless and defend the City of
Henderson, its officers, agents and employees, from and against any and all
claims, suits or causes of action for any injuries or damages to persons or
property, including death and loss of property, arising out of or incident to
the operation of this wrecker service and all other manner of operations
arising under, or otherwise incidental to the towing or storage of motor
vehicles.”



(Prior Code, § 4.11.042)



§ 119.27  REQUIRED INSURANCE.



   (A)   An applicant shall submit a certificate of insurance from an
insurance company that verifies the minimum requirement for liability
insurance as set forth in the rules promulgated by the state as authorized.
Any wrecker transporting hazardous material as defined by the U.S. Department
of Transportation shall furnish proof of the required insurance as required
by the U.S. Department of Transportation. The policy in this division (A)
above shall contain an endorsement providing for 30- days’ certified notice
to the Chief of Police in the event of any material change or cancellation of
the policy.



   (B)   Each wrecker service on police rotation shall provide a
certified copy of garage liability insurance in the amount of $100,000 or
more with extra legal care and custody.



(Prior Code, § 4.11.043)



§ 119.28  REQUIRED EQUIPMENT FOR POLICE ROTATION.



   The following shall be the minimum equipment requirement for each
licensee licensed for police rotation wrecker service.



   (A)   Each of the licensee’s wreckers shall:



      (1)   Be of at least 10,000 pounds gross vehicle weight in
size;



      (2)   Be equipped with a mechanical or hydraulic powered wench
(electric wenches are not allowed) with factory-rated capacity of not less
than 10,000 pounds single-line capacity and a minimum cable size of
three-eighths inch;



      (3)   Carry as standard equipment: a tow bar; safety chain;
extra chains; a four-pound or larger fire extinguisher; pry bar; broom or
push broom; shovel; and a container to hold wreck debris (example: plastic
bag, plastic or metal bucket and the like);



      (4)   Have inscribed on each side thereof in letters not less
than two inches in height the name of the wrecker service company doing
business;



      (5)   Be maintained so that all of its equipment shall be in a
safe and good working condition;



      (6)   Carry roof-mounted emergency lights, amber in color; and



      (7)   Carry a form of commercial communication (no citizens
band allowed).



   (B)   Each licensee shall carry at least one set of dollies for
every three wrecker vehicles operated.



   (C)   No licensed wrecker company shall use equipment too small in
gross vehicle weight rating for the size of the recovery work or vehicle they
are to pull or tow or to remove from the scene of an accident in the city;
leaving to the discretion of the police officer at the scene to call a
wrecker service that is more capable and that can handle the situation in a
safer manner. A licensed wrecker company is not required to license every
wrecker that is owned by the company, but only the wreckers that are licensed
may be used to remove wrecked, abandoned or impounded vehicles for the police
rotation wrecker service within the city.



(Prior Code, § 4.11.044)



§ 119.29  ACTION ON APPLICATION.



   In the event the Chief of Police finds that the applicant meets the
required qualifications to give proper and adequate service to the public,
the Chief of Police shall issue a license for police rotation wrecker service
to the applicant. In the event the Chief of Police does not so find, the
applicant shall be rejected, and the applicant is precluded from filing a new
application for a period of one year, except that in the event one of the
current licensee wrecker services should lose its license for any reason, the
Chief of Police may consider a reapplication at any time.



(Prior Code, § 4.11.045)



§ 119.30  REQUIRED FEES; EXPIRATION.



   The license fee for each police rotation wrecker service license shall
be on file in the City Secretary’s office. All permits issued shall expire
on December 31 of the year in which it was issued, and no license shall be
transferable.



(Prior Code, § 4.11.046)



§ 119.31  NUMBER DISPLAYED; STICKER.



   Each licensed police rotation wrecker shall be issued a city permit
sticker, which shall be displayed on each wrecker operated within the city
for police rotation wrecker service.



(Prior Code, § 4.11.047)



§ 119.32  DENIAL OR REFUSAL.



   The Chief of Police may refuse the issuance or renewal of a wrecker
rotation license for one or more of the following reasons:



   (A)   The making of any false statement as to any material matter in
the application;



   (B)   The conviction of the licensee, applicant or any employee of
the licensee or applicant for any violation of the provisions of this chapter;



   (C)   The failure to comply with any of the requirements of this
chapter or the rules or regulations established by the Chief of Police; and/or



   (D)   Conviction of an offense of driving while intoxicated, as
defined by Tex. Penal Code, § 49.04, or any crime of moral turpitude, or of
any felony.



(Prior Code, § 4.11.048)



§ 119.33  SUSPENSION FOR FAILURE TO PROVIDE INSURANCE.



   Any license issued under the provisions of this subchapter shall be
automatically suspended when the insurance required by § 119.27 has been
changed so as to no longer comply with the requirements of § 119.27 or has
been canceled. Such license shall be reinstated only after the filing of
proof of a new insurance policy meeting the requirements of § 119.27.



(Prior Code, § 4.11.049)



§ 119.34  SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION, GENERALLY.



   (A)   The Chief of Police may temporarily suspend or revoke the
license issued for any or all wreckers belonging to a licensee on any of the
following grounds:



      (1)   If a license was procured by fraudulent conduct or false
statement of material fact concerning the applicant not disclosed at the time
the application was made;



      (2)   If the licensee or any of his or her agents, servants or
employees arrives at the scene of an accident in violation of the provisions
of this chapter, with the exception of being at the scene when the accident
occurred;



      (3)   If a licensee or any of his or her agents, servants or
employees solicits any business in violation of the provisions of this
chapter;



      (4)   The licensee or an employee of the licensee has been
convicted for a violation of any of the requirements of this chapter or has
violated any of the rules or regulations established by the Chief of Police;
or



      (5)   Conviction of driving while intoxicated, as defined by
Tex. Penal Code, § 49.04.



   (B)   Such revocation of the license shall terminate all authority
and permission heretofore granted. Any person whose license has been revoked
shall not be eligible to again apply for a license for a period of one year
from the date of revocation.



(Prior Code, § 4.11.050)



§ 119.35  PROCEDURE; APPEAL.



   (A)   The Chief of Police may, at any time he or she finds a
licensee in violation of this chapter, give notice in writing to the
licensee, manager or other person in control of the operation and maintenance
of such license that the license for police wrecker rotation service has been
revoked.



   (B)   The Chief of Police shall notify the affected applicant or
licensee of any denial, suspension or revocation of a license by written
notice, mailed by certified mail, return receipt requested.



   (C)   Any denial, suspension or revocation of a license by the Chief
of Police shall become final after the expiration of three days from the date
of receipt of notice of the same, unless on or before the expiration of such
three days the licensee shall file with the City Manager a written notice of
appeal of such revocation.



   (D)   The appeal shall operate as a stay of suspension or revocation
of the license previously issued until such time as the City Manager shall
set a public hearing before the City Council.



   (E)   The appeal hearing shall be held within 30 days after the date
of filing of the appeal and any action and judgment of the City Council on
the suspension or revocation, after hearing all the evidence and facts, shall
be final and conclusive as to all parties, unless within 30 days the
aggrieved party shall file an appeal in the 4th District Court of the county.
The notice of revocation shall contain the appeal procedures stated herein.



(Prior Code, § 4.11.051)

   Chapter
